 Notes:  

H.P.R.
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: abbreviation
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: homestead pre-emptive right
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Station Years
 Author:  CRAWFORD
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Although many runholders came to regard the land they leased as their own, their occupancy was 

intended to be only a temporary using of waste land until it was required for closer settlement.  Anyone - the runholder included - could buy the freehold of all or any part of a run at any time to establish a farm. However, some protection for runholders was essential, for they could not be expected to improve their runs if the land and improvements were in danger of being freeholded

without warning by an outside buyer. Runholders were able to register with the Provincial Council improvements such as buildings, plantations, fencing, and yards, for which they were granted [246] an improvement pre-emptive right (i.P.R.) covering fifty acres of land surrounding the improvement. A homestead pre-emptive right (H.P.R.), which afforded protection for 250 acres, could also be registered. ... One H.P.R. could be taken out for each property and it was only businesslike that each runholder should use this right to secure 250 acres around his homestead against purchase by an outsider. An H.P.R. was initially intended to cover the owner's or manager's home, but, in the case of runs of over 5,000 acres, could be extended to cover an outstation.
 Notes:  [ca1878]

 Date:  4/5/1907  
 Source:  NZ Truth
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  98/2/3
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The term `hack' as understood in this country is not at all to be conflicted with the same term as applied elsewhere to horse racing under that category. A hack in New Zealand is a horse that has not won a certain amount of moneys [sic], and so it is quite possible for the Derby favorite of the year, or the New Zealand Cup favorite to be a hack.
 Notes:

Habitual Criminal
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1945  
 Source:  in Prison
 Author:  BURTON
 Vol / Page:  133
 Edition:  
 Quote:  This is an indeterminate sentence, and can only be given to a man who has been declared an Habitual Criminal. ... Unless the `Act' is lifted from him by a judge of the Supreme Court it will

continue in force for the rest of his life. Among convicts this particular sentence is is known as the `dog collar' for obvious reasons.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/11/1950  
 Source:  Here & Now
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  14
 Edition:  
 Quote:  GLOSSARY OF TECHNiCAL TERMS: A boobhead is a prisoner; a screw is a warder; a topper is a toady or an informer. The Act or the Collar - The Habitual Criminals Act, under which persons declared habitual criminals can have their sentences increased by the Prisons Board for offences against prison discipline during their incarceration.
 Notes:  (ian Hamilton `NZd's Last Flogging')

 Date:  0/0/1980  
 Source:  While We Have Prisons
 Author:  MacKENZiE
 Vol / Page:  9
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in 1953 i made a study ... of New Zealand's habitual criminals. These 520 people ... had received the accolade of New Zealand criminality ... in prison language they had been

given the `collar', the `key', the Kathleen Mavourneen sentence - `it may be for years and it may be for ever'. ... The unfortunate recipients of the new title `Habitual Criminal' would serve a head sentence of Hard Labour to be followed by an unspecified period of imprisonment which could last until death.
 Notes:

haddock
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: in early use applied to NZ fishes thought to resemble northern haddock, esp. Gadus australis.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1840  
 Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  1/202 fn
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called 

<i>para</i>[as-acute] <i> paraua</i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale,<i> mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale,  <i> tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark,  <i> mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. 


 Notes:

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRiS
 Vol / Page:  189
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Haddock, n.</i> The New Zealand <i>Haddock</i> is <i>Gadus australis</i>,  Hutton, <i>Pseudophycis barbatus</i>, Gunth, and <i>Merlucius gayi</i>, Guich., or <i>australis</i>, Hutton, all belonging to the family <i>Gadidae</i> or Cod-fishes. The European species of <i>Merlucius</i> is known as the `Hake.'
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Merriam-Webster Third international
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  202
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>HadZ.dock</i> (h&abreve.dZ.d&ubreve.k), n. <i>(zoo.l) [Add.] New Zealand haddock</i>, any one of several marine food fishes; as (a) Gadus australis; (b) various species of <i>Merlucius. </i>

 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  1/322
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Many other fish are equally numerous, answering to our  hakes, tench, bream, snapper, haddock, 

elephant-fish, pollock, salmon, gurnards, pipe-fish,  parrot-fish, leather-jackets, cole-fish, John Dorys,  sword-fish, cod; various kinds of skate  and cat-fish, sting-ray and dog-fish.

 Date:  0/6/1946  
 Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  55/148
 Edition:  
 Quote:  haeremai, cry of welcome; really two words - haere, come; mai, this way - come along! Haereatu, go away! Be off! atu, away from the speaker. [OEDS 1933] <i>ibid.</i> 150  haeremai, as this is included in the Dictionary, haerera also should be included, the former being the response to the latter.

 Notes:  

 Date:  5/8/1820  
 Source:  Journal
 Author:  CRUiSE
 Vol / Page:  134
 Edition:  1957
 Quote:  ...the women on either side waving their mats, and shouting Heromai (Come hither) to each other.  ibid. 214 [Notes] March 29th. Heromai, or `Come hither', is the salutation of peace and friendship. Where this word is not pronounced on the approach of the stranger the feelings of the people are not favourable towards him.

other expressions of applause, which are so liberally bestowed by these islanders, on those whom they may choose to honour. <i>ibid.</i> 1/160  As soon as friends ere espied ... mats were waved, the `airemai,' [e-acute] or wel-[161]come, was shouted ...

 Date:  0/0/1881  
 Source:  Poenamo
 Author:  CAMPBELL
 Vol / Page:  3/2/142
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Had we been Maoris of course we should there and then have also squatted down and rubbed noses. Hereafter i will explain why at such meetings the natives do not jump up and say how glad they are to see you, but welcome you in woe-begone `Haere mai's', squatting down and rubbing the lugubrious nose until the spectacle is anything but pleasant to look at. <i>ibid.</i>

4/4/267 The `haeremais' and `tautemais' - `come' - `come to my arms' of some blanketed figures standing near some huts seemed to exercise the most uncontrollable influence over my friends, ...

 Notes:  

haere ra
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: exclamation
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Farewell (to one departing) [Maori haere r&amacr.(phs popularised as the title of a well-known Maori song) (Williams: haere v. come; go, depart: ra av. there, yonder; or a particle denoting distance from the speaker), said to a person leaving, goodbye, farewell. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1881  
 Source:  Poenamo
 Author:  CAMPBELL
 Vol / Page:  33
 Edition:  
 Quote:  You can see a good many bundles of blankets and black top-knots scattered over the beach, all immovable. That is the native fashion of  bidding goodbye, ... [34] But meanwhile we must 

`haere' along or we shall never get clear of Herekino.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1938  
 Source:  Nor the Years Condemn
 Author:  HYDE
 Vol / Page:  169
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `Haere ra, i'm going to Napier to get my divorce.' You never hear such a korero. They don't like a divorce.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  haeremai, as this is included in the Dictionary,

haerera also should be included, the former being the response to the latter.  <i>ibid.</i> 55/151 haerera,term of farewell, said by the one who stays to the one who goes: ra, an indefinite `yonder.' The reply by the departer is: e noho (lit. sit still), or hei konei ra (for you this place).<i>ibid.</i> 151 haerera, term of farewell, said by the one who stays to the one who goes: ra, an indefinite `yonder.' The reply by the departer is: e noho (lit. sit still), or hei konei ra (for you this place). 




 Notes:   Andersen Maori Words in English

 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  Where the People Sing
 Author:  ZiMMERMAN
 Vol / Page:  42
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... the crowd came with me, and instead of saying goodby or cheer-o, they said  Haere ra' and i liked them for it, for it means, `Go, then.'
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  173
 Edition:  
 Quote:  haere ra: farewell.
 Notes:  

hag

 Notes:  Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Native Animals of NZ
 Author:  POWELL
 Vol / Page:  60
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HAG FiSH (<i>Heptatretus cirrhatus</i> ). This grows to about 2 feet in length, ... even more revolting than the lamprey, to which it is closely allied. Parts of the Otago trawling grounds are termed `hospitals' by fishermen on account of the large number of wounded fish which have received the attention of the voracious hag-fish.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An identification Guide
 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  397
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hagfish <i>Neomyxine biniplicata</i> (L.R. Richardson and Jowett) ...  Hagfish <i>Eptatretus cirrhatus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) (Syns. <i>Homea banksii</i> Fleming, <i>Bdellostoma forsteri </i>Muller and <i>B. heptatrema</i> Muller) 


 Notes:  1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 397

 Vol / Page:  23
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hagfish <i>Eptatretus cirrhatus</i> also known as blind eel; it is eel-like, but not a true eel. Hagfishes occur in cool waters throughout the world, but this species is restricted to New Zealand.

 Notes:  

haggle
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a golf bet
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  3/12/1987  
 Source:  Personal Communication
 Author:  DAViD NORTON
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A haggle is a bet between the players on a round of golf, part of the money allocated to the winner(s) of the first nine holes, part to the second nine (this amount may be doubled by the losers of the first nine), and part to the overall winner(s). Currently on Karori Golf Course: 50c, 50c, $1. Sometimes money is played for on each hole, but i dont think this is part of a haggle. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/2/1988  
 Source:  Personal Communication
 Author:  M.J. ORSMAN
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Haggle is used on Judgeford Golf Course (Pauatahanui) for playing for a small prize which all concerned share in but which losing team pays for - the whole process is called a haggle. `Are we going to have a wee haggle on the match.' 


 Notes:  

hahunga
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: ceremony of exhuming and scraping bones of the dead. 


 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1973  
 Source:  Maori Death Customs
 Author:  OPPENHEiM
 Vol / Page:  64
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [Hdg] The Display of the Bones

(Hahunga). ibid 70 in the northern

tradition the time lapse between primary

burial and Hahunga could be anything

from a few months to several years.


 Notes:  

 Date:  23/5/1828  
 Source:  Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
 Author:  WiLLiAMS
 Vol / Page:  130
 Edition:  1961
 Quote:  Tekoke and most of the natives of the settlement  had left to attend a Hahunga at Taeamai. ... [131 May 30] ... two messengers arrived from Waimate ...  to request our attendance at the Ha'hunga ... <i>ibid.</i> 244 The Chiefs Hiamoe and Pukututu came from the Kauakaua to request some of us to go up to attend the  Hahunga there, the feast which takes place at the

removal of the bones of the dead. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1835  
 Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
 Author:  YATE
 Vol / Page:  137
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hahunga, a grand annual feast ... No further notice is taken of the deceased till the Hahunga, a grand annual feast; when the [138] bones of all belonging to several united tribes are taken down, and removed to their last resting-place, in or near the sacred grove. 


 Notes:  (Griffiths Collection)

 Date:  0/0/1856  
 Source:  Traditions & Superstitions
 Author:  SHORTLAND
 Vol / Page:  147
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A very curious ceremony, called hahunga, takes place when the skulls of the dead are exhibited to their living relations before being finally deposited in the secret family vault. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1863  
 Source:  Old New Zealand
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  236
 Edition:  (Auckland edn)
 Quote:  Hahunga - A hahunga was a funeral ceremony, at which the natives usually assembled in great numbers, and during which `baked meats' were disposed of ... 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1869  
 Source:  TrNZi
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  1/iii/20
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Exhumation, or hahunga, - i.e., cleaning of the bones, - sometimes took place a year after death.
 Notes:  (Colenso Maori races)

 Date:  0/0/1873  
 Source:  Wonderland of the Antipodes
 Author:  TiNNE
 Vol / Page:  66
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The most ... interesting ceremonial ... was a `huhunga,' or bone-scraping, ... 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1895  
 Source:  TrNZi
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  27/611

 Quote:   ... the hahunga, a feast attending the ceremonial raising of a chief's bones ...

 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 Date:  0/0/1840  
 Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  1/72
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The food of the Chief mourners at an  haihunga is not allowed to be cooked by the slaves, to

whose office such labour is generally assigned, .. <i>ibid.</i>.  1/75  These orations ended, the crowds depart, and the actions, &c. of the deceased only are spoken of until the exhumation  (haihunga) takes place, about one year after the decease of the chief.

 Date:  0/0/1913  
 Source:  Old Whaling Days
 Author:  McNAB
 Vol / Page:  82
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Although the Auckland isles once abounded with numerous herds of fur and hair-seal, the ... seamen ... have made such clean work of it as scarcely to leave a breed; at all events there was not one to be found on the 4th of January, 1830. ... We searched then in vain for fur-seal ... 


 Notes:  1830 Benjamin Morrell in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 82

 Date:  0/0/1835  
 Source:  Boultbee Journal
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  105
 Edition:  1986
 Quote:  The hair seal, generally resort to places where there is plenty of fern growing and here they breed; ... they grow to larger size than the fur seal, which generally live on the barren rocks on the seaside.
 Notes:  [ed. fn 105: Sealions (Photarctos hookeri), pahkak in JB's vocabulary, were reported by Thomas Shepherd at Port Pegasus.]

haircut inflation

 Date:  2/4/1995  
 Source:  Sunday Star Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  A16
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Create yet another new definition of

inflation called haircut inflation, so

named for the odometer slice taken before

Japanese used cars are exported to New

Zealand - no matter what the total on the

odometer before the haircut, the level

afterwards is always rather low.

 Quote:  After a hard day rehearsing or performing the Hairy Maclary Hootenanny, singer and entertainer Jackie Clarke returns home to her two-year-old son Stan. And what does Stan want mum to read her [sic]? Hairy Maclary of course... Clarke first encountered Hairy Maclary a few years ago when approached.. to sing a couple of songs, including Slinky Malinki, Open the Door and the theme song for a recording.
 Notes:  

hairy shaker disease
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a congenital chorea in sheep, found mostly in Romney and Romney cross-breeds in the South island, in which birth coats of lambs are hairy. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  303
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Congenital chorea hypomyelinogenesis, Hairy shaker disease.
 Notes:  Diseases of Domestic Animals in New Zealand

haka
 Homonym Number:  2
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: the word suggests today violent and noisy

posture-dance (cf. A. 1896)
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `general term for a posture-dance; dance with song and action; usually supposed to mean a War-dance; but the real earth-shaking and nerve-shattering war-dance is peruperu, with its savage gesturing, eye-glaring, and cries demoniac, the savagest looking of which may be in pure fun and intended as hearty welcome. Both vowels must be short ...' -

haka
 Homonym Number:  2
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: in a debased form, often with meaningless Maori-looking words, and, esp. in Otago, English words and cries, a school or team form of noisy encouragement, or rally; often called `the school haka'.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1966

 Author:  McLiNTOCK
 Vol / Page:  2/679
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Perhaps the most useful and expressive of our loans from the Maori is mana, reputation, honour, etc. Another is haka, now becoming well known wherever our football teams go.

 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  2/57
 Edition:  
 Quote:  This behaviour pleased the old gentleman, who hastily jumped from the ground and began to dance a haka [a's-acute]; <i>ibid.</i> 1/81 After each of my retinue were 

presented to the chief, partaking of the honour of the ongi, or salutation, the haka [a1-acute,a2-grave], or dance of welcome, was performed. ... This dance, to a stranger witnessing it for the first time, is calculated to excite the most alarming fears; ... <i>ibid.</i> 1/86 The dance

(haka) then commenced amid the discharge of artillery.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  55/148-149
 Edition:  
 Quote:  haka, general term for a posture-dance; dance with song and action: usually supposed to mean a

war-dance; but the real earth-shaking and nerve-shattering war-dance is peruperu, with its savage 

gesturing, eye-glaring, and cries demoniac, the savagest-looking of which may be in pure fun and

intended as a hearty welcome. Both vowels must be short; h&amacr.ka and hak&amacr. differ altogether in meaning: there is no word h&amacr.k&amacr..  


 Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

 Quote:  There is a distinction in the case of the godwit (Maori kuaka, or hakakao), the season for which comprises the months of February, March, and April. 


 Notes:   [Animals Protection Act]

hakari
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: the feast after a ceremonial funeral or other important occasion; a feast, f. Maori: Williams: [Maori h&amacr.kari]
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]

 Date:  21/4/1820  
 Source:  Journal
 Author:  CRUiSE
 Vol / Page:  83
 Edition:  1957
 Quote:  One of the gentlemen ... was present at the shackerie, or harvest home (if it may be so called), of Shungie's people. it was celebrated in a wood, where a square space had been cleared of trees, in the centre of which three very tall posts, driven into the ground in the form of a triangle, supported an immense pile of baskets of koomeras.

square at the base.

 Date:  0/0/1859  
 Source:  Story of New Zealand, The
 Author:  THOMSON
 Vol / Page:  1/189
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The New Zealanders had another feast, called the hakari, very different from the hahunga. The hakari was a banquet given by nations to each other, ... Previously to the arrival of the guests the food was piled either on the ground or on wooden scaffolds. Such erections were sqare pyramidal towers having an elevation of fifty feet, or ranges of six feet high, extending from half a mile to 

two miles. There were several compartments in these receptacles for food; each being filled up with sweet potatoes, taros, maize, fern root, potted birds, dried fish, karaka berries, ... 


 Notes:  

 Date:  17/4/1863

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1985  
 Source:  Towards Taha Maori
 Author:  HOWE
 Vol / Page:  19
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hakari - this word referrred to the foodstand on which were displayed huge and varied amounts of food that a group was prepared to give its visitors, in order to maintain and increase their prestige or `mana'. (q.v.) The host group would make large personal sacrifices in order to feed visitors, and such sacrifice increased the sense of sharing both among hosts and between hosts and guests. Hakari now refers to the feast itself.
 Notes:  1985 Howe Towards `Taha Maori' in English (NZATE) 19 



 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  338

 Quote:  Another matter touching on the recurring annoyance of vernacular names is that up till 1891 <i>Lotella rhacinus</i> was universally accepted as the hake: then, in 1912, Waite, for no apparent reason, transfers this name to <i>Merluccius gayi</i>, although he admits that the records of

these fish were hopelessly mixed on the expedition. ...

 Date:  0/0/1912  
 Source:  Records of the Canterbury Museum
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  1(2):182
 Edition:  
 Quote:  This is where the confusion starts. He records <i>Merluccius gayi</i> (Guichenot)-syn. for <i>Merlus gayi</i> (Guich.) and <i>Gadus australis</i> (Hutton) - as the `hake,' and makes no independent record for <i>Physiculus rhacinus</i>, but admits that the records of the two fishes were in a state of hopeless confusion, thus tacitly admitting that specimens of both were recorded under the same name. LiTERATURE WiTH A SUMMARY OF THE DATA iN EACH CASE.


 Notes:  E. R. Waite

 Date:  0/0/1840  
 Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  1/202
 Edition:  
 Quote:   fn Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales,

called <i>para </i>[as-acute] <i>paraua </i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale,  <i>mungu nui </i> (black physeter); right whale,  <i>tohora </i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark,  <i>mango </i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

 Date:  0/0/1956

 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  164
 Edition:  2nd ed.
 Quote:  HAKE or WHiTiNG <i>Merluccius australis</i> (Hutton) Hake is [166] known in Christchurch, and by some in Otago, as Whiting, but it is not a true Whiting. in Napier, Wellington and Marlborough the Southern Kingfish (<i>Rexea solandri</i>) is caught and sold as Hake.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  28
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HAKE (a) Scientific name: <i>Merluccius australis</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Hake. (c) Other common names: Whiting; English Hake. (d) Principal localities where taken: Taken only rarely nowdays off Wellington in deep water; ... Whatever the position was years ago it is a fact that this fish is rare today. The position is further complicated by the almost indiscriminate use of the name hake, by fishermen, [for] other species of fish. ... The name Hake shold not be applied to either Southern kingfish or the Whiptail although there can be little, if any, objection to the commercial name of Blue Hake for the latter species.

 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An identification Guide
 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  315
 Edition:  2nd ed.
 Quote:  SOUTHERN KiNGFiSH or HAKE (TiKATi) <i>Rexea solandri</i> (Cuv. and Val.) .../ This fish is known as Hake in Auckland. in New South Wales it is often caught by trawlers in one hundred and fifty fathoms and is known as King Barracouta. it is a favoured food fish. in Tasmania it is referred to as Tasmanian Kingfish. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1957  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
 Author:  PARROTT
 Vol / Page:  43
 Edition:  
 Quote:  There is much confusion in the common names applied to New Zealand fishes, and the application of the name `Hake' to several distinct species of our fishes, is a good example of that confusion. in Blenheim, Nelson, Picton and Wellington, a very  different fish, scientifically known as <i>Rexea solandri</i>, and closely related to the Barracouta, with obviously no affinities to the Cod family, is called `Hake' or `Southern Kingfish'. The name Hake applied to this fish is entirely wrong, as it belongs to the Snake Mackerel family, the <i>Gempylidae. </i>

<i>ibid.</i> 154 SOUTHERN KiNGFiSH <i>Rexea solandri</i> (Cuv. & Val.) ... The Southern Kingfish is closely related to the Barracouta, and is known in the North island as the `hake' but this name is more accurately applied to a very different fish, <i>Merlangius australis</i>, which belongs to the true Cod family. <i>ibid.</i> 155 [Southern Kingfish, <i>Rexea Solandri</i>] is found also in southern Australian waters. in Sydney it is sold as `hake'. it is also known as `Hake' in Auckland and sometimes sold as `lemon-fish'. <i>ibid.</i> 170 Southern Kingfish Rexea solandri Hake 


 Notes:

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Fisherman's Bible
 Author:  WiLSON
 Vol / Page:  30
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HAKE: See Southern Kingfish <i>ibid.</i> 200 SOUTHERN KiNGFiSH <i>Jordanidia solandri</i>. This is the King Barracouta of Australia and the so-called Hake of more southern New Zealand waters. <i>ibid.</i> 201 [The Southern Kingfish is] Called Hake in southern fish shops but bears no resemblance to the traditional English Hake which is far less oily. Tasmanian kingfish,  barraconda and `tikati' (Maori) are other names. <i>ibid.</i> 141 Another so-called Kingfish occurs in southern New Zealand  waters but this is no relative of <i>Seriola Grandis</i>. He is the Silver Kingfish, who is sometimes called Hake and known in Australia as Gemfish.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
 Author:  BURTON
 Vol / Page:  75
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hake is a slender, silvery-grey fish found mainly in southern coastal waters, although it is now  not as plentiful as it used to be.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An identification Guide
 Author:  PAUL
 Vol / Page:  121
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Gemfish <i>Rexea solandri</i> ... Also occurs off southern Australia, as well as Japan. New Zealand names include silver or southern kingfish and hake (which is now easily confused with the true hake). The name gemfish, conveying family relationship as well as irridescence, is more appropriate.

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  28
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HAKE  (a) Scientific name:  <i>Merluccius australis</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Hake. (c) Other common names: Whiting; English Hake. (d) Principal localities where taken: Taken only rarely nowadays off Wellington in deep water; ... Whatever the position was years ago it is a fact that this fish is rare today. The position is further complicated by the almost indiscriminate use of the name hake, by fishermen, [for] other species of fish. ... The name Hake shold not be applied to either Southern kingfish or the Whiptail although there can be little, if any, objection to the commercial name of Blue Hake for the latter species.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An identification Guide
 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  172
 Edition:  2nd
 Quote:  ROCK COD or SOUTHERN HAKE <i>Lotella rhacinus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) Up to 1891 this fish was universally known to scientists and fishermen  as Hake, then for some unknown reason E. R. Waite (<i>Records of the Canterbury Museum</i>, Vol. 1, No. 3) transferred the name Hake to <i>Merluccius gayi</i>, with Whiting as a second alternative common name. ... The most common name among Otago fishermen was Rock Cod, because this fish favours a rocky habitat.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Guide
 Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  210
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [ROCK COD] ROCK COD ... <i>Other names: Lotella rhacinus</i>; Cloudy Bay cod, southern hake.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
 Author:  McLiNTOCK
 Vol / Page:  1/373
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Cloudy Bay cod (<i>Lotella rhacinus</i>), also known as rock cod and southern hake, is rather more brown and lacks the dark blotch by the pectoral fin. <i>ibid.</i> 1/898 HAKE is a name applied to several quite different marine fish in  different parts of the country. The whiting or haddock, <i>Merluccius  australis</i>, is a true hake, very similar to the North Sea species; it is, actually, often called English hake. it occurs in fairly deep  water south of Cook Strait. The southern kingfish, <i>Jordanidia  solandri</i>, is also known as hake: it is closely related and similar to the barracouta, and found throughout New Zealand. The Cloudy Bay cod, <i>Lotella rhacinus</i>, is sometimes known as southern hake.(see also Kingfish.) 


 Notes:

hakoke
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1985  
 Source:  Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  308
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Extinct birds ... Laughing Owl <i>Sceloglaux albifacies</i> (GRAY, 1844) OTHER NAMES: 

Whekau, hakoke (North island),rock owl. The `doleful shrieks' of the laughing owl, which varied seasonally, were heard incessantly on rainy nights. Apparently it was easily kept in captivity, and reports say that it cooeyed in the evening, yelped like a young dog and mewed and chuckled. ... The most recent record of sighting was at Manapouri in 1950 ...

 Citations 
hakuwai
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: A  Maori legendary bird, said to be heard at night but never seen. (Suggested originals include frigate bird, Haast's eagle; the most probable being Miskelly below, i.e. NZ snipe in display flights.)  See also hokioi.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  11/9/1912  
 Source:  Otago Witness
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  76
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Many legends are associated with the

mythical bird "hokioi"... in the South

and in some parts of the North island it

is identical, apparently, with the

"hakuwai" which has seven joints in its

wing, lives in the sky, and presages

trouble... "its cry was Hokioi! Hokioi!

Hu!" The last word represented the

whizzing sound made by the bird in

flight.


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1964  
 Source:  Little World of Stewart island
 Author:  DEMPSEY
 Vol / Page:  61
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Mysterious Ha-ka-wai Bird [heading] No-one has ever seen it, no-one knows what it is like.

Mutton-birders who have heard the strange sound of its passing over the islands at night speak of the ha-ka-wai bird. A swish of wings close overhead, a sound like the rattle of chains when a boat lets the anchor down, again the sound of wingbeats and the cry floating earthward from the heavens,  Ha-ka-wai! Ha-ka-wai! in a drawn-out singsong with accent on the first and last syllables.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1906  
 Source:  TrNZi
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  38/340
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A strange bird in Maori eyes is the hakuai of the off-shore islands in the far south. ... Whole families go mutton-birding ... At night the fowlers gather round their camp-fires, and old songs are sung ... and ghost-stories retold. And in the darkness sometimes they hear the ghost-bird 

screaming its `Haku-ai, haku-ai, Ooh!' and then a hair-raising swoosh of great wings ... This bird, called the `hakuai' from its call, is spoken of as a spirit. ... The mystery of the  hakuai may be dispelled by assuming it to be ... the  frigate-bird (Fregata aquila). 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/8/2000  
 Source:  NZWords
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  No. 4: 5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Maori word <i>hakuwai</i> (or <i>hakawai</i> or <i>hakuai</i>, or any of at least five other variant spellings, including the European <i>harkowhy</i>) was defined by Williams in his <i>Maori Dictionary</i> as 'an extinct bird heard at night'.

 Date:  0/0/1989

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  From Beads to Banknotes
 Author:  HARGREAVES
 Vol / Page:  151
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Half crown [:] half dollar, half bull
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/10/1977  
 Source:  NZ Numismatic Journal
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five  bob, and most familiar of all a dollar, ... 

The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull,  half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and 

two-and-a-buck. in the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only two bob being recorded as being in use in New Zealand.

 Date:  3/6/1843

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  258
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Coming to a country where there were no legal means of enforcing such rights, when objected to, did the first settlers expect to walk into every acre without opposition? or, if not, were the Company to provide an army to give possession by force? or, if not that, did they believe that the cupidity of the half-savage was not inextinguishable by feeding it, and that additional gifts and presents would not be building a barrier to keep them from their lands?
 Notes:  

 Date:  4/1/1862  
 Source:  Taranaki Herald
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  it may have suited those who were favourable to the success of the "King movement" to conceal its real purport; while others, who have cherished so much affection for the natives or professed so much interest in their welfare, may have been blinded to the inevitable results of encouraging such dangerous aspirations among the half-savage chiefs and tribes ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1930  
 Source:  Yesterdays in Maoriland
 Author:  REiSCHEK
 Vol / Page:  7
 Edition:  (1933) H.E.L. Priday Preface 7
 Quote:  Perhaps, also, he will help to remind them how good, how strenuous life was `in the good old days,' when their Dominion was still half-savage, still unsettled after the toughest of colonial wars, and before the fire and axe of succeeding generations of peaceful settlers had robbed her of so much of her incomparable possession, the native bush.
 Notes:  1930 Andreas Reischek Yesterdays in Maoriland (1933) H.E.L. Priday Preface 7

halfbeak
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: garfish, skipper, ihi,  garfish (from the name `reporhamphus', descriptive of the fish).
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1872  
 Source:  Edible Fishes
 Author:  HECTOR
 Vol / Page:  118
 Edition:  
 Quote:  This name is applied both to the SKiPPER (<i>Scombresox  Forsteri</i>) and to the ihi or Half Beak (<i>Hemiramphus intermedius</i>) which are allied fishes representing those of the same names in the British seas.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1886  
 Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
 Author:  SHERRiN
 Vol / Page:  33
 Edition:  
 Quote:  GAR FiSH (<i>Hemiramphus intermedius</i>). ... [34] This name is  applied both to the skipper (<i>Scombresox Forsteri</i>) and to the ihi or half-beak, which are allied fishes representing those of the same names in the British seas. The representatives of the former genus, however, though common in England, appear to be rare in these seas, while the half-beak, which is of rare occurrence in the British seas, is common all round New Zealand, and is the ordinary gar-fish that is so highly appreciated, especially in Auckland and Dunedin. 

<i>ibid.</i> 40 HALF-BEAK (see GAR FiSH).
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An identification Guide
 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  157
 Edition:  (2nd edn)
 Quote:  GARFiSH or PiPER (TAKEKE) <i>Reporhamphus ihi</i> Phillipps. This fish is known in Auckland as Piper, although in Otago it is called Garfish or Guard Fish. ... it is on account of this peculiarity [a long bottom jaw] that they are sometimes called Halfbeaks. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1957  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
 Author:  PARROTT
 Vol / Page:  34
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The name Half-beaks, which is generally applied to [garfish] in other countries, refers to their uniquely formed mouth, in which the upper jaw is normal, but it is the lower jaw which is produced into a long beak-like process. <i>ibid.</i> 169 Garfish <i>Reporhamphus ihi</i> Piper; Guard-fish; Half-beak
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Guide
 Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  206
 Edition:  
 Quote:  GARFiSH ... <i>Other names: Reporhamphus ihi</i>; piper, half-beak; ihe, takeke (Maori). 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1967

 Author:  MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  16
 Edition:  
 Quote:  GARFiSH [<i>Reporhamphus ihi</i>] ... Also called piper, halfbeak, ihi, and takake. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1970

 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  29
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HALFBEAK (a) Scientific name: <i>Reporhamphus ihi</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Garfish; Piper. (c) Other common names: None known. (d) Principal localities where taken:

North Auckland, Auckland and Cook Strait.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Fisherman's Bible
 Author:  WiLSON
 Vol / Page:  115
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Garfish, or Piper, or Long-Tom (Australia) or Half-beak is distinct from the New Zealand Needlefish which has a beak on both upper and lower jaws, the Piper's is only on the lower jaw. 

<i>ibid.</i> 120  HALF-BEAK <i>See Garfish </i>

half-bred
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: of Maoris,  half-caste
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  22/5/1844  
 Source:  Diary
 Author:  TUCKETT
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  At each place which i have visited, i have been assured that the Maories are dying rapidly - 

`perishing like rotten sheep,' these people often say; thus at Kurreroo or Molineux, where there are now half-a-dozen natives, they say that formerly, and at no remote period, about two generations previous to the present, there were above a thousand; and in many other places within the last sixteen years, which is about the extent of the experience of the older beachers, there has been, in many places, a corresponding diminution of numbers. if this is an unexaggerated statement, it is a very distressing one to reflect on. Since Dr. -- visited this settlement, one of the residents, Mr. --, an educated man, has opened a school for half-bred or any other children, and the progress which the children have already made is very encouraging. 


 Notes:  1844 May 22 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 223

 Date:  21/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Halfbred sheep. Originally only applied to a sheep by a longwool ram from a merino ewe, but now loosely applied to the type. Corriedale sheep  were originally called inbred hb. Now in-bred hb. flocks are those which reintroduce merino or longwool blood, while he Corrie- dale flocks can only introduce Corriedale blood. (C.)
 Notes:  Acland Glossary

 Date:  0/0/1936  
 Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  416
 Edition:  
 Quote:  This term [Half-bred] covers: (1) the progeny of any distinct breed of long-woolled ram mated with merino ewes; (2) the progeny of merino rams mated with any breed of long-woolled ewe; (3) the progeny from the mating of half-bred with half-bred. The wool produced by sheep from the above crossing is termed `half-bred' and ranges from 48's to 56's quality. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1938

 Author:  BURDON
 Vol / Page:  116
 Edition:  
 Quote:  When the frozen meat trade started, the change from Merino to crossbred, or halfbred, as they are called, became more rapid; but there was another reason for it as well.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  Off the Sheep's Back
 Author:  RiCHARDS
 Vol / Page:  97
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... my style of breaking out the neck by turning the head and coming out behind the ears could not be applied on these loose, wrinkle-necked half-breds.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1987  
 Source:  Boards, Blades & Barebellies
 Author:  OGONOWSKA-COATES
 Vol / Page:  96
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Halfbred. Breed of sheep developed from the Merino and one of the long-wooled breeds - Leicester, Lincoln or Romney. it is a dual-purpose meat/wool sheep with emphasis on wool production. Has a fine to medium wool that sells well. is mainly found in the South island foothills but is sometimes grazed with Merinos in the higher regions of the Southern Alps. 


 Notes:  

half-bred
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a breed of sheep developed in New Zealand through the crossing of Merino with one or other of the long-woolled breeds: English Leicester, Lincoln and Romney. [1800s]


 Origin: [none]
 Register:

half-bred country
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a low-country pastoral area where half-breds, less hardy than Merinos, can safely be grazed all year round.

half-bull

 See:

Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  14/1/1899  
 Source:  Sydney Bulletin
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:   (Red Page)
 Edition:  
 Quote:   (Loafer from Loafer, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]  Following are other local money-names...2.6d half  -bull, half-caser or two-and-a-buck... 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  From Beads to Banknotes
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  151
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Half crown [:] half dollar, half bull
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/10/1977  
 Source:  NZ Numismatic Journal
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five  bob, and most familiar of all a dollar ... 

The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull,  half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and  two-and-a-buck. in the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only two bob being recorded as being in use in New Zealand.
 Notes:  

half-canned
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Half = `fairly': OED a common formation with half : adverbial - tacked on when the sense suits.

 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]

 Date:  0/0/1980  
 Source:  Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
 Author:  LELAND
 Vol / Page:  50
 Edition:  
 Quote:   half g:Now superceded by its metric equivalent (2.25 liters). This is the standard sized bottle for taking home draught beer from the hotel. if there are only one or two of you, then 2-3 of these would be standard. Oh yes, a half g is HALF AN iMPERiAL GALLON bottle, almost always containing draught beer.

 Quote:   i thought, two loaves [would be enough]. `Two loaves? As much as that?' ... And my husband came home with two two-pound loaves and said that [3] was all the bread they could spare at the moment, but that later they might be able to spare another half-loaf. `i stared  at the bread. `But i meant two little loaves.' i had in fact been thinking of one-pound loaves. ... But it took me some

time to remember that in Stewart island,  one loaf meant four pounds of bread.

half-pie
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 3
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Transport Workers' Song Book
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  11
 Edition:  
 Quote:  i'd tell them what i think o'them ... . . There's no half-pie about this kid- -->i have never heard the Part. use, or heard of it. Half-pie =half -' used frequently, and perhaps has Maori origin (check Wms), quotes Finlayson - Maori Nthland, and i have heard it frequy in Hlock.  Part cf pyah. `weak; paltry; inferior; useless.' mainly  naut. (1864) pye A contraction of pariah-dog: Anglo -

ind mily (-1886) Yule and Burnell.  P: Sup. pie-ard straight fr. the Hindustani comes the R.A.F. 

Regulars' nuance `any dog' (Jackson) The Army in Nth Africa (1940-3) used pie-dog of any desert dog. [all of which is muddy and contradictory: possibly pie a corruption or derivn fr. 

Hindi - check] 


 Notes:  

half-pie
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: imperfect; half-way; (neither one thing nor the other); mediocre (sometimes used to express an unsatisfactory incompleteness), (cf. its neither my arse nor John Jackson's); or else (of

mechanical things) merely = `half' cf 1950 quotation.  [poss. from Ma. pai good]. 

Half-and-half; half-way; (neither one thing nor the other); mediocre (sometimes used to express an unsatisfactory incompleteness), (cf. its neither my arse nor John Jackson's); or else (of

mechanical things) merely = `half' cf 1950 quotation.

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
 Author:  TURNER
 Vol / Page:  49
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The word half-pie means `incompletely realized' or `only half'. it often occurs in inarticulate colloquial speech, very frequently with some speakers, as an equivalent of `sort of' or `kind of' when exact words will not come. Some derive it from Maori pai `good'.

Some keen pupils attended both schools...

halfway house

 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: hotel (orig. cf OED halfway to one's destination, and so a convenient stopping-place);

Looking about for lambs with halo hairs, Dr Dry found a ram plentifully supplied with them.

Hamilton jetboat
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a boat propelled by a Hamilton jet unit, designed by Sir Charles William ("Bill") Fielden Hamilton [1899-1978].


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  23/6/1984  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  69
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The books deals first with the experimental years in the development of the unit and jet boat in Hamilton's work shop... The book also recounts the development of different makes of jet unit following the success of the Hamilton jet unit overseas, particularly in America.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1983  
 Source:  Jet Boat
 Author:  BLOXHAM
 Vol / Page:  1
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A jet boat is a standard boat fitted with a car engine to drive a sophisticated pump or "jet unit". This draws water in through an intake in the bottom of the hull and forces it out at high pressure, jet-like, through a nozzle in the rear. Unlike a conventional boat, the jet boat has neither propellor or rudder. instead, it is pushed along, and steered, simply by the thrust of the jet stream
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1983  
 Source:  Jet Boat
 Author:  BLOXHAM
 Vol / Page:  xi
 Edition:  
 Quote:  For 30 years Sir William Hamilton's 'jet boat' has given thousands of New Zealanders pleasure and excitement as well as useful commercial service
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1983

 Quote:  Career Options

A range of positions in local industry for those wanting a career in the building and construction industry. Employment opportunities are as hammer-hand, a trainee carpenter, or construction labourer - then progressing to leading hand, and later qualified tradesperson.

 Date:  0/0/1840  
 Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  1/202 fn
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para[as-acute] <i>paraua</i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, <i>mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale, <i>tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, <i>mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

 Date:  21/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hand.- Man employed. Seldom used without qualification, as  extra h., shed h., etc., except in the plural. Everyone  employed on a station is a s[tation] h., except the manager and cadets, and perhaps the cook. `All hands' and `all hands and the cook' are common expressions for `everybody' among the hands themselves. (C.)
 Notes:  Acland Glossary

 Notes:  

handpiece
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: hand-held part of a shearing machine, used to comb and shear off fleece wool. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1974  
 Source:  Never a Dull Moment
 Author:  MACiNTOSH
 Vol / Page:  113
 Edition:  
 Quote:  How i welcomed an unexpected stop for a change of cutter or comb on the handpiece.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1991  
 Source:  A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms
 Author:  SQUiRE
 Vol / Page:  22
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Handpiece - That part of the shearing machinery, held in the hand by the barrel, which, by the action of a cutter moving across a comb, shears the wool off the sheep.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1955  
 Source:  Wool Away!
 Author:  BOWEN
 Vol / Page:  4
 Edition:  
 Quote:  One hears some shearers called butchers. in fact, it is not the shearer that does the butchering, it is the comb on his handpiece.

hand-strip
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: verb
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: to milk first few drops of milk, and last few drops of milk, from a cow's bag by hand, using a machine for the main milking.

 Notes:  

handy dog
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a non-specialist working dog; a general-purpose sheep dog that will head, hunt, back, and perform.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  25/11/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work.

The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some  dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special  slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually 

slew (q.v.). (C.) 


 Notes:  Acland Glossary

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Wayleggo
 Author:  NEWTON
 Vol / Page:  13
 Edition:

 Date:  0/0/1951  
 Source:  High Country
 Author:  McLEOD
 Vol / Page:  5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  So the musterer of to-day, with his pack of five or six dogs, began to take shape. One or two of the border type - `heading dogs' as they're called now and three or four huntaways and `handy' dogs. <i>ibid.</i> 46 . . .Wait, the most wonderful dog i ever saw, a true `handy' dog. He would

bring sheep out of any place where dog or sheep could go, and all his master ever said to him was `Here Wait! Here Wait!'; the rest was left to his own judgment and initiative and the sheep would be got.

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
 Author:  McGiLL
 Vol / Page:  54
 Edition:  
 Quote:  hang of a/hanguva intensive regarding something big or forceful; euphemistic version of `helluva'; a fervent intensive favoured by juveniles; eg `That was a hanguva good flick, eh? NZA.  - like hang euphemistic phrase for `like hell'; eg `That was a hang of a good movie, eh?' `Like hang it was!' NZA.

 Edition:  
 Quote:  There is a big difference between being stoned and `being held'. Addicts have to be at least held for their body responses to be `normal'. This is how the methadone programme works. it ...

holds addicts, depending on their dosages, for about 24 hours, before they start hanging out...Peter's early-days addiction routine started with a `ping' in the morning and a cup of coffee. ... The time of the day he started `hanging out' depended on a number of factors, including work pressure. He would have a minimum of three pings a day, a maximum of about six... When addicts are hanging out they will hassle around, do and pay anything to get a ping.

 Vol / Page:  118
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>GENiOSTOMA LiGUSTRiFOLiUM, hangehange</i>. A common, lightly branched shrub of

lowland forest margins and track-sides in the North island ... The waxy-surfaced, apple-green leaves ... might commend this as a desirable garden shrub were it not that the small greenish flowers, ... have an odd smell that gives rise to the name `pigwood' in some districts.

 Notes:  

hangi
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Native oven, consisting of a circular hole in the ground, in which the food was cooked by heated stones; the contents of a hangi; a) an earth oven, or its contents; b) a communal meal cooked in an earth oven:1979 HNZD;  =copper Maori, =umu.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1963  
 Source:  O Te Raki
 Author:  KEANE
 Vol / Page:  190
 Edition:  
 Quote:  hangi: Maori oven consisting of a hole in the ground in which stones are heated by a fire. Branches and leaves (or, nowadays, sacks) are placed on top, sprinkled with water, and then

the earth is piled on and stamped flat. The food is then steamed for several hours.

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
 Author:  BURTON
 Vol / Page:  1
 Edition:  
 Quote:  There are countless ways of preparing food Maori style, but basically there were only three ways of cooking it. The first, which  involves steaming in a subterranean oven called an umu or hangi, 

is known as tao cooking. it was the preferred method of cooking for groups of people, from family size up, in a village setting.
 Notes:

 Author:  CAMPBELL
 Vol / Page:  Bk2/2/61
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Pakeha was much too valuable an animal in those days to be killed and eaten; that game did not pay at all. Cannibal feasts did come off now and again on the sly, but the Pakeha was too dear a morsel, and moreover, was far too salt to be put into a Hangi (native oven) for epicurean Maories. <i>ibid.</i> Bk2/6/107 ... the steam was just arising from their hangis as these were being uncovered, and we were all soon served, each with a little freshly-plaited flax-leaf basket filled with most deliciously cooked kumeras, potatoes and peppies.

 Notes:  

hangi stone
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a large stone, composed of rock which heats and holds heat quickly in an hangi or uinderground oven.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
 Author:  BURTON
 Vol / Page:  1
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The ideal hangi stones are porous volcanic rocks, about the size of a fist, which are light and easily heated. Next best are the variety of metallic-coloured bluestone found in the Auckland area, or the dense riverbed boulders which are often found in deep mud. ... in some areas deposits of good hangi stones are rare, and in former times a set of stones was a welcome gift.

Hanging Bailey
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  History of Children's Play
 Author:  SUTTON-SMiTH
 Vol / Page:  259
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Civilization is saved, for example, when instead of trying to torture a classmate a child says, `Guess what happened to Bailey?' `What?' `This,' and the child pulls out the fold in a piece of paper on which Bailey has been drawn with his neck in a noose, When the fold is pulled out his neck suddenly appears as stretched several inches in length - a nice little game known as Hanging Bailey.

 Vol / Page:  54
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HANGiNG-WALL.- The upper wall of an inclined vein.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1978  
 Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
 Author:  McARA
 Vol / Page:  323
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hangingwall: The uppermost or overhanging wall of the reef opposite the footwall within which the reef was confined. As the reef was usually [324] inclined at an angle, when it was taken out one wall was overhanging. in the upper workings the hangingwall tended to be unstable 


 Notes:

 Quote:  Hanging wall: the uppermost wall of an inclined reef or lode.

hangman's blood
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1978  
 Source:  Thoroughbreds Are My Life
 Author:  TUCKER
 Vol / Page:  16
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in our ranks was a very hard-headed gentleman by the name of Jensen who, on arriving at the pub, breasted up to the bar and ordered a `hangman's blood'. The barman confessed total ignorance of just what this drink might comprise. He was told to produce a beer handle, which 

he did, and was then ordered to go along [17] the entire length of the bar, putting in one nip of whatever spirits were on display. Now at that time spirits were very hard to come by, but Paul Rabone, the proprietor of the Mangatara Hotel, seemed to have an inexhaustible supply. Doing as he was bid the barman proceeded from one end to the other, putting in such things as scotch, gin, bacardi, rum, creme de menthe, and so on. He finally returned to the prospective quaffer of this incredible beverage with the beer mug about quarter-full of a purplish looking liquid. `Now,' said Jensen, `Fill it up with beer.'
 Notes:

Hansard

 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  20/8/2003  
 Source:  Capital Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  2
 Edition:  
 Quote:  He just kept on subscribing to pink-covered Hansards, milking too-few cows, avoiding screwing roosters' necks, going to the footie and giving her plenty of space to do her own thing.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/5/2003  
 Source:  NZ Geographic
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  N o. 63/58
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hansard takes its name from the Hansard family, which ran one of the many private-sector companies producing reports on House of Commons debates in the early  [60] 19th century. At the time, no official record was kept of what was said in debates, only of decisions made. Where the Hansards made their name was by producing their reports more quickly than their competitors did.
 Notes:

 Edition:  
 Quote:  CONGERMURAENA HABENATA (Richardson). <i>Silver-eel</i>. Called `hao' by the Arahura Maoris. Rare in Auckland and Wellington markets, and not greatly utilized as a food fish. Distribution: New Zealand coasts (not recorded from Bay of islands).

hapua
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a shallow lake
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  16/1/1844  
 Source:  Southern Districts of NZ
 Author:  SHORTLAND
 Vol / Page:  219
 Edition:  
 Quote:  From the spot where Huruhuru left us our path lay along a pebble ridge, with the sea on one side, and the lake Waihao on the other. This `hapua,' as all similar pieces of water are called, has no outlet to the sea except at times of floods, when one is made by the bank of pebbles breaking down at its weakest point: at other times its water oozes through the pebbles and sand. After leaving Waihao, which was nearly three miles long, we passed several small `hapua' similar to it. 

<i>ibid.</i> 307 HAPUA, a shallow lake, the termination of a river, separated from the sea by a bank of sand or shingles. Syn. hopua.
 Notes:  1844 Jan 16 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 219

 Date:  0/0/1914

 Date:  0/0/1945  
 Source:  Maori Place-Names of Canterbury
 Author:  BEATTiE
 Vol / Page:  45
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Waitarakao, a large `hapua' or lagoon or sheet of water. <i>ibid/.</i> 64 Koareare is the edible part of the root of the raupo, and was got in the hapua (lagoons) and re (swamps). The name runs off the tongue glibly when given its southern pronunciation, `ko-a-ray-a-ray'. 


 Notes:  

hapuku
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: an important commercial fish =Cod 3b3 2b and grouper 2c. 1844 W Wakefield 1944 W & T Mod Jun Dice ed7 1960 Doogue & Moreland NZ Sea Angler guide 209 1946 JPS 1491966 Turner.] [Maori hapuku[a-micron].] Polyprion oxygeneios; 1. hapuku [`ha:puku] becomes English [ha:`puk],and a mishearing of Maori [p] phoneme gives the commonest pronunciation [ha:`buk]  2. whapuku [` a:puku] [`wa: puku] gives similarly [hwa:`pukd] [wa:`buk] etc. 

3. Forms with no initial aspirate may be due to a) de-aspiration in vulgar English b) Maori dialectal de-aspiration (cf. Whangaroa - (North island) Akaroa (South island) initial. in more Maori districts the stress is often on the initial syllable, as in Maori, but in NZ colloquial it is more usually on the second syllable; the Eng. plural can have an -s inflexion; Obsolete (and sometimes mistaken) names include:  (New Zealand) cod, cod-fish, rock cod;  formerly called New Zealand cod,  =groper.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes:

against that of the hapuka, a cod, which is considered poisonous, but it has been

partaken of by Europeans without inconvenience.

 Date:  0/0/1882  
 Source:  Brighter Britain
 Author:  HAY
 Vol / Page:  2/151
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. in the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga). <i>ibid..</i> 2/ 231 We prefer the substantial schnapper, the goodly whapuka or kanae, or the luscious poraki.

 Date:  0/0/1886  
 Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
 Author:  SHERRiN
 Vol / Page:  40
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HAPUKU (<i>Oligorus gigas</i>). The first on the list of marketable  fishes is the hapuku, or whapuku of the Maoris (<i> Hectoria gigas </i> of Count Castelnau), or habuka, as the name is generally pronounced by Europeans, who in the south, apply the name groper to the same fish. it is also occasionally called the cod-fish, which is altogether erroneous, as it is more properly the representative of the sea-perch of European seas. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1892  
 Source:  NZ Official Handbook
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  167
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand, we have among the constant residents on all parts of our coast the hapuku, tarakihi, trevally, moki, aua, rock-cod, wrasse, and patiki; and while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are confined to the south.

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRiS
 Vol / Page:  192
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i> Hapuku </i>... Maori name for a fish, <i>Oligorus gigas</i>, Gunth., called later <i> Polyprion prognathus </i> (see quotation, 1895), pronounced  hapuka, frequently corrupted into habuka, the Groper  (q.v.). it is variously called a <i> cod,</i> a <i> Perch </i>, and a  <i> Sea-Perch </i>. See quotations.

 Date:  0/0/1938  
 Source:  Nor the Years Condemn
 Author:  HYDE
 Vol / Page:  234
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Starkie never struck trouble but once, when he asked  [on the transtasman boat] for some 

<i> hapuka</i> at breakfast. A very young English steward commanded: `You cut out that language in front of the women.'  `i asked for <i> hapuka.  Hapuka</i>. Just plain  <i> hapuka</i>.' `There you are,' yelled the steward. `He said it again. Said it three times.' ... `For Christ's sake,' said the chief steward wearily: `Get him some fried fish.' `Fish? is that all it means? i thought , in front of the women . . .'  `in front of the women or behind their backs,  <i> hapuka's</i> still fish and fish is still <i> hapuka</i> fathead,' explained Starkie, ... 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  55/149
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>h&amacr.puku</i>, a sea-fish (Oligorus gigas), groper, vulg. harbuka. <i>ibid.</i> 55/150 <i>h&amacr.puku</i> is not the cod, which is p&amacr.kirikiri (Percis colias): groper is the common name, or hapuka corrupted to harbuka.

 Date:  0/0/1957  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
 Author:  PARROTT
 Vol / Page:  70
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Groper is known more generally in the North island by the name `Hapuka', and by Europeans this name is often spelt `Whapuka' or `Habuka'. <i>ibid.</i> 169  [whapuku, -->whapuka] Groper Polyprion oxygeneios Hapuku; Hapuka; Habuka; Whapuka 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1958  
 Source:  Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  193
 Edition:  8th
 Quote:  <i>hapuku (ha|-pu-ka)</i>. The Maori name for a large edible fish, also called `groper'. Often

mispronounced <i>ha-pu-ka. </i>
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1961  
 Source:  Merriam-Webster Third international
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  2599
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>whapuku n</i> -s [Maori] : a large edible marine fish  (<i>Polyprion oxygeneios</i>) of New Zealand waters that is closely related to or perhaps identical with the stonebass 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
 Author:  McLiNTOCK
 Vol / Page:  2/679
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The vocabulary of New Zealand English has been influenced by ... the adoption of Maori words and phrases. ... Examples of the native words now in  general use are the names of birds, fish, plants, and trees: <i>kea</i>, tui, hapuku, tarakihi, koromiko, raupo, <i>and </i>kauri. <i>ibid.</i> 3/705-12 Hapuku (groper).. .. hapuku, kapua, whapuku .. .. <i>Polyprion oxygeneios </i>

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Guide
 Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  224
 Edition:  
 Quote:  GROPER or HAPUKU ... <i>Other names: Polyprion oxygeneios</i>; whapuku (Maori). Groper has a wide usage in the South island, while hapuku is largely used in the North island. The word `hapuka' is a corruption of hapuku.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  Marine Fishes
 Author:  MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  52
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HAPUKU or GROPER [<i>Polyprion oxygeneios</i>] ... Hapuku is a Maori name widely used by North island fishermen, while groper has a predominantly South island usage. in some localities both names are used.

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  26
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>GROPER</i> (two species) (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Polyprion oxygeneios</i> (ii) <i>Polyprion moeone</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) New Zealand Groper; Hapuku (ii) Bass. (c) Other common names: (i) Hapuka, Stone-eye, Blue-nose, Bonita (ii) Deepsea Groper. (d) Principal localities where taken: [Mainly easten coasts, Foveaux, and Chathams] ... [27 Groper and Bass] should not be confused with the 

Australian and tropical groupers which they resemble superficially.

 Vol / Page:  82
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Hapuku Polyprion oxygeneios</i> ... Widely known throughout New Zealand as either hapuku (often pronounced hapuka) or groper, the former generally in the North island, the latter in the South. The species also occurs around southern Australia.

 Date:  0/0/1842  
 Source:  New Zealand (Heaphy)
 Author:  HEAPHY
 Vol / Page:  48
 Edition:  
 Quote:   [<i>Abuka </i>, (Chatham islands) -->apuko] Amongst those esteemed the most, the <i>Abuka </i> ranks first. it is generally of great size, but the flesh is of much delicacy of flavour. A considerable quantity of it is cured at the whaling stations for winter provision, and is very fine. i have seen this fish being carried along the beach of Wellington, on a pole, borne by two natives, who found its weight fully equal to their united strength. [124] The same fish that are found on the coast of New Zealand may be caught in plenty in Port Wakefield [Chatham islands] ... The great apuko, the snapper, ... <i>ibid.</i> 124 The great apuko, the snapper, and the crayfish, are very numerous ...

 Date:  0/0/1843

 Author:  DiEFFENBACH
 Vol / Page:  2/222
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Polack mentions `cod-fish', bearing the native name of `Wapuka,' but we do not know the fish he alludes to. The `polach' he speaks of are, perhaps, the young of the <i>Percis colias </i>, the adult of which are known to the settlers as the `cole-fish'.

 Notes:  

 Date:  28/9/2002  
 Source:  Dominion Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  F15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Outside the home of every self-respecting irish peasant in days gone by would be a small patch of flax, grown to be spun and woven into linen for household use. We're not talking about harakeke (New Zealand flax), of course, but the totally unrelated European flax (Linum usitatissimum)... When Europeans arrived in New ZXealand, they called harakeke "flax" because its fibres are similar to those of Linum.

Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1907  
 Source:  NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  4(NS):101
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The country rock separating two veins approximately parallel with each other has, in certain instances, been found to grade laterally from the vein-wall, where it assumes a highly propylitic facies, to a median rib of dark and only slightly altered rock. These

ribs or dyke-like masses are the `hard bars' of the miners. in some cases, however, these `hard bars' are probably due to dykes. <i>ibid</i> 111 The `hard bars' of mining terminology are in most cases merely remnants of less-altered rock, but occasionally as in the case of the `bar' mentioned in the Golden Pah mine, they owe their existence to intrusives. 


 Notes:  (Fraser and Adams, Coromandel)

 Date:  0/0/1948  
 Source:  NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  42(NS):39
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Further, the `hard' bars most probably interrupted the shoot, more of less horizontally. 


 Notes:  (Gage, Reefton)

 Vol / Page:  3
 Edition:  
 Quote:  We have now passed through the hard bar, and re now in good reefing country.

 Vol / Page:  2
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A hard bar then came in and pinched the reef up, but at the date of his report he had got through it and into soft ground, and the reef seemed making again.

hard beech
 Homonym Number:

 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Nothofagus truncata , tawhai-raunui.

 Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  578
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The chief indigenous trees of commercial value are: Kauri (<i>Agathis Australis</i>), Kahikatea or white pine ... red and hard beech (<i>Nothofagus fusca</i> and <i>Nothofagus truncata</i>), silver beech (<i>Nothofagus Menziesii</i>), black beech (<i>Nothofagus Solandri</i>) ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1940  
 Source:  Plants of NZ
 Author:  LAiNG & BLACKWELL
 Vol / Page:  139
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>N. fusca (The Red Beech</i>)... North island: mountainous districts; South island: abundant. The <i>Red Birch</i>. A somewhat similar species is <i>N. truncata</i>, the Clinker Beech, often called the Hard-Beech.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/8/1957

 Date:  0/0/1978

 Vol / Page:  80
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>NOTHOFAGUS TRUNCATA</i>. Hard beech, the only <i>Nothofagus </i>native to north Auckland, is absent from the east and south of the South island. 	
 Notes:

 Vol / Page:  157

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1983  
 Source:  Land of the Mist
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  60
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Above 900 m hard beech is replaced by red beech which begins to dominate the canopy up to the summits of the ikawhenua Range. Also at these altitudes are Hall's totara and tawari.
 Notes:  

 Date:  25/4/1987  
 Source:  Personal Communication
 Author:  A.L. POOLE
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `Hard' probably because timber is hard and brittle, and of all the beeches is probably the most difficult to cut: probably a bushman's name
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks
 Author:  DAWSON
 Vol / Page:  121
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Five species of <i>Nothofagus</i> were formerly recognised in New Zealand, but more recently two of these have been combined as varieties of one species. ... <i>Nothofagus truncata</i>: hard beech (the wood has a high silica content making it hard).

hard case
 Homonym Number:

 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: a sexually adventurous or willing woman

 Domain: [none]

 Vol / Page:  12-6-1
 Edition:
