 Notes:  

hard case
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a witty person (NZ-US Dictionary); a good-natured reprobate or hoon; Likeable, amusing, conventional, often adventurous, but tough-minded morally tough person; a character; a good sport; a dag;  also hard doer, hard lot, hard nail, hard shot, hard thing.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1971  
 Source:  Bastards i Have Met
 Author:  CRUMP
 Vol / Page:  59
 Edition:  
 Quote:  One of the most remarkable attributes of the Hard-case Bastard is his memory for jokes, and when he's not actually engaged in some other kind of hard-casery he keeps up an almost continuous running patter of jokes from his seemingly inexhaustible fund of them.


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1897  
 Source:  Station Ballads
 Author:  WRiGHT
 Vol / Page:  24
 Edition:  
 Quote:  i thought of old tramps in the summer to stations far out at the back,/ When i met with the hardest of cases that live on the wallaby track -/Men like him, full of tricks and devices, ....

 Date:  0/0/1911  
 Source:  in Maoriland Bush
 Author:  KOEBEL
 Vol / Page:  282
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The termed `hard case', purly colonial is one, is one of the most widely inclusive and general serviceable appellations imaginable. it may be employed in so many senses, from that of contemptuous pity, of ordinary condemnation, even to that unwillingly extorted admiration.

hard country

 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Loughnan Glossary
 Author:  LOUGHNAN
 Vol / Page:  39
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hard country: country running up to a height above which there is, or appears to be, nothing that can be grazed and which appears to be only rock and running scree. Nevertheless some of the highest quality mutton and wool come off such country.

 Vol / Page:  C-9/38

 Quote:  The decomposed andesitic lavas generally

possess a characteristic yellowish-brown

or grey colour, and form the "kindly

country" of the local miners; while the

solid andesites and tuffs possess a

greenish or dark-blue or purple colour

and are generally known as "hard

country."

 Edition:  
 Quote:  hard doer incorrigible person, wag; eg `Cliff's a hard doer, take my word for it. He's written off 15 stock cars, never won a race, no prize money. Now he's mortgaged his house to get another.' NZA.

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Stewart island Plants
 Author:  WiLSON
 Vol / Page:  456
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Blechnum</i> HARD FERNS ... They are easily recognized also by their hard texture and simply divided fronds. in some species young fronds are striking red or pink. <i>Blechnum</i> is a predominantly southern hemisphere genus of some 200 species; Stewart island has 12, which is about three- quarters of the New Zealand total.  <i>ibid.</i> 460 <i>Blechnum</i> sp. `brown scale' Common hard fern ... Fronds more or less tufted but commonly covering extensive areas of open forest floor ... Frond scales uniformly brown.  (ii) <i>Paesia scaberula</i>  pig-fern, ring-fern, silver fern.

hard lines
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Common esp. in constr.  it is (was etc.) hard lines on (a person, thing), to connote `hard going'; `hardship, hard times',  be hard on = `fall heavily on' (hard = `difficult') rather  than OED Line `6. ill luck, bad fortune (Prob. nautical in orig; now often associated with 4c).' 4c. Appointed lot in life (in echoes of Ps. xvi 6). OED quots for 6 (1824) are similar to the NZ quots, given below cf COD lines 2.

hard shot
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: NZ since ca1930 (Slatter).] a) (informal) an unorthodox, amusing, or incorrigible character; a dag. b) a person hardened by experience; ?Transf. from shot `one who shoots; an expert in shooting', 

often qualified by aj (good, bad shot) (cf good, bad sport)  cf OED 22, esp 22b. (a queer shot) dial., an `odd customer'. good shot occas. used in NZ for `good sport', good boy: e.g. (a grandfather speaks) `Be a good shot now and get me my slippers';  =hard case.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

whisky in vogue.
 Notes:  [c1880s]

hard thing

 Sense Number:

 Date:  0/0/1935  
 Source:  Slang Today
 Author:  PARTRiDGE
 Vol / Page:  286
 Edition:  
 Quote:   [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... a hard thing, a man noted for his outspokenness, his hardihood, or his kindly if abrupt eccentricity, with which compare the more widely known  hard case;

 Vol / Page:  55
 Edition:  
 Quote:  hard thing resolute, outspoken or abrupt loner; eg `Polt's been up in that old whare for years, never spoken to a soul, except to buy his provisions, when he has to. Hard thing, that Polt.'

 Vol / Page:  No. 66/28

 Quote:  Less grand and altogether less fortunate are the short tussocks. Growing up to half a metre in height, they include such hardy species as blue tussock (<i>Poa colensoi</i>), silver tussock (<i>P. cita</i>) and hard, or fescue, tussock (<i>Festuca novaezelandiae</i>).... [29] Rub your hand down a leaf-blade of hard tussock, and you'll find it prickly and rough.

hash
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: usu. humorous or ironical for inferior food badly-prepared or badly-served, not necessarily chopped up chiefly in compounds in NZ : dry hash, hash-foundry, hash-house, hash-me-gandy; hash-up; hash is Std E. (cf OED sb1, and COD), and specific uses may be dialect : cf EDD. from Nhb `sheep's lights boiled then minced small  and stewed with onions'.; or NZ (Dry Hash) chopped or minced left-overs, heavily seasoned or spiced, and baked without liquid; food. 


 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

Hash House Harriers
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a running club
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See:

Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  4/6/2003  
 Source:  Capital Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  17
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Despite its name, Wellington Hash House Harriers has nothing to do with the drug. it bills itself as a drinking club with a running problem... Hash House Harriers was started in Malaysia in 1938 by a handful of Britons. "They decided to have a hare and hound-type chase on a Monday evening."...

The name Hash House came about because it was what these Britons called the boarding house where they lived.

 Date:  0/0/1941  
 Source:  NZ Slang
 Author:  BAKER
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1949  
 Source:  Dictionary of Slang Addenda
 Author:  PARTRiDGE
 Vol / Page:  1072
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hash-me-gandy. Station stew: New Zealand and Australian rural: since ca. 1920. B., 1942, suggests: ex Mahatma Gandhi's frugal meals.  An elaboration of hash


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1957  
 Source:  Canterbury Frozen Meat Company
 Author:  MACDONALD
 Vol / Page:  7
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in the early eighteen-nineties digesters were installed for `boiling down' the offals. ... This was essentially a stewing process which took four to six hours' cooking, and separated the fat by partial breakdown of the animal tissues. The residue, or `ashmegandy', was dried in a machine for fertiliser material, as was the blood. 


 Notes:

hatch tent
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1964  
 Source:  Watersiders
 Author:  DAViS
 Vol / Page:  97
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `Right, up we go and put the tent on. The rain's gathering a bit of weight.' 

A hatch tent consists of a large, light tarpaulin which is

lashed down round the hatch coaming while its centre is

held up by a wire strung fore-and-aft across the hold. it

provides effective temporary cover for an open hold, saving the time and labour required to replace the more cumbersome permanent hatch covers.
 Notes:

 Author:  MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  19
 Edition:  
 Quote:  They [sc. miners] dug and washed for gold in the creeks with the most primitive of outfits, amidst much toil and privation; and the solitaries came to be known as 'Hatters', the only explanation i ever got of the term being, that if they had nothing else to wash in, they washed in their hats!

 Source:  Shadows on the Snow

 Vol / Page:  76
 Edition:  
 Quote:  i was working as a `hatter'.
 Notes:  

 Date:  10/7/1868  
 Source:  Letters from Canterbury, NZ
 Author:  HARPER
 Vol / Page:  143
 Edition:  1914
 Quote:  Some of the men [are], in mining phraseology, `Hatters', that is men who live and work by  themselves content with the solitude of well kept huts, a few books [etc] ... .<i>ibid.</i> [144] hard work, their dog as companion, perhaps some poultry, and a weekly visit on Saturdays to the townships to sell their gold and see friends. Whence the term `hatter' i have never discovered; maybe because such solitaries are regarded as `mad as a hatter.' 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1948  
 Source:  Julius Von Haast
 Author:  VON HAAST
 Vol / Page:  529
 Edition:  
 Quote:  By one of these [West Coast] `beachers,' a countryman of mine, we were most hospitably entertained, the table being covered with several luxuries of the season which i did not expect in the abode of a `hatter' who are generally of a morose character, and do not indulge in any comforts of life.
 Notes:  1868 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 529

 Date:  0/0/1873  
 Source:  Wild Will Enderby
 Author:  PYKE
 Vol / Page:  3/vii/95
 Edition:  (1889,1974)
 Quote:  He was what is termed in mining phraseology, a `hatter', - meaning one who works by himself. ... Alone and unaided he scooped the wash-dirt into his cradle, which he vigorously rocked with his left hand, whilst with the right he ladled water from the river into the `hopper' or seive [sic]. ... He cast aside the `dipper', and hastened towards the eddy.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1874  
 Source:  Colonial Experiences
 Author:  BATHGATE
 Vol / Page:  138
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hatter: Whatever the origin of the phrase, `as mad as a hatter' can have been, i have often unsuccessfully endeavoured to discover. But doubtless it is from this phrase that the name of hatter has come to be applied in mining parlance, to one who works alone or without a mate. There are always a few of these unsocial miners about every digging, and their solitariness arises from every imaginable cause. Frequently they are misanthropes, sometimes placid contented creatures, who, so long as they can make a living by `fossicking' about, are happy. / [139]. My host was a hatter and he always kept a spare stretcher for any chance passer-by.  


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1876  
 Source:  Colonial Travel
 Author:  KENNEDY
 Vol / Page:  189
 Edition:  
 Quote:  These [holes] frequently form the grave of some unfortunate `hatter', as a man who works alone and has all his property `under his hat' is called [in Central Otago]. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1879  
 Source:  Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
 Author:  HAAST
 Vol / Page:  159
 Edition:  
 Quote:  By one of these `beachers,' a countryman of mine, we were most hospitably entertained, the table being covered with several luxuries of the season which i did not expect in the abode of a `hatter,' [[fn] in gold-mining communities those men who work for themselves are usually called hatters, amongst them many originals are found.] who are generally of a morose character, and do not indulge in any comforts of life.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1881  
 Source:  Waitaruna
 Author:  BATHGATE
 Vol / Page:  88
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `i wonder what can be the origin of [the term, hatter]?' `i don't know, i'm sure. Oh, i'll tell you. Those men who work alone are, i should think, more or less cranky, and you know the phrase `as mad as a hatter.' So i suppose they came to be styled `hatters'.

 Quote:  Miners who work alone are called `hatters', one explanation of the term being that they frequently go mad from the solitude of their claim away in the bush, exemplifying the proverb `as mad as a hatter.'

 Edition:  1962
 Quote:  HATTER: a solitary, a digger who works alone. The derivation of this New Zealand expression is obscure. Archdeacon Harper described the hatters as `men who live and work by themselves, often old sailors and much travelled men, content with the solitude of well-kept huts, a few books, hard work, their dog as companion, perhaps some poultry, and a weekly visit on Saturdays to the townships to sell their gold and see friends. Whence the term `hatter' i have never discovered; maybe because such solitaries are regarded as `mad as a hatter'. Another possibility is suggested by the remark that the hatter `kept his whole world under his hat'. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1968  
 Source:  NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  10
 Edition:  
 Quote:  hatter n.prospector who works alone.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1983  
 Source:  Gold Fossicker's Handbook
 Author:  NOLAN
 Vol / Page:  112
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hatter: miner who works alone. Probably derived from the habit of such men of leaving their hats at the surface to indicate that they were working down the mine shaft.

 Date:  0/0/1982

 Edition:  
 Quote:  At that time, only a few old bachelors and hatters were left living at Moonlight.

hatter
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: extended to other occupations, a solitary person
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  28/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  17
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hatter. One who works and camps by himself. Originally a miner's expression, no doubt from the saying of a man without relations that he had `all his family under his hat'. Archdeacon  Harper derived the word from `mad as a hatter' (Letters, p. 143). The word is in 

general use on stations. H.'s billy, tent, etc., one just large enough for one man. ([1898 Morris

Austral-English])
 Notes:  Acland Glossary

 Quote:  At the same date all the young stock ... went to still more exposed places by themselves, and spent the moulting-season, ... when, having acquired the new fur coat, they proceeded to sea.

The last of these `hauling-grounds,' as they are called, i have known in New Zealand was at Cape Foulwind, but formerly they were all round the coast.

 Date:  0/11/1978

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  46/4
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The implication for the Hautawan stage (pre-<i>Gephyrocapsa sinuosa</i>  according to Edwards 1976) are uncertain since we do not yet know enough about its planktic micro-fauna at the type locality, but the indication of a longer survival of the <i>Chlamys</i> in Wairarapa and the southern Dannevirke district suggest that the stage, if recognised by the presence of <i>C. delicatula</i>, is not a reliable correlation unit.

have
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: verb
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: have a beer in, have a fly, have a look-in, rat (in one's garret), have a set on, have a spite on, have for breakfast, have had it in a big way, have one's photograph 

taken, have on toast, have the goods on, have tickets on,  have whacked; see beer, fly, look-in, rat, set, spite, breakfast, had it, photograph, toast, goods, ticket, whacked.

have a cramp in one's kick
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: phrase
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: to be short of money (in the pocket)
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: kick
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1879  
 Source:  Spangles and Sawdust
 Author:  WHiTWORTH
 Vol / Page:  5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  i was down there with Old Ashmore's lot, doing the trampoline, and so on; but things was very quizby. Everything went crooked somehow, and the gorger had a hawful cramp in his kick. Well, ramp was the word, and vamose we did, the lot on us; some here, some there. i was reg'lar beached, and i tell you when a cove 'as to spout his smish it's about time to look out. However, i got a job at a livery stable, but although that kep' me in grub, and i slep' in a spare stall, the billet was very multy, and i kep' on the kivvy for something better. [fn] 1. [trampoline] Vaulter. 2. [quizby] Bad. 3. [crooked] Wrong. 4. [cramp in his kick] Emptiness in his pockets. 5. [ramp] Clear out. 6. [vamose] Go. 7. [beached] Hard up. 8. [smish] Shirt. 9. [multy] No good. 10. [kivvy] Look out (qui vive.)
 Notes:

 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]

Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
 Author:  McGiLL
 Vol / Page:  87
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>pop</i>, phr. <i>have a pop at</i> a fight; NZA. <i>- to go off pop</i> to start speaking angrily. <i>- not a fair pop</i> not a fair chance; eg `i'd like to have a pop at the little basket, but i apologise for going off pop at you. it's not a fair pop you having to be involved.' c. 1925.

have a rat

 Vol / Page:  251/1/6
 Edition:  
 Quote:  His Worship: `Was the accused sober?' Witness: `Well, he looked muzzy.' His Worship: `What  do you mean by that?' Witness: `He looked either drunk or a shingle short.' His Worship: `A what?' Witness: `A screw loose.' His Worship: `i don't understand you.' Witness: `He seemed to have a rat in his garret.' His Worship: `Oh, speak English!' Witness: `Off his dot - balmy [sic] - dilly.' Sergeant: `He says the man was mad, your Worship.' Witness: `No, i didn't. i said he was either drunk or ratty.'

 Quote:  The people are not at their back as the English masses were at the back of the Grey government, when it sought to pass the Reform Bill of 1832 The English middle classes then had all sections of the people, except the Lords, `by the wool'.

have for breakfast
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: phrase
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1937  
 Source:  Dictionary of Slang
 Author:  PARTRiDGE
 Vol / Page:  379
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Have for breakfast</i>. occ. <i>before breakfast</i> (as a rare appetiser). A humorous way of implying that a thing is easy to do, (gen.) a man easy to beat. E.g. `Why! i have one like him every day before breakfast' or `i could have <i>or</i> done with six like him for breakfast.' For task or feat, the <i>before breakfast,</i> often with <i>do</i> or <i>have</i>, is preferred. C. 20 coll.: mostly Australia and New Zealand.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
 Author:  McGiLL
 Vol / Page:  21
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>breakfast</i> in phr. <i>have for breakfast</i> find some person or thing easy to overcome or achieve; eg `Just let him try anything. i'll have him for breakfast.' NZA mostly.
 Notes:

have the wood on
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: phrase
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: to have the/an advantage over, to have the upper hand of: possibly f. tree-falling or axemen's contests, where one wins because one is a chip or thickness of wood ahead of an opponent who loses because he still has a piece of wood to sever before his trunk or block falls: but cf. ADD, and have the googs on 




 Origin: [none]

have tickets on
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: phrase
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: to be keen on (a person); espec. to set one's cap at a man or woman to have a special interest in, to be courting. -->(from a fig. use of ? to put one's personal label or ticket on (to claim possession of or to warn others off); or from ? having a raffle ticket on with hope of winning [but raffle tickets are usually in not on a raffle].

hawk
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Usu. Falco novaeseelandiae, occas. <i>Circus approximans</i>.  See falcon, harrier; also kahu, karearea. See also  fish-hawk (Caspian tern); sea-hawk (southern skua). 

[Spec. and strictly erroneous use of hawk--> a diurnal bird of prey of the sub fam. Accipitrinae to various similar NZ birds.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes:

 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  i saw two kinds of small Hawkes, both being small.

 Vol / Page:  6
 Edition:  {1888 2nd edn 1/220}
 Quote:  HiERACiDEA BRUNNEA \{HARPA FEROX\}. (BUSH-HAWK.) ... <i>Native names</i>. Karearea, Kaiaia, Kaeaea, Kakarapiti, Karewarewa, and Tawaka; but sometimes distinguished as Karewarewa-tara. `Sparrow-Hawk' of the colonists. <i>ibid.</i> 1/222  The continuous

screaming of the Bush-Hawk is understood by the natives to be a sure indication of change. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1874

 Vol / Page:  8
 Edition:

 Date:  0/0/1873  
 Source:  Birds of New Zealand
 Author:  BULLER
 Vol / Page:  xv
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Concerning the specific distinctiveness of the Sparrow-hawk and the Quail-Hawk, ... i got two of the former (<i>i.e.</i> the small species). ... Both birds were <i>full</i>-grown, and showed ... the impossibility of their over developing into a large and perfectly Quail-Hawk. 


 Notes:  1872 Mar 10 Haast in 1873 Buller Birds of NZ xv

 Date:  0/0/1882  
 Source:  Out in the Open
 Author:  POTTS
 Vol / Page:  37
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `in New Zealand the courageous family of the <i>Raptoresis</i> very feebly represented; the honourable post of head of the family in all fairness must be assigned to the falcon, which is commonly known by the name of the quail- or sparrow-hawk, not that it is identical with, or that it even bears much resemblance to, the bold robber of the woods of Great Britain - `the hardy sperhauke eke the quales foe,' as Chaucer has it.'
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1882  
 Source:  Brighter Britain
 Author:  HAY
 Vol / Page:  2/221
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Kaiaia (<i>Hieracidea Brunnea</i>) is a sparrow-hawk, smaller than the Kahu. ... By the same native name the `quail-hawk'  (<i>Hieracidea N.Z</i>.) is also known. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1882  
 Source:  Encyclopedia Britannica
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  XiV/54
 Edition:  
 Quote:  No Kestrel is found in New Zealand, but an approach to the form  is made by the very peculiar <i>Hieracidea (</i>or <i>Harpe)  novae-zelandiae</i> ... the `Sparrow-Hawk', `Quail-Hawk', and `Bush-Hawk' of the colonists.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1889  
 Source:  Catalogue NZ Exhibition
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  117
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Of the three species recognized, two, the quail-hawk (<i>Harpae Novae Zealandiae</i>) and the bush-hawk (<i>H. ferox</i>) [or sparrow-hawk], belong to a genus peculiar to New Zealand. [The third is the New Zealand harrier, <i>Circus Gouldi</i>, also found in Australia.]
 Notes:  Prof. Parker  [Morris]

 Author:  HiLGENDORF
 Vol / Page:  201
 Edition:  1967
 Quote:  HAWKSBEARD (<i>Crepis capillaris</i> or <i>C. virens</i>) is also called hawkweed, hawkbit, and hawkbite, as well as being confused with cat's ear and dandelion. it is common in gardens, pastures, and waste places throughout the islands.

 Quote:  The old time hay box was a good servant. A deepish box filled with good dry hay enveloped a cold lamb and its properties of heat and revival had to be experienced to be credited. i have sometimes at night given a stud lamb up for lost, left it in a hay box on the laundry floor and gone to bed, to be awakened in the small hours by the bleat of a lamb wanting milk.

 Vol / Page:  10
 Edition:  
 Quote:  increasing use of haylage - a hay silage which is sufficiently nutritious to allow cows to continue lactating - has changed the business in a big way. While hay has to be dried out, haylage can be baled a day or two after cutting.
 Notes:  

 Date:  25/8/2000  
 Source:  Dominion
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  Farming Suppl. 24
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [Hdg] Handy haylage. Empty hay sheds are becoming a familiar sight on lower North island farms as farmers discover the convenience of haylage... Haylage is plastic wrapped in convenient bales, keeping it preserved for longer... Haylage is simple to make. There is no pit to dig as there is for silage and the cut grass is only left lying for 24 hours.

haymaking
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: working a beach claim for gold
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1866  
 Source:  Letters from Canterbury, NZ
 Author:  HARPER
 Vol / Page:  100
 Edition:  1914
 Quote:  [goldfields] They give me a shovel and, with it nearly full of sand, direct me to shake it gently in the water till all the sand has gone, and then round its rim is a thin line of gold, fine as dust, enough to cover a threepenny bit. This is the easiest way of getting gold, so easy, it is called `Haymaking,' but it will not last long, as the black sand brought down by the river, with its gold,

from the mountains, and cast up on the beach, where it has lain for centuries, is of limited extent. [Also in -1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 10
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
 Author:  MAY
 Vol / Page:  222
 Edition:  
 Quote:  When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient.* ... [fn] This method of working the beaches was also called `haymaking' or `beachcombing'. These terms were not applied to beach-workings above high-water mark. 


 Notes:  1868 Haast in 1967 May West Coast Gold Rushes (1962) 222 



 Date:  0/0/1962

Hay's curse
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a species of Oxalis; a garden weed.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  7/6/1952  
 Source:  Personal Communication
 Author:  R. MASON
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hay's curse: A species of oxalis. i heard this in 1933 from T.L. Lancaster who was head of the Departtment of Botany Auckland University College. Hay's Nurseries were well known and old established nurseries in Auckland, still going then, but i believe since closed down. i am not certain of the particular species but the plants have pinkish flowers and produce large numbers of tubers and of corms, by which it spreads and which are almost impossible to get rid of! i understand that Hay introduced the plant into N.Z. it is the only time i have heard the name used, and imagine that it was then obsolescent.
 Notes:

 Quote:  Action terms related to the movements of the marbles are, Throughs and No Throughs, Tracks and Clears, Stops and Rolls, Lay-Up, Manyies, Kiss, Ons, Gees, Haystacks, Stays, Spiders

Can't Cross a River etc. Action Terms related to taking an opponent's marbles are Fires, Double-Hits and Forces.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMiTH
 Vol / Page:  175
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

 Date:  28/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  17
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ~ (1) People do not as a rule say (e.g.) `fifty cattle'  but `fifty h. of cattle'. Up country people usually confine this idiom to cattle and sometimes horses. But i see to-day in `The Press' (June 27, 1933)  the editor speaks of a decrease of so many h. of sheep disclosed by this year's sheep return. (C.) (2) A dog goes round to the far side of  a mob of sheep and stops them. This is called heading. Hence  heading dog, one whose work this is. if he does it neatly he  makes a good h See also sheep dog. 3. The owner would say, `i can  head with him'.(C; [1874 Kennaway Crusts],p. 45)
 Notes:  Acland Glossary

head
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a substantival use of head v. (of a dog, `head' sheep), in make a good head
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Wayleggo
 Author:  NEWTON
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Stopping dog: A heading dog which, once it has headed sheep, will just lie and hold the mob until its master arrives. The ordinary heading dog will endeavour to `pull' the sheep. in early days when high country sheep were much wilder and longer heads occasioned stopping dogs - real specialists at straight-out heading - were common.
 Notes:  [glossary]

 Date:  0/0/1953  
 Source:  Musterer on Molesworth
 Author:  STRONACH
 Vol / Page:  13
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Boy was certainly the fastest sheep dog i have ever seen. He put in a splendid hunt, which would have been a bad head if the sheep had not been so fast, and hunted them all on to the next man's beat. <i>ibid.</i> 44 Tim and his dog came along full of business, and Rover started up the bank in great style. He made a beautiful head and flopped on his belly about ten yards from the sheep ...

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1962  
 Source:  Waikaka Saga
 Author:  EVANS
 Vol / Page:  8
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `When other and more accurate means of measuring water are not conveniently available, it may be done by using gauge boxes of the dimensions ... `The gauge box shall be 12 feet long, 20 inches or 40 inches wide, inside measurements ... in accordance with the undermentioned table ... in other words, if the depth of the pressure above the board, above the top of the aperture, is five inches, the aperture is twenty inches wide, and two inches deep, the number of sluice heads discharged is one.'

head rope
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: verb
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  18/12/1856  
 Source:  Diary
 Author:  W.H.S. ROBERTS
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  At Macfarlane's the men saddled fresh horses and rode in some cattle which we had a great bother to yard, as everything was new ... The yard was divided into three - one large and two small - but as there was no crush pen, or drafting race, we had to head rope those requiring branding, and after hauling them up to a corner post, leg-roped and threw them on [44] their side, placing a long lever on their neck and under the lowest rail so that they would not move much ... When released the poor beast is not in an amiable temper ... So anyone in the yard has to climb the rails quickly ..., and the idea that it may catch you before your legs are safely over the cap rail certainly accelerates one's movements.
 Notes:  1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43

 Date:  0/0/1978  
 Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
 Author:  McARA
 Vol / Page:  324
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Head sample: A sample of the ore taken as it entered the plant in order to determine its average

value. A tail sample was taken as the tailings were

discharged, so that the percentage and quantity of the precious metals being recovered were always known.

 Date:  28/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  17
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Head shepherd: He takes charge of mustering, yards and all sheep work when the manager is not present, and very often when he is. He cannot as a rule sack a man, but can send him in to the boss, who very soon  will. Cf. h. ploughman, rabbiter, fencer, etc. (C.)

head-ditch
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a central or feeder ditch in a furrow irrigation system. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  20/8/1924  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  108
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in the furrow method of irrigation small furrows or corrugations are made in the direction of the slope and connected with a head-ditch supplying water .. Water is taken from the head-ditch, which follows approximately the contour of the surface, into the distributing-furrows, which may be parallel with the ditch or diverge from it. in turning the water from the head-ditch into the furrows the common practice in Central Otago is to make openings in the lower bank with a shovel.
 Notes:  

 Date:  20/8/1924  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture

 Quote:  One of the most frequent and heaviest operations in the preparation of land for irrigation is the formation of head-ditches.

headframe
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1978  
 Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
 Author:  McARA
 Vol / Page:  324
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Headframe: The poppet-head erected above a shaft was also called a headframe. it had to be very strong to withstand the shock and weight of two cages plus the weight of over 1000 ft of heavy wire-rope, with a wide margin of safety, and high enough to allow double-deck cages to be used if necessary and to have at least 10 ft clearance above the detaching hook to the detaching-ring. Most of the headframes were of steel but Nos 5 and 6 were of kauri timber. The back stays were placed midway in the angle between the winding-rope and the line of the shaft.

heading
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin:

 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]

 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  28/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  17
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ~ (1) People do not as a rule say (e.g.) `fifty cattle'  but `fifty h. of cattle'. Up country people usually confine this idiom to cattle and sometimes horses. But i see to-day in `The Press' (June 27, 1933)  the editor speaks of a decrease of so many h. of sheep disclosed by this year's sheep return. (C.) (2) A dog goes round to the far side of  a mob of sheep and stops them. This is called heading. Hence  heading dog, one whose work this is. if he does it neatly he makes a good h See also sheep dog. 3. The owner would say, `i can head with him'.(C; [1874 Kennaway Crusts],p. 45)  


 Notes:  Acland Glossary

heading
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: (sheepdog trials)
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
 Author:  McLiNTOCK
 Vol / Page:  1/493
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Heading. in the long head the competitor stands with his dog in a ring (1 chain in diameter) facing a hillside near the top of which three sheep are set loose.  When time is called the dog is dispatched, either on a left-hand or a right-hand cast, up the hill for some 800 yards to a point behind the sheep. On command the dog `lifts' the sheep and, keeping them together, `pulls' them in a direct line back to his master in the ring. To allow the dog to show complete control over the  sheep, the run ends with a `hold in the ring'. This involves stopping the sheep in the ring and 

holding them there. The first stages of the short head are much the same, but over half the distance, 400 yards. At the point where the sheep reach the shepherd, man and dog must drive them ahead down a `drive' which is 60 yards long and 1 chain wide and defined by short poles, to a set of hurdles which are 9 ft apart and parallel with the line of the drive. The sheep are driven between the hurdles and then down a second drive, similar to the first, to the pen or yard, which is 6 ft square. After opening one side, the competitor must stand by the pen gate until the sheep are yarded. The dog must do virtually all the work and his master's right of movement and intervention are strictly limited.
 Notes:

 Homonym Number:  2

 Author:  BAUCKE
 Vol / Page:  75
 Edition:  
 Quote:  An old-time bay whaling station consisted ... of at least two boats, with their crew of six men each. The headsman, or mate, four ordinary oarsmen, and the harpooner, or `boat-steerer,' who pulled the bow-oar, and drove in the harpoon, and who, when the whale had been struck and `fastened on,' went aft and steered the boat, while the mate took his place, and by repeated  lance-thrusts killed it.
 Notes:

 Date:  3/12/2005  
 Source:  Otago Daily Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  45
 Edition:  
 Quote:  After the All Blacks had beaten Wales in the first match of their grand slam, i was startled to find a sports writer lambasting commentator Murray Mexted for applying the word "heady" to rugby, when "heady", in his view, only meant things like "intoxicating" etc.  News to me.  Phrases like "He plays a heady game" or He's a heady player" have been in New Zealand sporting vocabulary all my life, meaning "thinking, intelligent, or analytical".
 Notes:  Civis' column

health camp
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a camp for the improvement of children's physical or emotional health; a (usu. summer) camp orig. for undernourished or physically deprived, extended later also to emotionally troubled children [see also Davin Gloss].
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Politics
 Region: [none]

 Date:  0/0/1997  
 Source:  John Banks : A Biography
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  22
 Edition:  
 Quote:  With a background like this, Banks was a candidate for the health camps. Set up after World War One, they were originally intended for malnourished and tubercular children. After World  War Two they specialised in children who were nervous, solitary and emotionally troubled... We would never admit to the other kids that we were going to a health camp, because, supposedly, any kid who went to health camps was diseased.

health stamp
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: an annual postage stamp which includes a levy for support of health camps; a postage stamp, formerly issued annually, part of extra value of which went towards supporting health camps.

heath

 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1879  
 Source:  Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
 Author:  HAAST
 Vol / Page:  114
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fortunately there were many shrubs of <i>Dracophyllum longifolium. </i> growing in this locality, which even in their green state burn freely, and which enable the traveller in those regions, so much exposed to rain, to light a fire with comparative ease. This plant has needle-shaped leaves, generally of a brownsh tint,and small bell-shaped white flowers. it [115] is generally called a native heath by the Europeans. As some of the bushes grow to a height of ten feet with thick branches, it offers wood enough to keep up a cheerful fire.

hebe
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Hebe salicifolia and related spp.; see koromiko.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Environment
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1940  
 Source:  Plants of NZ
 Author:  LAiNG & BLACKWELL
 Vol / Page:  393
 Edition:  
 Quote:  (<i>Hebe</i> from the Greek, the cup-bearer of the gods). Maori name, <i>Koromiko</i>. The evergreen, shrubby habit, in addition to other botanical characters, as well as the distribution, separate the genus <i>Hebe</i> from <i>Veronica. </i>

 Date:  0/0/1951  
 Source:  Confessions
 Author:  HUNT
 Vol / Page:  136
 Edition:

 Author:  GASKELL
 Vol / Page:  191
 Edition:  
 Quote:  1978 editorial note 191: `hellashin'. Originally in the expression `hellashin hot' to match `perishing cold'. The more aceptable variations were `hangashin' and `heckashin'.

heckler's veto
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  29/11/1984  
 Source:  Evening Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  2
 Edition:  
 Quote:   [Hdg] Media react to `heckler's veto'/  Are the views and `messages' of these [special interest pressure groups] being given undue prominence too often? Are they tending to beat into the ground opposing views, equally or more valid but less well organised? Are they imposing, in fact, a form of censorship. ...  The term `heckler's veto' was coined by the incoming president of the Auckland Council for Civil Liberties in September. He was publicly voicing concern over the action of police in seizing anti-Black pamphlets from the pro-white Nationalist Workers' Party.

"Technicolour yawn" is used for an instance of vomiting, as is "liquid laugh', i believe.

hellashin
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adverb
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: an intensive,  cf hangashun  (not merely children's (as Part, quot B 1942 for Aust) often used as mild slang by adults).
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1950  
 Source:  All Part of the Game
 Author:  GASKELL
 Vol / Page:  158
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `He thinks he's hung his clothes up and they fall down ... it's hellashin funny.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1984  
 Source:  Some Other Country
 Author:  GASKELL
 Vol / Page:  96
 Edition:  
 Quote:  it's hellashin funny.  1978 editorial note 191: `hellashin'. Originally in the expression `hellashin hot' to match `perishing cold'. The more aceptable variations were `hangashin' and `heckashin'. 


 Notes:  1950 Gaskell in 1984 Some Other Country 96

 Date:  0/0/1983  
 Source:  Bone People, The
 Author:  HULME
 Vol / Page:  29
 Edition:  
 Quote:  i'll be hellashing popular if i sent it home drunk.

hemp
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Phormium tenax, an obs name, used by early writers then reintroduced as a commercial name ?for the manufactured product of flax;  flax, also native hemp, New Zealand hemp.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  11/10/1769  
 Source:  Journal
 Author:  W.B. MONKHOUSE
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The materials of this sort [of mat] thinks [sic] is of true hemp - it looked like it and had the proper smell. There grows spontaneous every where a kind of very broad pladed [sic] grass like flags of the nature of hemp of which might be made the very best Cordage Canvas etc. There are two sorts [sic] the one finer than the other, of which the natives make cloth, rope, lines, netts etc. 

[Footnote: the New Zealand flax or Phormium tenax]. 


 Notes:  1769 Oct 11 W.B. Monkhouse in 1955 Cook Journal 1/573

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  NZ Medicinal Plants
 Author:  BROOKER et al.
 Vol / Page:  25
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> Forst f. Common name: <i>Hen and chickens fern</i> Maori names: <i>Mauku, mouku </i>... `Mauku' has been identified as <i>Asplenium bulbiferum, Cordyline pumilio</i>, and <i>Hymenophyllum</i> spp. by Williams and as <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> by Best. `Mouku' has been identified as <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> by Williams and as <i>Marattia salicina</i> by Tregear. <i>Asplenium bulbiferum</i> is a common fern throughout New Zealand forests.

 Quote:  HENBiT (<i>Lamium amplexicaule</i>) ... is native to Europe and western Asia. it occurs in several regions of New Zealand but is less widespread than red dead-nettle.

hencackle
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition:

 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1934  
 Source:  Canterbury Mountaineer, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  iii/9
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in Switzerland the "impossible" has

graduated to the "easy day for a lady"

("hencackle" in our patois).




 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1935  
 Source:  Canterbury Mountaineer, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  iV/3
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Just as difficult peaks sometimes fall to

the common denomination of "hencackle" so

do inaccessible valleys suffer the

indignity of being traversed between

excursion trains.


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1935  
 Source:  Canterbury Mountaineer, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  iV/8
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in passing, i must relate that it was on

the winter slopes of the Blimit that the

famous word "hencackle" was coined by

Evan Wilson... it was also suggested that

[Mt] Oates was too far away and that it

was too big an effort under such bad

conditions to which Evan replied: "Oates

is a hencackle" and a Hen-cackle, Oates

has remained to this day.


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1935  
 Source:  Canterbury Mountaineer, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  iV33
 Edition:  
 Quote:  if hencackles are hencackles then the

outcrop we were on was yet easier, a

"chicken-cheep."

 Source:  Canterbury Mountaineer, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  9
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in Switzerland the `impossible' has graduated to the `easy day for a lady (`hencackle' in our patois) ... 85-6 [2 Apr.] This route is easy but long and ought not to be called a `hen-cackle'. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1939  
 Source:  Unclimbed NZ
 Author:  PASCOE
 Vol / Page:  33
 Edition:  
 Quote:  For the cost of perhaps four shillings a party may spend a week-end climbing to a 6000 or a 7000 feet top, whence they traverse and descend snowburnt and happy. All the lasting alpine partnerships on Canterbury have been formed in the easy expeditions. `Hencackles' we call

these expeditions.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1941  
 Source:  NZ Slang
 Author:  BAKER
 Vol / Page:  57
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hen-cackle ... is applied by mountaineers to a mountain that is easy to climb. Doubtless there is a wider application of the term since  a mere hen cackle, a trifle, seems to have been the origin of the application.

 Author:  THOMSON
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Pastor Wohlers, long a missionary working among the natives on Ruapuka in Fovaux Straits, states that mice were first brought to the island in the `Elizabeth Henrietta', which was wrecked there in 1824, and that even as late as 1873 they continued to be known as `henriettas'.
 Notes:  (R. Mason)

Henry
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1949  
 Source:  i Saw in My Dream
 Author:  SARGESON
 Vol / Page:  140
 Edition:  (1974 ed. Rhodes)
 Quote:  At the war there were Froggy soldiers that always carried round little boxes - just little wee things less than the size of a matchbox. And inside there was a model of Christ on the cross - just a tiny thing. And over the top there was a word you could hardly read but it looked like H-E-N-R-i.  Well, Mr Anderson said, i could never work it out why they were called Henrys - that's what us diggers called them, little Henrys. D'you know, i've always meant to ask somebody why they were called that name.  And it was on the tip of Dave's tongue to explain, but he thought no. Because he'd have to explain why the i's weren't J's, and --[note 271:] ... His explanation of `little Henry' would have been based on i.N.R.i., Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews, from Lat. iesus Nazarenus, Rex iudaeorum.

 Vol / Page:  26
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The herd-testing movement is worthy of special mention. Practically 20 per cent. of the dairy cows in the Dominion are tested for butter-fat production monthly during the milking season. 

<i>ibid.</i> 346 Although herd testing and milk recording societies existed in Germany, Denmark, England and other countries many years earlier, systematic herd testing appears to have been first developed in New Zealand about the year 1920, when a model Herd Testing Association was established by the New Zealand Department of Agriculture in the Wairarapa. 


 Notes:  

herd-testing
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: the testing of dairy herds for disease, or to estimate milk production, etc.

 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  22/1/1927  
 Source:  NZ Dairy Produce Exporter
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  35
 Edition:  
 Quote:  We have been rather keen on herd-testing in this district and most folks [get] the herd-tester to do their cows.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1920  
 Source:  Dairy Farming in NZ
 Author:  POWDRELL
 Vol / Page:  46
 Edition:  
 Quote:   Herd-testing. - it is strongly maintained that herd-testing - the periodical recording of the weight of each cow's produce together with a butter-fat test from which data the production of the cow for the period is calculated - is the surest way of distinguishing the drones ... 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1936  
 Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  28
 Edition:  
 Quote:  As the result of herd testing, greater attention to culling and breeding and improved farm management, the average butterfat yield per cow increased from 154.25 lbs. per annum in 1920-21 to 218.80 lbs. per annum in 1929-30. <i>ibid.</i> 345 The major function of Herd Testing is primarily to determine the milk and butterfat producing ability of individual cows, and from this information to secure accurate data for the elimination of low-producing cows and also to provide a more scientific basis for the breeding of dairy stock. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
 Author:  TURNER
 Vol / Page:  45
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A cow with `a good test', that is, milk rich in butterfat, may be more valuable than another cow that gives more milk. About 1910 the practice rose of smpling milk from all the cows in a herd individually and testing the milk for its fat content. This process is called herd-testing. ... it is still not decided whether the word is hyphenated or not. i find it without a hyphen in a publication of the Department of Agriculture in 1950,  with a hyphen in a textbook of dairying in 1955. Pronunciation is with one stress, on herd. <i>ibid.</i> 149 in New Zealand, everyone uses

the term herd-testing, not  milk-testing, because everyone thinks of the dairy industry from a producer's, not a consumer's, point of view.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1974  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  92
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Herd testing helps farmers to maintain the standard of their herds - it shows up the lower producers so that they can be culled from the herd.

hermit
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a high country sheep that grazes alone and always evades a muster, or one that lost its mother when young and becomes attached to a particular location.

herpolirion

herring
 Homonym Number:  1

 Sense Number: 3
 Definition: anchovy.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  10
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ANCHOVY  (a) Scientific name: <i>Engraulis australis</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Anchovy. (c) Other common names: the following names of related Clupeids and Engraulid fish are sometimes applied to anchovy - Herring, Sprat, Sardine, Pilchard, although the true Herring of European waters  (<i>Clupea harengus</i>), does not occur in New Zealand. (d) Principal localities where taken: Hauraki Gulf, Gisborne, Tasman Bay, Marlborough Sounds.

 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1872  
 Source:  Edible Fishes
 Author:  HECTOR
 Vol / Page:  114
 Edition:  
 Quote:  58. SEA MULLET. ... The Makawhiti or Aua of the Maoris  (<i>Agonostoma Forsteri</i>) ... is a common fish ... it is commonly called Herring, from its general resemblance in size and form to that fish, but is easily recognisable from the true Herring by having two fins on the back, ... The Picton Herring, a dried fish commonly known roughout the colony, is the Aua preserved by

smoking.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1886  
 Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
 Author:  SHERRiN
 Vol / Page:  65
 Edition:  
 Quote:  MAKAWHiTi (<i>Agonostoma Forsteri</i>). ... Called the sea-mullet in other places, but the makawhiti or aua by the Maoris. it is a common fish, Dr. Hector says, obtained at all seasons of the year by fishing from the wharves in the harbours. in Dunedin it is known as the mullet. ... The Picton herring, a dried fish, commonly known throughout the colony, is the aua, preserved by smoking.

 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  104
 Edition:  
 Quote:  PiLCHARD (MOHiMOHi) <i>Sardinops neopilchardus</i> (Steindacher) The Pilchard is known from the northern end of the South island as the Picton Herring, and off Picton large shoals of these fish have from time to time been recorded. it has no relation to the so-called New Zealand Herring or Yellow-eyed Mullet (<i>Agonostomus forsteri</i>).

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An identification Guide
 Author:  PAUL
 Vol / Page:  40
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Pilchard  Sardinops neopilchardus</i> ... Sometimes called the sardine. Also occurs around southern Australia. ... in the 1880s a fishery in the Marlborough Sounds produced salted and smoked `Picton Herring', and small fisheries have developed briefly elsewhere. ... Pilchard are caught for groper bait (`bloater'), and have been used also for tuna.

 Citations 
 Date:  0/6/1921  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  iV/115
 Edition:  
 Quote:  EMMELiCHTHYS NiTiDUS (Richardson). <i>Red bait-fish</i>. Rare, and only occasionally utilized as a food fish. Taken in seine among mackerel, and commonly known as `red herring'. Distribution: i have recorded specimens only from the northern coasts of the South island. 


 Notes:  Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Fisherman's Bible
 Author:  WiLSON
 Vol / Page:  35
 Edition:  
 Quote:  BAiTFiSH, RED <i>Emmelichthys nitidus</i>: A less common species in New Zealand waters this fish turns up unpredictably in vast schools that give the water a red appearance - and the fish its name. Grow up to about 16 inches and known also as picarel, pearl fish and red herring. Colours light pink to dark red.

 Quote:  [index to common names 283-293] herring, red 1446
 Notes:  

herring
 Homonym Number:  2
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: an anglicisation of a Maori rendering (hereni [hereni]) of Eng. `shilling,' with the -ing from Eng. shilling, the whole approximated  to the Eng. word herring also herren.

 Date:  0/6/1921  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  iV/120
 Edition:  
 Quote:  AGONOSTOMUS FORSTERi (Bloch and Schneider). <i>Common Mullet; Aua</i>. Common in the estuaries of all tidal rivers, often entering fresh water in the summer. Called `herring' at Golden Bay and on the west coast of the South island, but not identical with Picton herring. ... Distribution: New Zealand harbours and estuaries.

 Date:  0/0/1927  
 Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
 Author:  SPEiGHT
 Vol / Page:  198
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Mugiloidea. An intermediate stage in the forward movement of the pelvic fins is represented in the little sea-mullet (<i>Agonostoma forsteri</i>  (Plate i. fig. 2)), popularly known as `herring.' it is a shore and estuarine form and feeds on the small shrimps which come in with the tide.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Guide
 Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  220
 Edition:  
 Quote:  YELLOWEYE MULLET ...<i> Other names: Aldrichetta forsteri</i>; herring, common mullet, sprat; sea mullet, river mullet (Australia); aua (Maori). The name herring in widely used in New Zealand for the yelloweye mullet but the true herring is a very different kind of fish. There are two species of true herring in our waters.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  Marine Fishes
 Author:  MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  48
 Edition:  
 Quote:  YELLOWEYE MULLET [<i>Aldrichetta forsteri</i>] ... Other names are herring, common mullet, and sprat. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  39
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>MULLET, YELLOW-EYED</i>  (a) Scientific name: <i>Aldrichetta forsteri</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Sea Mullet; New Zealand Kipper (smoked); Rollmops (pickled). (c) Other common names: Herring (in error and best dropped); Common Mullet; Sprat (in error). (d) Principal localities where taken: Tauranga, Kaipara, Lake Ellesmere. ... The name `Herring' has been applied widely and for a long time to the New Zealand Yelloweyed Mullet which is not a Clupeid and therefore only very distantly related to the true Herring of European waters. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Way Up North
 Author:  THOMAS
 Vol / Page:  24
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Maoris knew to a nicety when to expect the Aua, or herring, or to be correct, the yellow eyed mullet ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Fisherman's Bible
 Author:  WiLSON
 Vol / Page:  120
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HERRiNG More often than not a Yelloweye Mullet, but the fish that is widely known as the `herring' in our coastal waters. Also known as `sprat', though this term also covers the young of several species including anchovy, yelloweye mullet and several other small fish. There are

only two, `true' herrings in our waters. <i>ibid.</i>164 The Yellow-Eye has a much narrower head than the Grey and is the ubiquitous, but misnamed `sprat' or `herring' of our wharves. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  23/7/1986  
 Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [species name] herring .. herringbone
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a design of milking shed in which the milker works centrally between two queues of cows.

herringbone cowshed
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a shed in which cows are milked in two rows standing at an angle to the milker who is in a pit at udder level.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  MAF Agricultural Glossary
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  39
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Herringbone cowshed. Cows are milked in two rows standing at an angle to the milker who is in a pit at udder level. Cup put on from the side. All the cows enter and leave together. 




 Notes:  

herringbone waltz
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: the movement required of a milker when removing cups from a cow on one side of a cowshed to place on a cow on the opposite side. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See:

hickey
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1949  
 Source:  Dictionary of Slang Addenda
 Author:  PARTRiDGE
 Vol / Page:  1075
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hickey (or Hike). [P8 omits hike] Often elaborated to do-hickey. A `thingummy': New Zealand: late C. 19-20. Perhaps ex a Maori word. B., 1941. [P8: Perhaps influenced by a Maori word, but the form  do-hickey has long been common in the mid-west US.]

All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor.

 Date:  0/0/1977  
 Source:  Journal of Tussock Grasslands inst.
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  36
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The high country is the area east of the Southern Alps consisting of properties at high altitude with extensive grazing which are subject to severe weather hazards such as snow loss.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/2001  
 Source:  Calling the Station Home
 Author:  DOMiNY
 Vol / Page:  142
 Edition:  
 Quote:  .. the Grasslands Division of the Department of Scientific and industrial Research (DSiR) defines the South island "high country" in "agricultural terminology" as a remote area of high-altitude pastoral Crown leasehold land occupied by large sheep stations, or runs .. The New Zealand Meat and Wool Board's Economic Service defines the South island high country similarly as "extensive run country" and calculates the carrying capacity in Canterbury, Otago and Marlborough as 0.9 stock units per hectare. Distinguished from the South island high country is South island hill country, characterized by a larger proportion of lowland soil, lower snow risk and less dependence on wool as a source of income ...
 Notes:

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1952  
 Source:  Land Uplifted High
 Author:  PASCOE
 Vol / Page:  162
 Edition:  1961
 Quote:  The speech of the men is a slow drawl, sometimes flavoured with Scotch burr ... [fn] High country slang on sheep runs has national characteristics such as referring to a man as a `joker',

and using the adjective 'crook' to describe bad weather or ill health, eg `i felt crook on the day the crook weather brought the river up'. Regional slang is also of interest, such as use of `dag' (literally wool fouled with sheep's dung) to mean a `hard case' or unusual character, with an implication of approval, even of admiration. `Rooster' is another variant of `joker'. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1960

 Notes:  -->1938 TrRSNZ  (Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour)

 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An identification Guide
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  344
 Edition:  (2nd edn)
 Quote:  SEAPERCH (POHUiAKAROA) JOCK STUART, HiGHLANDER, FiVEFiNGER,  SOLDiERFiSH or SCRODDiE <i>Helicolenus papillosus</i> (Bloch and Schneider) The seaperch is a fish well known to all fishermen both sports and commercial fishermen alike, who give it quite a number of vernacular names, a few of which are as follows: Jock Stuart, Highlander, Fivefinger and soldierfish. These names have a bearing on some distinguishing characteristic of the fish. For instance the first two names are supposed to be given on account of the colouring of the fish resembling, in some ways, the tartan of a Scot; ...

 Date:  0/0/1888  
 Source:  Birds of New Zealand
 Author:  BULLER
 Vol / Page:  1/14
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... to say nothing of Korimako and Pitoitoi ..., we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even than

the Huia. The <i>Zosterops</i> was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1877  
 Source:  TrNZi
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  9/485
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [Native or Common Name] Hiku, Frostfish ..  [Scientific Name] <i>Lepidopus caudatus </i>


 Notes:  (P. Thomson, Otago)

 Date:  0/0/1886  
 Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
 Author:  SHERRiN
 Vol / Page:  29
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FROST FiSH (<i>Lepidopus caudatus </i>). ... [30] The frost-fish, or hiku of the Maoris, is esteemed the most delicious fish in New Zealand. it is most commonly found cast up after cold frosty nights on sandy beaches that are exposed to the long roll of ocean swell, and is not in this country obtained by any kind of fishing. <i>ibid.</i> 300 <i>Lepidopus caudatus </i> Euphrasen Frost-fish, Hiku, or Para

hill country
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: high ground, esp. when used for sheep farming; steep to rolling country (usu. with only a small proportion accessible by wheeled tractor; and in NZ usu. land previously covered in bush), a mainly Ni use.Cf. [1984 Frame Angel at My Table 175 `That's the Mount.' [Maunganui] i had grown used to the North islanders' reference to hills as mountains.]  Compare high country.
 Origin: [none]

 Author:  TAYLOR
 Vol / Page:  7/115
 Edition:  
 Quote:  One of the women of the pa ... presented my natives with two hinau cakes tied up in leaves. in former days this was a kind of food which was very much admired and considered most excellent ... it is of a dark olive color and it is of this that the saying is used, that no one has a

right to awake his neighbour in the night except it be to feed him with hinau bread.

 Edition:

hisser
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/2006  
 Source:  internet - see Notes
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Many trampers today like the flexibility of planning their own routes, of not having the pace set by others. Some are put off by the "hisser" mentality, which is apparently still alive in some clubs. Hissers sprint from point to point, seeing nothing. At the hut they bore everyone senseless with their boasts about record times. 




 Notes:  http://masseynews.massey.ac.nz/magazine/stories/going_bush.html    Accessed 1 Mar 2006.

 Date:  0/9/1958  
 Source:  Tararua
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  29
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Visitors to Wellington comment on the brisk pace of the pedestrians, and Wellington trampers  have achieved a certain notoriety for the speed with which some of them travel in the hills. it is not surprising,  therefore, that its hillmen and hillwomen should hiss along, that hissers and little hissers should flourish, and that little hisser should sometimes be used as a term of approbation - `stew a  hisser', `a real hisser of a day'. The Tramper first gives to hiss in 1934, and hisser with reference to a stew appears on 1940, but to a person not until 1943, though it must have been so used long before.
 Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
 Author:  McGiLL
 Vol / Page:  56
 Edition:  
 Quote:  hisser term of approval, mostly among trampers, in such contexts as `a hisser of a day' or `a hisser of a stew'.

historic hut
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: any of a large number of older back-country huts built for mustering, tramping, etc.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/2009  
 Source:  internet - see Notes
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The back country of New Zealand contains a heritage of about 1400 huts that is unequalled anywhere in the world. 



These huts were built for the following reasons: 

wild animal control (~750) 

sheep mustering (~500) 

recreation (~150) 

a range of other purposes including prospecting, scientific studies and castaway sustenance. 

Others began life as schools and homes and later became huts. These huts have heritage value as the only physical remnant of these activities. ...

DOC is identifying a representative selection of key historic huts that can be managed long term to conserve this heritage and allow its appreciation. it is intended to have interpretation signs provided for each historic hut.
 Notes:  www.doc.govt.nz/conservation/historic/historic-heritage-topics/huts

 Origin:

 Domain: [none]

 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1927

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  13
 Edition:  1971
 Quote:  <i>Galaxias attenuatus </i>(Jennyns). MiNNOW; HiWi or iNANGA. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An identification Guide
 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  118
 Edition:  2nd
 Quote:  MiNNOW or WHiTEBAiT (iNANGA) <i>Austrocobitis attenuatus</i> (Jenyns) ... For a long time it has been known to the Maori and to Europeans that our New Zealand Whitebait is the young of a native freshwater fish commonly known as Minnow, or inanga or Hiwi to the Maori, and erroneously called a Trout. ... The early settlers called it Maori Trout, Native Trout, Rock Trout and Minnow. But it is not a Trout. Nor is it a Minnow, through it resembles the English freshwater Minnow. While the name Trout is not correct, it is and will always be known as such by farmers and naturalists. in the Bay of Plenty, Whitebait is known to the Maori as Porohoe. 


 Notes:

Hobart
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: we communicate/correspond with (post to) Hobart, (Melbourne), a euphemism for `Tatts tickets

sold here';  to post to, to be in touch with Hobart, to sell (then illegal) tickets in Tattersall's lottery; notices in tobacconists' etc. shop windows: `We post to Hobart' to sell tickets (illegally) in Tattersall's Tasmanian Lottery; see also Tatts, ticket. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1980  
 Source:  indirections
 Author:  BRASCH
 Vol / Page:  408
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A little news-agent's window on Plimmer Steps, ... bore the same message in its oracular pronouncement that  We Communicate Weekly with Hobart. 


 Notes:  [1940's]

 Date:  0/1/1951

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  25
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `We communicate with Hobart every week' [heading]
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/1/1952  
 Source:  Here & Now
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  31
 Edition:  
 Quote:  their realisation staked on the/ still intangible ticket from Hobart./ 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  TURNER
 Vol / Page:  175
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Golden Kiwi was established partly to prevent money being sent out of New Zealand for tickets in Tatt's, a Tasmanian lottery with a name abbreviated from Tattersall's and quite unconnected with the English cant word tatts `dice'. it was illegal to sell tickets in Tatt's in New Zealand but many barbers' shops displayed a notice, `We communicate with Hobart', which was

universally understood.... it was clear that in the context of a barber's shop window the notice meant `we sell tickets in Tatt's', but legally a man can announce that he writes to Tasmania. Newspapers might report the good fortune of winners but the illegal source of the winnings would not be specified. The money came from `an overseas consultation'. 


 Notes:

hobo
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: in NZ after WW1, often applied to a rough-and-ready fellow; and also used ?humorously)  ca1947; as a term of familiar address to a group of companions: `Your hoboes ready?' (? cf bo).  


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1933  
 Source:  Hull Down
 Author:  EADDY
 Vol / Page:  103
 Edition:  
 Quote:   ... there's a hobo up there who cant lay out a yard. <i>ibid.</i> 116 Wilhelm, the German hobo,

had been disrated to boy for bad steering.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1937  
 Source:  Dictionary of Slang
 Author:  PARTRiDGE
 Vol / Page:  394
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hobo, pl Hoboes. 3. in New Zealand and Australia, in post-G.W. days, it is often applied to a

rough-and-ready fellow. The etymology remains a puzzle: see esp. irwin, who quotes a tramp's C. 20 distinction: `Bums loafs and sits. Tramps loafs and walks. But a hobo moves and works, and he's clean.'
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1960  
 Source:  Memories of Maoriland
 Author:  SCRYMGEOUR
 Vol / Page:  185. 195
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [refce c1920s] Sitting opposite were several typical Fielding [sic] hobos, each perhaps but certainly not in the studbook [sic] ... One of the hobos gurgled, and said, `Want to make an impression on that pretty icicle, ...'.  Jim quietly replied `Thanks for your advice, but i do

not want any information from `hobos' nor even from `quadroons'.'  `Hell! call me a half-caste?' flushed the main offender, sitting opposite. ...  `Dad is very taken with you, and with the fact that you skittled those Maori hobos has tremendously advanced your stocks. ...'

hog
 Homonym Number:  3
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a gen. term usu. used to describe young pigs. May be used for castrates or barrows but not specific (American) (CCR notes: US not young: a domestic swine weighing more than 120lbs).
 Origin:

hog weed
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: wireweed
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
 Author:  HiLGENDORF
 Vol / Page:  61
 Edition:  1967
 Quote:  WiREWEED (<i>Polygonum aviculare</i>), also called road weed, mat weed, knot grass, [pig weed,]  and hog weed, is common in cultivated land all over the country. it is an annual, with stems up to 2ft. in length trailing over the ground. The stems have swollen nodes (`knot grass') and are very tough (`wireweed').
 Notes:  

 Date:  23/7/1970  
 Source:  Dominion
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15/1-3
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The news from Britain that hogweed or cow parsnip as it is more commonly called, has been added to the list ... The New Zealand Weed and Pest Control society in recent publication `Standard common Names For weeds in New Zealands' records the name cow parsnip without

giving the specific name. This plant could be H. sphondlylium a native of the British isle and at one time widely advocated as a suitable stock food because of its thick fleshy tap root. Hogweed in New Zealand is a popular descriptive name for four different weeds. Two of these, namely the twin cress and wart cress, belong to the same genus. The other two are the wild portulaca and wire weed, which are in no way related. The popular names of the latter illustrate how confusing

the use of names like fire weed or wandering willie can be as a means of identifying weeds and plants. These common names of plants frequently have only local significance and in cases may even become obsolete. For this reason botanical names are ...

 Notes:  

hogget
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: in NZ used widely on and off (esp. for the meat) the farm (cf hog n1.) (note that animal and meat definitions differ); a) a young sheep between weaning (4 months) and first shearing(14-16 months). b) meat from a yearling sheep between 14 and 24 months.
 Origin:

 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]

 Quote:  ~ 8 temporary teeth - centre pair of permanent teeth start to erupt about 12 months... Hogget: Young sheep between weaning (4 months old) and 14-16 months of age. The hogget stage usually ends when the animals are shorn (around 14 months old). There are ram hoggets, ewe hoggets and wether hoggets.

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
 Author:  BURTON
 Vol / Page:  104
 Edition:  
 Quote:  New Zealanders are alone in distinguishing hogget from lamb or mutton. Lamb is the meat of any animal from six weeks until it grows its first two teeth, from which time it becomes hogget. When a full set of teeth is grown, the meat from the sheep becomes mutton. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  13/11/2003  
 Source:  Dominion Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  C6
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Each year, he buys in 1000 replacement ewes as hoggets amd two-tooths, going out of his way to source the best genetics.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1987  
 Source:  Boards, Blades & Barebellies
 Author:  OGONOWSKA-COATES
 Vol / Page:  94
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Ages of sheep. Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A 

sheep is a lamb until weaned. After weaning a lamb  is called a hogget until shorn. A male lamb is a  ram lamb until castrated, then a wether. A female  lamb is a ewe lamb. After shearing, a ewe or ram  lamb is usually called a shorn hogget until  cutting the first two teeth. it is then called a two-tooth. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a  four-tooth, then a six-tooth and then an  eight-tooth or full-mouthed sheep. it is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/11/2001

 Quote:  i got two bob a week pocket money and for that, i had to feed the chooks, collect firewood, dag the hoggets, dynamite the swamp and drench the bulls.
 Notes:  Daryl Crimp

hogget
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a hogget carcass comes from a sheep between 12 and 24 months of age, i.e. from yearling sheep. -->2. (butchers') Of meat from hogget; but often as a general (or euphemistic) term for mutton (on hotel menus, etc) (R. Mason).

hogsback/hogback
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 1. a long, sharply crested ridge. 2. a similar shape, especially a cloud heralding a northwest storm in the Si mountains.
 Origin: [none]
