 Source:  Peaks, Packs & Mountain Tracks
 Author:  GiLKiNSON
 Vol / Page:  25
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... he showed me a hogsback and told me what it meant. [fn] Term applied to a particularly unwelcome cloud only too well-known to climbers, and almost invariably heralding a north-west storm. An unpleasant sight - but a valuable weather sign.  


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1945  
 Source:  Camping and Bushcraft in NZ
 Author:  HARPER
 Vol / Page:  39
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The most infallible warnings of a nor' wester are the very high clouds of a peculiar torpedo shape, with a hard, rounded upperside like a whale's back - `hog backs' is the usual name among alpine men.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/9/1958  
 Source:  Tararua
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  27
 Edition:  
 Quote:  it is scarcely neccessary to mention the well-known hogsbacks, those torpedo-shaped clouds which form on the east side of the Southern Alps during a nor'wester and presage bad weather in the ranges, so [28] named by the late A.P. Harper. ... <i>ibid.</i> 40 From our camp on the grassy meadows some battled their way up to the snowline, retreating pellmell when they came face to face with a herd of hogsbacks; ...

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  iV/123
 Edition:  
 Quote:  GENYPTERUS BLACODES (Bloch and Schneider). <i>Ling; Hokarari.</i> A deep-water fish, to be secured during all months of the year. Common around Stewart island and the South island generally. Distribution: Taken as far north as the Bay of Plenty and Hauraki Gulf where it is considered rare. 


 Notes:  Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An identification Guide

 Edition:  2nd
 Quote:  LiNG (HOKARARi) <i>Genypterus blacodes</i>(Bloch and Schneider)
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1957  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
 Author:  PARROTT
 Vol / Page:  159
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Ling was known to the Maoris as Hokarari. Some years ago ago large catches were made in Cloudy Bay, and were placed on the Wellington market as `Cloudy Bay Cod'. The scientific name <i>Genypterus blacodes</i>, freely translated, means `a flabby fish, with a fin on the chin.' The New Zealand Ling is also found in Australia where it is known as the `Rockling.'

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  B4
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A chance glimpse of The Concise Oxford Dictionary has you wondering. it says: "ice-cream formerly sold esp. by italian street vendors." The Concise's bigger sibling, The New Shorter Oxford Dictionary, is even worse: "A kind of cheap ice-cream sold by street vendors." These English lexicographers would find nothing cheap or italian about the best ice-cream, in the world sold at any Kiwi dairy.

 Quote:  Baloo baloo balight,/ All on a Saturday night,/ Put your right hand in,/ Put your right hand out,/ Shake it a little a little/ And turn right about./  This curious song had a revival in another form as the boisterous dance-hall craze of World War ii, the hoki toki, or as many South islanders called it, the hokey pokey.

hokioi
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: hakuwai
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  11/9/1912  
 Source:  Otago Witness
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  76
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Many legends are associated with the

mythical bird "hokioi"... in the South

and in some parts of the North island it

is identical, apparently, with the

"hakuwai" which has seven joints in its

wing, lives in the sky, and presages

trouble... "its cry was Hokioi! Hokioi!

Hu!" The last word represented the

whizzing sound made by the bird in

flight.

 Date:  12/2/1864

 Vol / Page:  2

being derived from a semi fabulous bird

of evil omen had been started at

Ngauruawahia... "The Hokioi" would brook

no rival in its nest in the rearing of

its cantankerous brood.

 Edition:  
 Quote:  He stated further that a similar bird [to the Great  Frigate Bird, Fregata aquila] had been killed by the natives at ihuraua, ... and that all who had seen it pronounced this the true `Hokioi' of Maori tradition - a long-winged bird that is supposed to soar in the heavens, far above the range of human vision, and to descend to the shore at night to feed upon shell-fish.

 Notes:  1983 Hulme Bone People (Gloss) 467 [p] 262

Hokitika swindle
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: (also Hokitika ellipt.) a hotel bar game, orig. popularised on the West Coast (at Hokitika), but known throughout NZ.


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1941  
 Source:  NZ Slang
 Author:  BAKER
 Vol / Page:  57
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Hokitika Swindle is an hotel bar game played in order to create a jackpot from which payment of drinks may be made. it is based on a method of counting, whereby the person

who calls a certain number in sequence pays a specified sum into the jackpot [or shouts the round].  


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1949  
 Source:  Dictionary of Slang Addenda
 Author:  PARTRiDGE
 Vol / Page:  1077
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hokitika swindle. `Hotel bar game played to create a jackpot from which payment for drinks may be made,' B., 1941: New Zealand: C. 20. Of topical origin.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
 Author:  McGiLL
 Vol / Page:  57
 Edition:

Hokonui
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: a wild, fine-wool Merino-type breed of sheep that has roamed the Hokonui Hills in Southland. 


 Origin: toponym
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1987  
 Source:  People, Places & Paddocks
 Author:  GORDON
 Vol / Page:  103
 Edition:  
 Quote:  For Leon that's meant ducks, for Lynley, her hokonui flock, and all of them have a few Coopworths ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1987  
 Source:  People, Places & Paddocks
 Author:  GORDON
 Vol / Page:  101
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hokonui sheep are out of the same hills [as Hokonui whisky] and although not illegal, are certainly a curiosity. A fairly original form of Merino, they've run wild for well over a century and have developed, or reverted to, quite a few distinct characteristics. There's the varying shades of black, brown and grey with a wee dash of white on the forehead and a white tip on the tail...'They're just different,' he says. 'Things like positioning of bones and teeth, everything from the traditional farm animal breeding world, you can forget about when it comes to Hokonuis. They're as tough as old boots and interesting in their grazing habits. They prefer rough feed and will eat heads and thistles before they touch the clover.'..interested though he is, there's no way Peter will reduce the Coopworth flock in concession to the Hokonuis.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/2/2008  
 Source:  Growing Today
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  58
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The first record of the feral Hokonuis was in 1863, a flock of about 200 animals, so they have had 150 years to adapt. The Hokonuis' ancestors are believed to be smooth-skinned Saxony Merinos .. When and how Hokonuis came to be here is unlikely to be proven.
 Notes:

Hokonui
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: illicit home-distilled spirits, liquor; moonshine (orig. from the Hokonui Hills, Southland, famed for the illicit whisky distilled there (during local prohibition).

Hokonui Swindle
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: error for Hokitika swindle, a bar-game played with the numbers on bank-notes.  ca1974 Wellington: used in De Brett hotel bar
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  19/10/1983  
 Source:  NZ Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  3
 Edition:  
 Quote:  included in Hodges's  study is the truly macho battle of alcoholic consumption - the drinking game. ... There'll be some inane feat of manliness to perform, such as a lewd tongue-twister, or a physical show of strength, and he who loses has to down his glass in a gulp. in Otago alone, Hodges found 42 varieties of the theme, with names such as `One Fat Hen and a Couple of Ducks' or the `Hokonui Swindle'.
 Notes:  

 Date:  13/3/1988  
 Source:  Dominion Sunday Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  16
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Other well-known [drinking] games are Hokonui Swindle, Bottles, Fluffy Ducks, Bunnies are Hovering, Cardinal Huff, All Blacks, Matches, and The Amazing Grimaldi Brothers. All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical 

calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1989  
 Source:  Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The
 Author:  McGiLL
 Vol / Page:  45
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hokonui Swindle more recent name for and/or version of the Hokitika Swindle, a pub game aimed at financing further drinking. Baker identified the Hokitika version as based on a method of counting `whereby the person who calls a certain number in a sequence pays a specified sum into the jackpot'. Glenn Johnston defines the Hokonui version as a drinking game that combines

elements of chance with the ability to hold your liquor and follow a few simple rules - though the deviousness of the caller can also influence proceedings. The aims are simple: to liven things up, get a bit of alcohol consumed quickly and sort the stayers from the pikers.


 Notes:

Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1848  
 Source:  Handbook for New Zealand, The
 Author:  WAKEFiELD
 Vol / Page:  166
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Many kinds of dogs have been introduced by the Colonists; including  Bull-dogs, by the whalers, Kangaroo-dogs, (a mixture of greyhound and mastiff) from New South Wales, and various crosses between these and the natives' dogs, which go under the general name of  pig-dogs, and combine courage with speed, being used chiefly to hunt the wild hog, and taught to hold him, when caught, by ear or jowl, until the hunter comes up. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1875  
 Source:  Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
 Author:  MEREDiTH
 Vol / Page:  64
 Edition:  1935
 Quote:  ]  it sometimes takes up to half an hour to scramble through the rough gullies to where the dogs have the pig stuck up. if the bulldog were released before reaching the quarry, he would `go in' at once, and would probably be exhausted with holding the pig before we could get there, and possibly get killed. A bailed-up pig makes periodical rushes at the baiting dogs, ...

 Quote:  fn `To bottom a hole,' is a peculiar expression used on the mines in Australia; it means to convey the sinking of a shaft down to the bed-rock on which the auriferous drift generally rests.

 Date:  0/0/1887  
 Source:  Taken in
 Author:  HOPEFUL
 Vol / Page:  135
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [Colonial slang] if a man isn't `up to the mark' he is called `a regular shicer!' This phrase originated from the gold diggings. Supposing a man is digging, but without success, and he therefore abandons his hole, it is called a `shicer' - that is, the  ground was called a `shicer' or duffer, thus the origin.

 Quote:  `Treasure' i played ringie and holie. i played funs and keeps. i had pee-wees and bully taws and changers that weren't made of glass mind you. And i won nearly every game because the kids were so dazzled by the look of my stinkers. ... They came for miles to play marbles with me ... 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1953  
 Source:  Unorganized Games
 Author:  SUTTON-SMiTH
 Vol / Page:  2/719
 Edition:  
 Quote:  There is only one record of a New Zealand game in which a formal penalty element entered. This was a game of marbles called Dumps and was played at Wakefield in 1875. in this game the loser, in a marble game of Holey, was required to hold his marble partially exposed between the fingers of his closed fist [for others to shoot at]. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMiTH
 Vol / Page:  174
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (in more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. The last was more usually a girls' game. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1984  
 Source:  NZ Yesterdays
 Author:  KEiTH & MAiN
 Vol / Page:  288
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ] [Photo caption] Marbles became `in' or `out' capriciously but someome always knew the rules of the various games - `holey,' `liney' and, seen here, `ringey' - which could be played for `funs' or `keeps.'

holey dollar
 Homonym Number:

 Sense Number:

 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1941  
 Source:  Numismatic History of NZ
 Author:  SUTHERLAND
 Vol / Page:  66
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in New South Wales, in 1813, this difficulty [of shortage of coin] became so acute that Governor Macquarie, in an effort to check the outflow of Spanish dollars, then the main circulating medium, caused the centres of these coins to be struck out, the centre-piece (about the size of a shilling) being stamped NEW SOUTH WALES, 1813, around a central crown, and on the other side FiFTEEN PENCE, the remainder or `ring' part of the dollar being impressed around the new inner rim with NEW SOUTH WALES, 1813 on one side, and FiVE SHiLLiNGS on the other. ... [67] 3,008 Dollars (mainly Holey or Ring Dollars) [pounds] 752 0 0/ 725 Dumps (centres of Spanish Dollars) 45 6 3

 Vol / Page:  p 45
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The extremely rare coastal plant Holloway's Crystalwort (<i>Atriplex hollowayi</i>) has received a much needed helping hand from a keen band of Te Hapua school children. ... Holloway's Crystalwort is a small New Zealand annual plant which grows near the high tide level on sandy beaches over summer.

holly
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Olearia illicifolia; holly-leaved olearia, an evergreen shrub with red berries and sharp, pointed, shiny leaves used as a Christmas decoration [check Maori holly]; Andersen (7 entries) Native Holly 1890 MLN 1925 DDD2, Andersen (4 entries) N.Z. Holly 1908 MK, 1919 CNZ; see also native holly.

 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  History of Children's Play
 Author:  SUTTON-SMiTH
 Vol / Page:  230
 Edition:  
 Quote:  i remember two essentially Maori games, Cat's Cradle and Homai, but the others were all traditional English games i think, ... (1912-20; Ohau) <i>ibid.</i> 231 There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. West Coast: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; Wellington: Who Goes Round My Stone Wall, Beg o' My Neighbor, Bellahonie, Run a Mile, On and Off the Bridge, Here Come Two Nuns, Colours, isaac and Rebecca. Scrag, Diabolo, Bumble Puppy, Homai, Fives; Auckland: My Fair Young Lady, Rushes and Reeds, Surrender the Tower, Walls, Ball Hopscotch, ball games, Solomon Says; Hawkes Bay: Wolf Wolf Go Home, Homai; Canterbury: Poor Old Tom, Rats and Rabbits and Rips, Steps, Skin the Snake, Steal a Peg, Toodle-em-Buck, The Gag; Golden Bay: Who's That Walking Round My House Tonight, i've Come to See Poor Mary Jane, Steps and Stairs, Creeping, Branding, O'Leary;  Otago: Sir Roger de Coverley, Who's That Knocking at My Door.

Homaiacky
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a former children's game
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1953  
 Source:  Unorganized Games
 Author:  SUTTON-SMiTH
 Vol / Page:  2/513
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Of the Help-He games, Kick the Tin, is the most widely known. A tin is placed in the centre of a circle. One He is in charge of the tin. He can only tag the other players when his tin is in the centre of the circle. Any players he catches must stay in the circle. Any non-caught player can help and free the other caught players by running through the circle and kicking the tin out of it. Other names for this game are: Kick the Boot (Gisborne [18]90), Knock the Block or Homaiacky (Nelson [18]95), Kick the football or Piacky (Mangatainoka). 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMiTH
 Vol / Page:  80
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in a few tagging games the players joined hands with the He when they were caught and helped him catch the other players. These games were known as  The Bellahonie (E-21) (Wellington, 1910), Kick Post One (Hampden, Otago, 1880), and Ballyhooley (Wellington, 1920). More popular were those games in which the players helped one another to fight the He, and of these the most widespread was the game known as  Kick the Tin (e-3), Kick the Boot, Kick the Block, or Homiacky.  in this game the He was put on guard of a jam tin placed inside a small circle marked on the ground. [Other players hid: those He could see he named and tapped the tin three times and `captured': other hiders waited till they had chance to kick tin out of circle: then all were free again.]

home
 Homonym Number:  1

 Date:  5/8/1857  
 Source:  Lyttelton Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Mr. Fyfe had found a moa's egg, at the Kai Koras, while digging the foundation for his store. it is a foot long, about 6 inches in diameter, and 27 inches in circumference. The shell is the 16th part of an inch in thickness. A hole is drilled in the end of it, and the egg must have been considered of great value by the natives, as it was found deposited at the head of a skeleton, with a number of very large poenamu axes. Mr. Fyfe, we understand, is going to send them home to the British Museum.

 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:

 Date:  0/0/1935  
 Source:  Little Country, The
 Author:  BRODiE
 Vol / Page:  1
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... which they call the Old Country, the Old Land, the Old Dart, and, in common speech, Home. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1937  
 Source:  New Zealand From Within
 Author:  COWiE
 Vol / Page:  265
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The word Home on most New Zealanders' lips is no more than a synonym for the United Kingdom; it does not mean `dear old England', or `my beloved birthplace,' or `my real country'; it does not even mean what the United Kingdom means to all irish irishmen. it simply means the 

United Kingdom, and is used without emotion, as a word that has been handed down from father to son, and mother to daughter. it is part of the real New Zealand language, a genuine piece of Antipodean slang. And, like all slang, it has its significance.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1937  
 Source:  Dictionary of Slang
 Author:  PARTRiDGE
 Vol / Page:  399
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Home. Great Britain and ireland; esp., an gen., England: Colonial, prob. first in U.S. (by 1912 very ob., says Thornton) in C. 18. in C. 20, mostly Australian and New Zealand. Esp. as 

as at h., go h. A coll. usage bordering on-indeed, by the O.E.D. considered as-S.E. -4. (home.) A dug-out in the front trench: New Zealand soldiers': 1915-18.

But this country is our real home.'

 Date:  0/0/1979  
 Source:  Heinemann NZ Dictionary
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  518
 Edition:  
 Quote:  - 


 Notes:  

Home
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: G.B. and ireland; esp. and gen. England : Colonial, prob first in U.S. (cf Thornton) in 18c. : 20c Aust and NZ esp. go, at home.]  (it is perhaps possible to distinguish among the earliest recorded uses, a specific reference to England, rather than other parts of the British isles, or to the British isles themselves. This would be expected, as most early Company settlers were English born. My evidence suggests that 1840-1860 usage was mainly by settlers in Canterbury, Nelson, and Wellington. There seems no early evidence of its use in Otago.) By the first settlers, and the early generations of colonially born, England; the British isles; the Old Country; the mother country; one's home country. A. Referring to the homeland left. 1. a. Chiefly `England'. (i) initial cap. [?more freq. proportionally after WW1]. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations

 Quote:  When i presumed to take on the cloak you [Buck] dropped ... and in the borrowed mantle essayed to climb Hikurangi and so catch ... views of the local conflict i was amazed that so much progress had been made in winning the regard ... of the `pakeha'. The generation for which the New Zealand Herald catered in leading articles had almost passed away. Your lectures throughout New Zealand had set the best minds among the pakeha at work. With that generation also had largely passed the pakeha who was wedded to the idea of England being `Home'. The native born New Zealand pakeha is looking nearer to his native heath for objects of study, literary effort and missionary care.

 Quote:   `i hope to go Home some day' You mean England, i suppose. `Yes, of course,' replied Philip. He really meant the British isles with England predominant. ... i don't think of England as Home. ... if there's any `Home' for me in that sense, it's ireland. But this country is our real home. ... in thinking of England as `Home', Philip was typical of his countrymen. Nearly everyone spoke of `Home' - as naturally as, unknowingly, they sprinkled their speech with current phrases from Shakespeare.

Home Guard
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Home Defence Force, WWii
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/10/2003  
 Source:  NZ Memories
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  No. 44/28
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Home Guard has atrtracted little attention from historians... There was nothing glamorous about the Home Guard... it was nearly a year after war was declared that the War Cabinet finally laid plans for the formation of a volunteer Home Guard, to comprise men who were too old or to young to serve overseas, or who were being kept at home in essential occupations... The urgency and seriousness of the war eventually forced Home Guard units to be set up in almost every settlement and town in the country... The Home Guard in New Zealand eventually numbered 12,000 in its ranks.
 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1999

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  575 : 17550

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1999  
 Source:  NZ Statutes
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  262
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The definition of home invasion.. is intended	to cover all situations where an offender commits an offence in the process of entering, while inside, and while leaving, places where people live. in the bill as introduced, a home invasion must occur in a "dwellinghouse"... The definition of "dwellinghouse" is.. .intended to encompass the variety of places in which people can live, including caravans, mobile homes and other structures. it focuses on the use to which a building is put, and is therefore not intended to include buildings or parts of buildings that have some other primary purpose, such as a commercial buildings or hospitals... 17A.. 'Dwellinghouse' means (a) a building or other structure, or part of a building or other structure, that is used by the occupant principally as a residence; or (b) A mobile home, caravan, or houseboat, that is used by the occupant principally as a residence; "Home invasion", when used in the expression 'the offence involved home invasion'.. means that the person who committed the offence did so... (a) While breaking and entering, or otherwise unlawfully entering, an occupied dwellinghouse; or (b) While in an occupied dwellinghouse, after having broken and entered, or otherwise unlawfully entered, the dwellinghouse; or (c) While breaking out of an occupied dwellinghouse; or (d) While otherwise unlawfully in an occupied dwellinghouse




 Notes:  Report from the Justice & Law Committee

 Date:  14/8/1999  
 Source:  Dominion
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  25
 Edition:

home separation
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: the skimming or separating of cream from milk at the farm where the milk has been produced 

(rather than being sent as whole milk to a skimming station or dairy factory). 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]

 Date:  15/6/1910

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  34
 Edition:  
 Quote:  By 'home separation' is meant the skimming of milk by small cream-separators on the farm and supplying the cream to butter-factories .. the butter generally made at 'home separation' factories is of a distinctly lower grade than the butter made from the cream at factories and skimming-stations where the whole milk is delivered.

 Date:  0/0/1937

Home-separation developed in the first instance on farms remote from a factory or skimming-station ...

 Date:  0/0/1888

 Vol / Page:  22
 Edition:

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
 Author:  BEATTiE
 Vol / Page:  11
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. in this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.'
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
 Author:  BEATTiE
 Vol / Page:  115
 Edition:  
 Quote:  it is usually understood that in the early days the word `station' denoted the owner's house and its immediate buildings, while `run' meant the whole property. Strange to say, i only noted the word `station' twice, and each time with a diverse meaning. On July 21, 1865, the diary says: `Sold 17 head of cattle - remaining on station 15 head.' Then on September 11, 1865, we read: `Wilkinson returned to the Home Station.' The first of these entries means the whole run - the second the homestead or main buildings.
 Notes:  -->1947 Beattie Early Runholding 115 quoting 1856 July 21 Puketoi Station Diary

 Date:  0/0/1971  
 Source:  Wakatip
 Author:  GRiFFiTHS KiNG
 Vol / Page:  73
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Rees family barely had time to get settled again at their home station before the quiet pastoral barony ... was invaded by a noisy and often drunken avalanche of gold-seekers.

 Notes:  Roger `Auckland Life

 Date:  0/0/1987  
 Source:  Te Reo
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  30/132
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Review NZPOD Town house is in, and uneasily acceptable as a `residence in town esp. of person with house in the country' although `in the country' could be better phrased; but `house in (esp. terraced) group in town' is not apt, and increasingly the style for this type of dwelling is townhouse. That is, `My town house is a townhouse', correctly distinguishes, on the page, and will be distinguished in speech; tow stresses for the one, and one stress (TOWNhouse) for the other. There is as well a question of nuance to be noticed. A 

townhouse is emphatically upmarket from a home unit. 


 Notes:  Smithyman

home-aid
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: A girl or woman, usually part-time or temporary, domestic servant; a person employed, often by a public organisation, to help with housework, etc; home-aid has often denoted spec. the official domestic servants, employed by the Home-aid Service of Labour Department, hired temporarily by families when a parent is ill, having children, or in other difficulties. (There have been similar services run by, eg. the Women's Division of the Federated Farmers, and by the Churches.)

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
 Author:  BEATTiE
 Vol / Page:  11
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. in this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.'
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1853  
 Source:  Auckland
 Author:  SWAiNSON
 Vol / Page:  38

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  27 Vict. 39/157
 Edition:  
 Quote:  No portion of the land occupied by a

holder of a pasturage license whereon a

homestead shall have been erected or

improvements made shall be offered for

sale until the offer of purchasing such

land shall have been made to such

license-holder at a price per acre

assessed within the limits of the upset

price of the class of land to which the

land in particular may belong. [Marginal

note: Homestead to be offered to license

holder previously to sale].

permit the original holder of a pastoral

license.. to apply for and purchase in

one block.. an allotment of land not

such other improvements as may be

 Vol / Page:  49 Vict. 56/294

a homestead on the land included in his

lease or license, he shall have the

right, with the consent of the Board, to

select and occupy, during the currency of

his lease or license, an area of not

exceeding in the whole one hundred and

fifty acres adjacent to such homestead,

which shall be exempt from the right of

determination as provided in section one

hundred and seventy.

 Notes:  

 Date:  28/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  17
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Homestead. in the old days the owner's residence, but only if it was some distance from the rest of the station buildings (see big house). when the Goverment began cutting up the runs in the 'nineties, they or their surveyors adopted the word to signify what had been formerly called the station, and the new settlers followed them, so that the new sense of the word is now widely used. Butler and Sir F. Weld also use it in the modern sense, but in writing for Englishmen. (C.R.)
 Notes:  Acland Glossary

 Notes:  

Homestead Act
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: an early Land Grant law where permanent dwellings had to be erected within twelve months of land occupancy. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1977  
 Source:  To the Northward
 Author:  KEENE
 Vol / Page:  128
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in the 1870s the Homestead Act provided for free grants of 50 acres of first-class land or 75 acres of second-class land, plus certain acreage to children, conditioned on the cost of surveys being paid and on specified improvements being done within a certain number of years.

 Vol / Page:  284
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HOMESTEAD SYSTEM. [heading] Under this system the settler makes no payment for the land, the only cost to him being the expenses of survey. On the fulfilment of conditions, which are five years' residence, the erection of a house, and the cultivation of one-third of the selection if open land, and one-fifth if bush-land, the Crown grant is issued.

homeward bounder
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1962  
 Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
 Author:  MAY
 Vol / Page:  244
 Edition:  1967
 Quote:  it was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of the `pilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access.  <i>ibid.</i> 275 The richest claim was always a `homeward-bounder'. A Nelson digger recalled how at work his mates talked of `trips to Europe, going back for a week, and astonishing the Natives generally'. <i>ibid.</i> 329 J. F. Byrne & Co. showed off their wares by the light of six kerosene chandeliers and advertised, THE REAL HOMEWARD BOUNDER!/An ounce to the Dish can be Saved/ BY BUYiNG YOUR/CLOTHiNG AND BOOTS AT THE CORiNTHiAN HALL/ NEW RUSH NEW RUSH /Peg out your claims at the Corinthian Hall if you want to strike a good lead/Dead on the gutter/ BUY YOUR CLOTHiNG AND BOOTS AN THE CORiNTHiAN HALL/

Homey/Homie
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: an English person or Briton; a person from home; a person (poss. became obsolesc. as Pommy became more popular) with a non-NZ, British accent.

 Edition:  
 Quote:  They [English immigrants] loathed the New Zealanders, who called them Homies. <i>ibid.</i> 155 We don't call them green-horns out here. We call them new chums, or else Homies.  <i>ibid.</i> 164 `if you're in any way different, in this country, ... you're made to feel such a fool. ... They call us Homies.' `A lot of people called the New Zealanders Pig islanders, and the Australians the Aussies.  <i>ibid.</i.>165 ... don't mind if you're called a Homie. After all, what does it mean? Somebody from Home. A bit sissy, but it could be worse.

honeysuckle
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Native and introduced spp.; 1. any of various climbing shrubs with small, fragrant, trumpet-shaped, yellow or pink flowers; 2. a) any of various similar but unrelated plants, such as

banksia; b) in New Zealand;  rewarewa. 1. Knightia excelsa  (Morris: applied in Austr. to Banksias, the `Bottle-brushes' to which the NZ plant is related.) rewa-rewa, bucket-of-water-tree
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]

 Date:  0/0/1945  
 Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  54/97
 Edition:  
 Quote:  As each arrives, she goes through the bus, shaking hands and hongi-ing everyone. There is a set patttern for the hongi - clasp hands, briefly press together the tips of the noses, make a wailing sound, press noses briefly for a second time ... Close relatives hongi for a longer period than the formal brief nose-press. 


 Notes:  (Beaglehole)

 Date:  0/0/1945  
 Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  54/97
 Edition:  
 Quote:  As each arrives, she goes through the bus, shaking hands and hongi-ing everyone. There is a set patttern for the hongi - clasp hands, briefly press together the tips of the noses,  make a wailing sound, press noses briefly for a second time ... Close relatives hongi for a longer period than the formal brief nose-press.
 Notes:  (Beaglehole)

 Notes:  

Hongi
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a Maori. Usu. in pl. (the Hongis); prob. from Hongi Hika, name of an early Maori chief well known from school history books; poss. chiefly a Si term, as unlike Hori, it is not used by Maoris among themselves. 


 Origin: Maori
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes:

 Quote:  One of the most initially shocking [fees] is the honour fee introduced by ANZ in June. The way it works, on certain accounts, is that for every day the account is improperly overdrawn - i.e. if you haven't previously arranged an overdraft facility - the first two transactions that day each attract a $15 penalty. ... "Fundamentally, " Shaw points out, "there's no reason for a customer to incur an honour fee. An overdraft facility costs you less a year [$28] than two honour fees."

 Notes:  

hoodat
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: exclamation
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: who say hoodat, a catchphrase popular among students etc. in 1950's and early 60's, said especially as a welcome to a newcomer to a group, or outsider. Often a meaningless saying. (from who dat say who dat?, from the coloured joke about Rastus / Hori / Jacky etc, who comes home suddenly when a friend is in bed with his wife. The adulterer gets out of his bed, and tries to creep out under cover of darkness. Rastus hears him,in the dark, and says `Hoo dat?' being answered by silence, until the adulterer bumps into him in the dark, and says himself `Hoo dat?' Rastus immediately says `Hoo dat who say hoo dat'. The story has many variants, and is variously placed in stage Black, Maori or Aboriginal contexts.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes:

hoof cultivation
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: the use of grazing stock to aerate soil or to cultivate pasture. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  1/9/1937  
 Source:  NZ Farmer
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  11
 Edition:  
 Quote:  i mentioned previously the hoof cultivation by sheep.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1928  
 Source:  Tour in Australia and NZ
 Author:  STAPLEDON
 Vol / Page:  55
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A Tour in Australia and New Zealand 55 Concentration of grazing carries with it other important effects - the benefits of what Bruce Levy has so appropriately termed 'hoof cultivation.' in New Zealand the soil dries so rapidly after rain that the 'hoof' seldom does harm and most frequently only does good - provided of course that a period of rest follows a period of excessive 'cultivation.' The combined application of 'hoof cultivation' and judicious feeding out is a method definitely employed for grass land improvement in New Zealand.

 Edition:  
 Quote:  The fern is fired; if it burns well, all the thick and matted dead stuff at the bottom.. will be consumed, leaving only the shrivelled 'Tutu'; and the cane-like fern stalks.. should be cut at once with a strong hook, or better still, with a short scythe, and the 'Tutu' slashed down with a bill-hook.

hook
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a gumfields tool
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1900  
 Source:  NZ illustrated Magazine
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  3/208
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The tools used by the digger are the spade, the spear and the hook. ... The hook is used for raising the gum from the deeper and wetter swamps. it is a rod of iron perhaps twelve feet long,

looped at one end for a handle, and with the last three feet of the other turned off at right angles  and given its own peculiar shape. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Gumdiggers, The
 Author:  REED
 Vol / Page:  50
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The hook was used for drawing up nuggets of gum from the depths of swamps, after location by the spear. The hook consisted of a galvanised pipe an inch or so in diameter, equipped at one end with a spade handle, and at the other end with a steel `toe,' about an inch and a half in length, welded to the pipe, and forming the `hook'. it is said that expert diggers could bring up with ease gum of various sizes from great depths.

 Source:  Stories
 Author:  MANSFiELD
 Vol / Page:  193
 Edition:  (1984 Alpers)
 Quote:  `Come for a walk round the esplanade, Matilda. i can't stand this any longer.'  `Right-o. i'll put on my ulster. isn't it an awful day!' Bogey's ulster is just like hers. Hooking the collar she looks at herself in the glass. ... Good-bye, dears; we shall be back soon. `This is better, isn't it?'  [194] `Hook on,' says Bogey.  They cannot walk fast enough. Their heads bent, their legs just touching, they stride like one eager person through the town, ...

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1980  
 Source:  Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
 Author:  LELAND
 Vol / Page:  52
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A hooley is a WiLD PARTY. in NZ felt to be irish, (and perhaps associated with hooligan)  but probably a development of OED hoolee (sb) [Hindi holi] E indies. The great festival or carnival of the Hindoos, held at the approach of the vernal equinox, in honour of Krishna and the Gopis milkmaids < 1687.1800 the hooly, or saturnalia of india, when liberty of speech and action towards superiors are allowed ... 1825. During all the time of Hoolee, drunkenness is common among the Hindoos.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/2001  
 Source:  Curious Questions
 Author:  CRYER
 Vol / Page:  102
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Before the second World War a hoon was a loutish exhibitionist... [After the war] the word remained in use, but reverted to its earlier sense. A few grammatical extensions also exist: hoonish, hoonism, hooning, hoondom, hoon around, hoon it up, a bit of a hoon, hoon-chaser (traffic police) and hoon-bin(place where drunken football hoons are put to cool off).

 Notes:  

hoon
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a humanitarian, ethical or political objector to military service; a person whose objection to military service is based on other than religious convictions; a political or humanitarian objector 1941-5. ACB: ca1941-45 A.C. Barrington; J. McCreary; a non-religious objector 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/2004  
 Source:  Question of Faith, A
 Author:  GRANT
 Vol / Page:  53
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The third group were non-religious objectors (known as 'hoons'in camp) who were a diverse group, often individualists, who opposed war for a variety of ethical and humanitarian reasons... Christian pacifists and some 'hoons' mixed well and learned from each other. 'Hoon' George Gunn recalled that the Methodists "simply glowed with humanity."
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/2000  
 Source:  Bread and Water
 Author:  FOOTE
 Vol / Page:  14
 Edition:  
 Quote:  However, a number of Christian pacificsts and some 'hoons', - humanitarian/ethical/political objectors - felt this argument was a cop out. <i>ibid.</i> 62 The majority of the Christian pacifists in detention were Methodists. Hoon George Gunn wrote, "they simply glowed with humanity."
 Notes:  Used in WWii period

 Date:  0/0/2001  
 Source:  Curious Questions
 Author:  CRYER
 Vol / Page:  102
 Edition:  
 Quote:  During the war the same word [sc. hoon]underwent a complete reversal of meaning. Poeple who were conscientious objectors on other than religious grounds were known to the military as hoons...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1953  
 Source:  Till Human Voices Wake Us
 Author:  HAM,iLTON
 Vol / Page:  154
 Edition:  
 Quote:  i hadn't been in detention long when i heard his name mentioned ...He hadn't gone to jail with the first group ...They reckoned he'd stuck to his religion all through and the Hoons [(fn) non - religious groups] gave me the impression that he took his religion seriously ... you couldn't take much notice of the Hoons of course, not about a thing like that. Most of them just lumped the

religoes together ... . <i>ibid.</i>  164 There was a sort of line drawn in the [detention] camps

betwen the Hoons and the religoes. ... The religoes were divided again into God knows how many sects and amongst the hoons were absolute pacifists, pacifists, Communists, Anarchists, humanists, and plain dodgers. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Love and War
 Author:  SANDYS
 Vol / Page:  244
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `i'm lucky to be here [in a detention camp for conscientious objectors]. Reckon they must have got me mixed up with the Hoons. i'd be much worse off in a regular gaol.' `Are all the men here pacifists?' ... / `But you'd have a job getting anything like a consensus out of the lot we've got here. Some are war resisters- ... Then there are the Christians. ... They're still trying to work out how the hell they landed up [here] ... The majority are Hoons - military defaulters. Against war for reasons of sanity and humanity, not out of religious conviction.

hoon-ethos
 Homonym Number:

 Sense Number:

 See:

 Citations 
 Date:  20/12/1986  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  13
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The best-known primer for this kind of activity, and indeed an integral part of the hoon-ethos itself, is the drinking game. Designed to take the monotony out of rapid, heavy drinking, the drinking game perhaps found its purest expression in the version entitled Next. Down a drink as fast as possible (commonly known as `sculling'), turn to the bloke on your left and say `Next', whereupon he does the same ... very efficient.

 Date:  0/0/1898

 Notes:  

 Date:  12/1/1896  
 Source:  Truth (Sydney)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `There are several specimens of bush slang transplanted from the Maori language. `Hoot' is a very frequent synonym for money or wage. i have heard a shearer at the Pastoralist Union office in Sydney when he sought to ascertain the scale of remuneration, enquire of the gilt-edged clerk behind the barrier, `What's the hoot, mate?' The Maori equivalent for money is utu, pronounced by the Ngapuhi and other northern tribes with the last syllable clipped, and the word is very largely used by the kauri-gum diggers and station hands in the North island. The original  meaning of first settled in New Zealand, they found that the savage inhabitants had no conception of any recompense except the grim recompense of blood. Under Christianizing influences the natives were induced to forego the blood-revenge for injuries, on receiving a

solatium  in goods or land, and so utu came to have the double meaning of revenge and recompense, and eventually became recognized as the Maori word for money.'

hoot
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun

 Date:  0/0/1889

 Quote:   [Note] Utu, revenge or satisfaction on the principle of blood for blood; also payment in more modern times. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1990  
 Source:  Personal Communication
 Author:  H W ORSMAN
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A. Maori contexts. Orig. a European rendering of the Maori noun utu, return (for anything ); satisfaction, ransom, reward,  price, reply' (Williams); not to be used confused with uto `revenge', a confusion evident in many of the explanations of the meaning of utu). 



The word widely used was in all the above senses by Europeans who had dealings with Maoris, from the general `return for work, injury, etc.' to the concrete `money' it is often found constructed with the definite article `the utu, hutu' etc. translating  the original Maori indefinite article, or adjective `some' he utu `an utu, some utu'. (Occas. constr with indef. article, see 1834). 



in later European usage the definite article was dropped to conform to English idiom eg' `give me the hoot' becomes `give me (some) hoot' The following is perhaps a `transitional' use 1828 C Davis journal Colenso Papers 3/18) `Another chief had been killed as a utu or payment'. (is this [ei utu] reflecting Maori [(h)e utu], as well as English  a for an?). 



The phonology, resulting in the English  hoot, parallels that of toot from  tutu, with the final unvoiced [u] not being heard by English ears. The initial [h] derives perhaps from a syncopation of [he utu]; but more prob. from the var. or error noted on p. 4 of 1842:  Maunsell Grammar of the New Zealand Language (4th ed) 1894: `in  pronouncing u, the speaker will have to guard against the error of those who prefix the aspirate when no aspirate is admissable. According to the u, utu, etc., are pronounced as if spelt hu, hutu.'. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1964  
 Source:  Book of New Zealand, A (J.C. Reid)

 Vol / Page:  285

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
 Author:  TURNER
 Vol / Page:  132
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in New Zealand, the term bash for a party where drink is the chief attractionis heard (or was, some years ago among Wellington students) and  hophead for a person who drinks regularly. The term  hophead is (or was) used in convivial greetings, `Hello, hophead', the implication that the person addressed was a persistent drinker being equivalent to calling him a decent joker.

 Date:  5/4/2001  
 Source:  Evening Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  6
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Within minutes of play starting Hopoate was written indelibly and ever so elegantly into the language, A quite bad shot brought the threat, with the appropriate gesture, of a one-finger hopo. A rank short bowl was a two-finger hopo, an appalling misjudgment of a shot a three-finger hopo...Then the skip... looked stricken, turned ashen-faced and disappeared at unusual speed into the club-house - proof-positive the hopo is here to stay as the ultimate deterrent to poor play in any sport.

 Quote:  He was what is termed in mining phraseology, a `hatter', - meaning one who works by himself. ... Alone and unaided he scooped the wash-dirt into his cradle, which he vigorously rocked with his left hand, whilst with the right he ladled water from the river into the `hopper' or seive [sic]. ... He cast aside the `dipper', and hastened towards the eddy.

hopper
 Homonym Number:  2
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Orig. cheese-hopper; applied by bacon-handlers to the maggots which breed in bacon; and more widely to any sort of maggot (from blow-flies in meat): from ca1910 (WHBO).

 Edition:  
 Quote:  TREVALLY  (a) Scientific name: <i>Caranx lutescens</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Trevally; New Zealand Pompano. (c) Other common names: Hoppers (fish in uncleaned

state). (d) Principal localities where taken: [Largely confined to northern waters and south to Cook Strait].

 Edition:  
 Quote:  The use of the word `Hori' was becoming distasteful said ... Mr H.W. Herewini, a former officer of the 28 Maori Battalion ... addressing the annual conference of the New Zealand Returned Services Association ... appealing to the association to act as a spearhead to create better race

relations in New Zealand.... As an example of deteriorating race relations ... [he] instanced the use of the word `Hori'. `That word is becoming distasteful to many - but the Kiwi and the Maori let it go because we know we don't mean it in a distasteful way.'

 Date:  1/7/1988  
 Source:  Dominion
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  10
 Edition:  
 Quote:  (John C. Mcab) Brown and white there were no differences between the colours then [in WW2]. The happy members of the 28th Battalion referred to themselves as `horis' (i've never known what the word meant, but now to use it is as big an insult as for a white to be called a Pakeha), and spoke of `Maori time' (some time) and `Maori PT' (lying on one's bedroll) and we followed their lead, not knowing that they, and we, were using such appallingly insulting terms to the Maori race that a special Race Relations Conciliator would have to be installed to quell them.

 Notes:  

Hori
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a Maori [Maori Hori[o-macron], alteration of George]. it was often used as a stage-Maori name, or as a general term of reference or address to an un-named Maori. Unlike Hongi, it was not at first so objectivable as used by English speakers (but cf the 1933 quotation). it is used by Maoris among themselves humorously or sardonically;  cf George, hongi @n.  (From Maori rendering of English George, formerly fairly common as a name among Maoris, esp. during reigns of Kings George iii-Vi; cf.)  1a. a  particular Maori named Hori


 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes:

 Quote:  TVNZ said "Poms" was a term used affectionately by Kiwis and Australians, and it rejected the complainants' view that the word was comparable to terms such as "Chinks",  "Wogs", or "Horis". it agreed expressions such as "Pommy bastards" and "whingeing Poms" were terms of abuse. Authority chairman Sam Maling noted the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's ruling that the words "Pom" and "Pommy" were unlikely to offend of insult.

 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  299
 Edition:  (2nd edn)
 Quote:  THORNFiSH or HORNY <i>Bovichtus variegatus roseopictus</i> Hutton This beautifully marked and coloured fish is sometimes called Horny by boys. Both the common names are derived from the sharp spines which puncture the flesh of one's hands when taking the Thornfish from a net.

 Author:  AYLiNG
 Vol / Page:  274
 Edition:  1984
 Quote:  THORNFiSH (Horny, dragonet) <i>Bovichtus variegatus  (Bovichthys variegatus)</i> ... The thornfish is a small, cylindrical fish with scaleless body ... There is a distinctive strong spine directed upward and backward on each gill cover behind the eyes. ... Thornfish are common in tidepools ... from the Wellington area southwards ...

 Vol / Page:  17/216
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Amongst smaller trees and shrubs the most prominent are the horoeka (<i>Panax crassifolia</i>), and its congeners <i>Panax simplex</i> and <i>P. edgerleyi</i>, both exhibiting such excessive luxuriance as frequently to require an examination of the fruit before their identification can be determined; the rautawhiri (<i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, var. <i>colensoi</i>), the kotukutuku (<i>Fuchsia excorticata</i>), the mako (<i>Aristotelia racemosa</i>), the mapau (<i>Myrsine australis</i>), the pokako (<i>Eloeocarpus 

hookerianus</i>), also <i>Carpodetus serratus, Myrsine divaricata</i>, both of which are abundant. The remarkable `weeping tree', <i>Myrsine montana</i>, with its crowded recurved branches and small foliage, affords a picturesque effect

 Quote:  <i>Drymis axillaris</i> Horopita 


 Notes:  (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)

horopito
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Drimys axillaris a small, slender, evergreen tree with aromatic bark. Also called pepper tree.
 Origin: Maori
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  15/8/2002  
 Source:  Dominion Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  D3
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The kitchen gets marks for initiative in sourcing ingredients, having somehow found somebody to supply piko piko, horopito and other New Zealand bush herbs, some of which, the waitress told me, had gone into the Hubba Hubba spice rub for the salt water prawns and calamari.
 Notes:  

 Date:  24/8/2002  
 Source:  Dominion Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  F16
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Horopito (Pseudowintera) was used for skin and venereal diseases and Mother Aubert, in a letter to the French Consul, wrote that a chemist at the University of Paris considered her medicine Karana, which contained horopito, was "superior to Quinquina (quinine). it has been very useful to me in cases of anaemia, of debility, of continuous diarrhoea etc, and in recovery from temperatures."
 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks
 Author:  DAWSON
 Vol / Page:  103
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Kawakawa is sometimes called `native pepper tree' because of its hot tasting leaves, and it is in fact related to the true pepper plant of indonesia ..  Horopito (<i>Pseudowintera axillaris</i>) with its dark green shiny leaves has also been termed `pepper tree' for the same reason, but it is not in fact related to the kawakawa.
 Notes:

 Quote:  A decoction of the leaves [sc. of Horopito or Drimys axillaris] is not uncommonly used by bushmen and others to allay pain and is honoured with the name of "Maori Painkiller".

 Date:  0/0/1869  
 Source:  TrNZi
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  1/iii/5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ..  (e.g.) the Houhere, <i>Hoheria populnea </i>.. the Horopito  <i>Drimys axillaris </i>; the Manuka-rau-riki, <i>Leptospermum ericoides </i>;  the Kohuhu, <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium </i>; the Kowhai, especially the small-leaved mountain variety <i>Sophora tetraptera </i> var.: <i>grandiflora</i>; the Koromiko-taranga,  <i>Veronica </i>, several species; the Mairehau, <i>Phebalium nudum </i>; the Toro, <i>Persoonia Toro </i>; the Pukapuka, <i>Brachyglottis repanda </i>; the Northern Maire,  <i>Santalum Cunninghamii </i>; the Tawari, <i>ixerba brexioides </i>; the Tipau,  <i>Myrsine Urvillei </i> and <i>M. salicina </i>; the Tangeao,  <i>Tetranthera calicaris </i>; the Ramarama, <i>Myrtus bullata </i>; the Ti, <i>Cordyline australis </i>; the Kahikomako, <i>Pennantia corymbosa </i>; the  Pate, <i>Schefflera digitata </i>; the Horoeka, <i>Panax crassifolia </i>: and, on the sea-coast .. the Karo, <i>Pittosporum crassifolium </i>; and the truly evergreen Ngaio, <i>Myoporum laetum </i> ...

horopito
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a pepper flavouring from leaves of the horopito tree.
 Origin: Maori
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Cuisine
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 Edition:  
 Quote:  Mussels provide a taste of New Zealand, and this soup for all occasions is complete with the unique flavour of horopito (bush pepper) and a sprinkle of manuka-smoked sea salt. .. Add the mussels, spinach leaves and horopito .. Add more horopito to taste.

horrors
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: the horrors, the DT's, delirium tremens; but widened often to a bad attack of the shakes, joe blakes; dingbats; creeps, etc.

 Notes:  

horse
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: as a distiguishing epithet in the names of plants and animals often indicating one larger or coarser than the  usual variety, see mussel, nettle, plantain;  see also horse-mackerel. 


 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes:

 Notes:  The Goldfields of NZ

 Date:  0/0/1909  
 Source:  TrNZi
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  41/77
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Rising to No. 2 level, a barren block of glassy quartz comes in, and the seamy gold-bearing quartz is pushed over to the two walls, and divided by clay partings from the barren centre block,

which corresponds practically to a `horse' of country rock....  [The blocks] are frequently split

by `horses' and the stone is generally mottled and seamy.

 Vol / Page:  121
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HORSE MACKEREL<i> See Mackerel, Horse or Koheru. </i> <i>ibid.</i> 140 KOHERU Commonly-caught inhabitant of our northern coastal waters who is also known as Yellowtail or Horse Mackerel. <i>ibid.</i> 162 MACKEREL ... The common Mackerel is also known as the English Mackerel, Frigate Mackerel or Southern Mackerel. The Horse Mackerel is also known as the Yellowtail. The Koheru is also sometimes known as Yellowtail and is often misnamed Horse Mackerel and Scad.
 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1886  
 Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
 Author:  SHERRiN
 Vol / Page:  46
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HORSE MACKEREL (<i>Trachurus trachurus</i>). ... This is the hauture of the Natives, and the scad of the Northern Hemisphere. <i>ibid.</i> 61 MACKEREL (<i>Scomber Australasicus</i>). ... This valuable fish is well known as an occasional visitant in Wellington Harbour, being called by the Natives tawatawa. in colour, size, and form it closely approaches the common mackerel of England, and is very superior in delicacy to the scad or horse-mackerel, which is commonly called the mackerel in New Zealand.
 Notes:

 Source:  Journal
 Author:  PARKiNSON
 Vol / Page:  114

shags. [in the Stout Collection copy, Victoria University Library, an early 19th C. or late 18th C. hand has added: `*Baracootas, a fish remarkably smooth about 7 or 8 foot long [dagger] Flying Gurnards, a flying fish, of a remarkable fine Gold Colour.  Vol / Page:  1/126

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRiS
 Vol / Page:  203
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Horse-Mackerel, n.</i>  The name is applied in Sydney to the fish <i>Auxis  ramsayi</i>, Castln., family <i>Scombridae</i>. in New Zealand it is <i>Caranx(or Trachurus) trachurus</i>, Cuv. and Val., which is the same fish as the Horse-Mackerel of England. This is called <i>yellow-tail</i> on the Australian coasts. See <i>Trevally.</i>

horse paddock
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a paddock in which pack, draught, or saddle horses are grazed when not working [adjacent to a homestead, outstation or shepherds' quarters].

 Date:  0/0/1913  
 Source:  Country Work
 Author:  CARR
 Vol / Page:  11
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Haymaking. ... The jobs to look for are `cocking up' (with a two or three pronged fork), driving the horse rake (no handrakes are used nowadays) ... loading the drays or sledges when ready ... A `crow' is also employed, whose work consists of passing the fork-fulls thrown up by the carter to the stacker.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  55/149
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>para</i>, a large fern (Marattia fraxinea), horse-shoe fern, from the shape of the tuber; also paraeka, since para was also the name given to the tubers of two orchids, Gastrodia Cunninghamii and Orthoceras strictum; but if there is no distinguishing suffix para is understood to mean the fern-tuber, as in the place-name Kaipara, so called because the well-known ihenga there enjoyed his first meal of that tuber. 


 Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
 Author:  McGiLL
 Vol / Page:  58
 Edition:  
 Quote:  hosed off fed up; perhaps from being hosed with water, just possibly connected with English late-C16 colloquialism `in my other hose', expressing refusal or disbelief. Current usage would be: `was i hosed off when the first decent shower of rain brought down the wooden retaining wall i'd spent a whole day building.'

hospital paddock
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a spelling paddock where animals recover from disease or illness [usually located close to the homestead or working buildings and with natural shade and water.] 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]

 Date:  27/1/2001  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  48
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [He] would like to know the meaning and origin of the term 'hospital pass'. it's a rugby term and refers to a pass to a player about to be (heavily) tackled, and thus liable to be injured. Occasionally, the pass is called a "Hail mary", from a prayer needed to make it successful.

 Date:  10/2/2001  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:

hote

 Sense Number: 
 Definition: vegetable caterpillar,awheto
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See:

Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1844  
 Source:  Journal
 Author:  J.B. WiLLiAMS
 Vol / Page:  108
 Edition:  1956
 Quote:  The Hotte a decided Caterpillar or worm, is found growing at the foot of the Rata tree with a plant growing out of its head; some have said that this peculiar and singular insect travels up the tree, both the rata & periri [puriri] trees, and entering into the top burrows or eats its way through the trunk of the tree until it reaches the root; it then comes out of the root and dies or remains dormant and the plant propagates out of its head, the body remains perfect and entire, ... 

[Glossary 118 ... Cordyceps robertsii: a fungus which attacks caterpillars . . .] 


 Notes:  

hotel
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: in NZ, any licensed public house; the general name for a public-house, esp. (and formerly) one offering accommodation. The word inn has rarely been used in NZ, except in the name of a particular hotel. Tavern, a licence which does not offer accommodation for guests, been used since 19??. 


 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1844  
 Source:  Journal
 Author:  J.E.WiLLiAMS
 Vol / Page:  69
 Edition:  1956
 Quote:  i might say with propriety that six eighths of all the European houses are nothing more than grogeries. Here are in capital letters over the door `Tap'. One in particular so-called Hotel, a man and his family the only occupants, over the door a large sign one third as large as the front, with bold letters `Victoria Hotel.' Her Majesty must feel proud to have her name in blazon letters embellishing a house, where all kinds of satanical devices are practiced with [sic] impunity.

 Vol / Page:  200

 Vol / Page:  No.3/88
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in London the swells in the park drive all round, But the diggers drive here with a pick underground;  And the props that they use, surely everyone knows  Ain't the same used in London for hanging up clothes.  The women use fans* there, the men use them here,  Though to cockneys that statement may sound very queer, And the fellows that frequently hang round hotels,  Out here are called loafers, at home are called swells.  -->[p 89 fn] * A fan is a machine for pumping air down the shafts.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1887  
 Source:  Taken in
 Author:  HOPEFUL
 Vol / Page:  71
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The town [Lyttelton] was hilly ..., and for so small a place there seemed no end of `Pubs', or 

Hotels as they are called here, at each corner of which stood groups of men, idling and gossipping - in fact, the male element prevailed greatly, and it was rather an ordeal for the `New Chum' to have to go through the ranks this way. <i>ibid.</i> 134 if this is agreed they will

adjourn to the nearest inn, or hotels as these little match-boxes are called; ... When one friend

meets another very often the greeting will [135] be, `Are you going to stand `shout'?' in other words, `Are you going to stand drink or `treat'?' if this is agreed to they will adjourn to the nearest inn, or hotels as these poor little match-boxes are called; and in fact there is a great

deal of standing `shout' in the Colonies, both in public and in private.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1899  
 Source:  in the Shadow of the Bush
 Author:  BELL
 Vol / Page:  21
 Edition:  
 Quote:  About the centre of the township, on the main street, two or three hotels, already mentioned, stood, with most of the other places of business scattered around in their vicinity. The hotels were at such a distance from each other as to allow the landlord of each to stand at his own door and watch with feelings of envy any unusual trend of customers seeking refreshment at the other. They were large, pretentious buildings of their class, with verandah and balcony to each, and were well-conducted inns, the accommodation afforded to travellers being all that could be expected - equal, indeed, to that of some of the best hotels in the larger centres.

 Quote:  The practice of calling hotels `Hotel Astor' instead of `Astor Hotel' etc. dates i think from c. 1928, and was i think inspired by `Chateau Tongariro' which was built about then. i can remember a number changing, including the Astor in Auckland & all were subsequent to the name `Chateau Tongariro'

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1882  
 Source:  Brighter Britain
 Author:  HAY
 Vol / Page:  2/229
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Hotete is the so-called `vegetating caterpillar'. it is a grub two or three inches long, and out of its head there grows a parasitic fungus (Spaeria Robertsii) ... The natives eat the hotete. it is

the larva of  Hepialus virescens, a kind of locust. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1904  
 Source:  Maori Race, The
 Author:  TREGEAR
 Vol / Page:  86
 Edition:  
 Quote:   ... careful watch was also kept upon the growing plants to guard them from the ravages of 

a certain caterpillar; the larva of a large  moth (anuhe, awhato, hotete; Cordiceps  robertsii) which preyed on the kumara leaves ... This pest is better known as the `vegetable caterpillar' from a fungus that grows from it after death.

houhere
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a small, white-flowered, graceful tree with a fibrous many-layered underbark [Maori], the application of houhere to Plangianthus sp. is a back-formation from lacebark or ribbonwood applied to both genera;  =lacebark, =ribbonwood, =thousand jacket, =houhi,  also called lacebark, ribbonwood, thousand-jacket.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1940  
 Source:  Plants of NZ
 Author:  LAiNG & BLACKWELL
 Vol / Page:  264
 Edition:  
 Quote:  notes: The varied names given by the Maoris in different districts to this plant, are all said to spring from the same root. <i>Whau</i> signifies `wrapped about, netted - like lace', and the tree

is so-called from the character of its inner bark. The settlers name it lacebark, ribbonwood or

thousand-jacket' <i>Cf Williams, whawhau</i> v.t. `tie', <i>whau</i> = hou, (hohou) vt `lash, bind together'.

 Date:  0/0/1869  
 Source:  TrNZi
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  1/iii/5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... (e.g.) the Houhere, <i>Hoheria populnea</i> ...; the Horopito <i> Drimys axillaris</i> ; the Manuka-rau-riki, <i> Leptospermum ericoides</i> ; the Kohuhu, <i> Pittosporum tenuifolium</i> ; the Kowhai, especially the small-leaved mountain variety,  <i> Sophora tetraptera</i>  var.: <i> grandiflora</i> ; the Koromiko-taranga, <i> Veronica</i> , several species; the Mairehau, <i> Phebalium nudum</i> ; the Toro, <i> Persoonia Toro</i> ; the Pukapuka, <i> Brachyglottis repanda</i> ; the Northern Maire, <i> Santalum Cunninghamii</i> ; the Tawari, <i> ixerba brexioides</i> ; the Tipau, <i> Myrsine Urvillei</i>  and <i> M. salicina</i> ; the Tangeao, <i> Tetranthera calicaris</i> ; the Ramarama, <i> Myrtus bullata</i> ; the Ti, <i> Cordyline australis</i> ; the Kahikomako, <i> Pennantia corymbosa</i> ; the Pate, <i> Schefflera digitata</i> ; the Horoeka, <i> Panax crassifolia</i> : and, on the sea-coast, ... the Karo, <i> Pittosporum crassifolium</i> ; and the truly evergreen Ngaio, <i> Myoporum laetum</i>  ...
 Notes:  (Colenso Botany North isd)

 Date:  0/0/1882  
 Source:  Brighter Britain
 Author:  HAY

 Notes:  [Morris 120]

 Date:  0/0/1889  
 Source:  Forest Flora
 Author:  KiRK
 Vol / Page:  87
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in one or other of its varied forms the `houhere' is found in nearly every district of NZ. ...The bark is capable of division into a number of layers.... By settlers all forms are termed `ribbonwood', or less frequently `lace-bark' - names which are applied to other plants [Gaya Lyallii (now H. Lyallii) Plagianthus betulinus, Pennantia corymbosa]; they are also termed `thousand-jacket'  


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1890

 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Maoris apply the names <i>hoihere</i>  or <i>houhere</i>  to varieties [of <i>Hoheria populnea</i> ] indifferently; the European settlers usually call all the forms `ribbon-wood' or `lacebark', names which are, unfortunately, also used for <i>Plagianthus betulinus</i> and <i>Gaya Lyallii.</i>

 Date:  0/0/1949  
 Source:  Coming of the Maori, The
 Author:  BUCK
 Vol / Page:  156, 162, 264
 Edition:  
 Quote:  
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1889  
 Source:  Art Album NZ Flora
 Author:  FEATON
 Vol / Page:  55
 Edition:  
 Quote:  HOHERiA POPULNEA (A.Cunn.) ... The `HOUi' or `WHAU-WHi'.- ... grow abundantly in both islands. ... Owing to the chaste [snow-white] appearance of its flowers, it has not inaptly been termed by some the `New Zealand orange Blossom'. The inner bark is peculiar, and consists of layer upon layer of laced fibre, ...From this peculiarity it is called by the settlers the `Thousand Jacket', `lace-bark', or `Ribbon-wood'.

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRiS
 Vol / Page:  205
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Houi</i>, n. Maori name for New Zealand tree, <i>Ribbonwood(q.v.),  N.O. Malvaceae</i>, kindred to <i>Hoheria, Plagianthus Betulinus</i>, sometimes called <i>Howi</i>. in Maori, the verb <i>houwere</i>means to tie, to bind: the outer bark was used for tying.

houma

 Origin:

 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See:

 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1867  
 Source:  Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  765
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Houma, <i>Hector. Sophora tetraptera. </i>
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1868  
 Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
 Author:  LiNDSAY
 Vol / Page:  73
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>S. tetraptera</i>, Aiton, var. <i>microphylla</i>, Jacq. ... The `Kowhai' of the North island Maori; the `Kowai' of settlers, - or as the word is variously corrupted and spelt by them, - `Goai' or `Ghoai,' `Goa' or `Ghoa.' According to Hector, the type is known to Otago Maoris as `Houma;' while the term `Kowhai' is applied to var. <i> grandiflora</i> in common with its other varieties. Var. <i>microphylla</i> is also sometimes designated by the colonists the Native `Laburnum' or `Mimosa,' from the similarity of its foliage, in the arboreous condition, to that of these familiar ... European trees.
 Notes:

phrase for Carisbrook, but it is certainly not the first major stadium to boast this moniker. in the 1980s the Houston Astrodome was similarly labelled, in recognition of an intimidating defensive line sported by the Houston (now Tennessee) Oilers of the NPL.

 Notes:  

 Date:  12/2/2000  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  48
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [Two correspondents] wonder why the Dunedin rugby ground, Carisbrook, is called "The House of Pain." Otago rugby historian Dave McLaren says that several people claim to have coined the nickname, but the most likely person is ex-player (and children's book author) Brent Pope. Apparently, some time in the mid to late 80s, Pope was heard to exclaim, after a particularly hard training run inflicted on them by coach Laurie Mains, "Why the hell do we keep coming to this bloody house of pain?" it went public on September 27, 1992, when North Harbour coach Brad Mourant said much the same thing in his after-match function speech.

 Notes:  

 Date:  12/8/2001  
 Source:  Sunday Star Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  A2
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The House of Pain, it was said, would fill the Ocker hearts with ice.
 Notes:  

 Date:  28/9/2004  
 Source:  Letter
 Author:  PALENSKi
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  it is often assumed that the phrase [sc. the "House of Pain"] came to be applied by visiting teams because of the perceived difficulty of winning at Carisbrook. it actually began, however, in the late 1980s within the Otago team when players referred to Carisbrook as the House of Pain, because of exhausting training sessions. it was once attributed to an Otago player of the time, Brent Pope, and he happily claimed the credit for it, but it's difficult to pin down to one person. it's only in recent years that it's been seen as the House of Pain for visiting teams - a belief encouraged by Radio Sport (which began in 1998) commentators who had little or no acquaintance with either the ground or the phrase.

how
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a howitzer shell
 Origin: 
 Register: 

 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1936  
 Source:  Recollections of an Amateur Soldier
 Author:  TREADWELL
 Vol / Page:  112
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Shell after shell burst round our ears as we clambered down. `Whiz-bangs' give no chance of escape. The first thing is the `whiz', and if it is coming straight there is no chance to escape the `bang'. it is different with the `how.', for ... a soldier can tell by the note of its flight if the shell is coming near or not.

Howard Smither
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/5/1951  
 Source:  Letter
 Author:  PUGH-WiLLiAMS
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  if a vessel sails at any time in the evening and to avoid payment of overtime to personnel who would have an excess of eight hours if they worked all day and their watch in the evening, they are given the afternoon off and report back on board just prior to sailing. Such time off is called `a Howard Smither'. One of the first companies to bring this in was one Howard Smith and Co. of Australia, a firm seafarer noted for means to save money at the so-called expense of the [hand].
