 Quote:  i had a word with Manawatu hill country farmer Darrell Shellard, after he was quoted saying there was no use howlibagging about flood damage; you just had to get on with cleaning up the mess. ... Howlibagging is a great word, presumably a mixture of howling and bagging (criticising), but Darrell says he has no idea where it came from.

Heather Hapeta .. chimed in with an e-mail saying "howly-bag" had been in her family since the mid-1970's, meaning cry-baby.  The setting she recalls, was in Maori groups in Christchurch.

how's it goin', mate?
 Homonym Number:

 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]

 Notes:  

how's that?
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: phrase
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: an interrog. phrase or `Why?'; occas. an indication of imperfect hearing or understanding: `What did you say?', phs from `How does that come about?' As intej.= `why' us. pron. [ha'uz set] with intonation pattern [B ]. Perhaps assoc. with the cricketer's' coy Howzat?.. Phs dial in origin: cp EDD How adv. ii 1. 22 Howat, How that how was it that why was it? Cum. [through the quot. suggests a different constr & use from the NZ] or ii 2. =Why? how comes it? (Sc. Lan Cor) e.g. `How didn't you tell'ni would come?' (Pen). Cf OED adv. 1.c. Obsolete pregnant use = How is it that? How comes it that? Why? Last quot. 1611 Bible `How said thou, She is my sister?' cf 4 interject (esp US) =What? What!  


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations

hucklebones
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMiTH
 Vol / Page:  176
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Knucklebones (K-34) was played in both Europe and Polynesia, independently at first. in the nineteenth century distinct European [177] and Maori versions were known. More recently, the two types have merged, and today the Maori children, who are mainly responsible for perpetuating the game in New Zealand, include in their games movements borrowed from the

European tradition. ... in most of the provinces the game was known as Knucklebones, and it is widely reported as having been played by New Zealand children of European origin until about 1900. Occasionally it was known as Chucks, Chuckstones, Chuckystones, Fingerstones, Hucklebones, Jacks, Jackstones, Knuckles, or Knucklestones. Children still played it here and there throughout the country in 1949, but they knew little about it until plastic knuckles were imported in 1954 in large quantities and revived the game.
 Notes:

Huey
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: Hughie
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Hills, The
 Author:  PiCKERiNG
 Vol / Page:  8
 Edition:  
 Quote:  So to cope with the rituals of tramping, its pains and camaraderie, a slang language has developed to suit. Lots of quick short words to fit in the breathless pauses as you pant uphill. `Crud' (cloud), `bush-bash', a `gunn' tramper (which must have originated from Davy Gunn's famous trek up the Hollyford Valley to help victims of a plane crash in1936; he travelled 40 km by rowing boat, horse and foot in 21 hours), `windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), `pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag), `pog' (porridge), `bastard grass' and `lawyer' (two unpleasant plants), `piker' (one who stayed home), `Huey' (all-powerful god of weather), and many, many more. <i>ibid.</i> 46  New Zealand weather, sometimes called `Huey', is fast and fickle, with abrupt and noisy changes of mood. 


 Notes:  [Not so: HWO]), `windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), `pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag), `pog'  (porridge), `bastard grass' and `lawyer' (two unpleasant plants), `piker' (one who stayed home), `Huey' (all-powerful god of weather) ...

Hughie
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1937  
 Source:  Dictionary of Slang
 Author:  PARTRiDGE
 Vol / Page:  209
 Edition:  
 Quote:  David (or Davy)!, send it down. Often send it down, David,  send it down! A military c.p. apropos of a shower, esp. if likely to cause a parade to be postponed: C. 20. F. & Gibbons; B. & P. (Wales has a notoriously wet climate; David, the Welsh parton saint.) New  Zealanders and Australians say send her down, Hughie!.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/9/1958  
 Source:  Tararua
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  27
 Edition:  
 Quote:  An outsider might guess that our weather in the hills was almost always bad, to judge by the characteristic expressions used. The derisive phrases, `Send it down, Hughie' and `Let it come down, Hughie', go back to early in this century and are variants of the British military catch-phrase `Send it down, David'. `Send her down, Hughie', common in Australia's droughty climate, may not be so derisive. Judging by a verse attached to Dekker's Shoemaker's Holiday, St. Hugh has long been associated with rain. 


 Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail

 Date:  0/9/1958  
 Source:  Tararua
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  65
 Edition:

 Quote:   '... There's a walloping great shower coming.' `We'll take it. Send her down Hughie.' cf Part: David Send it down David (Davy) ... A milit c.p. apropos of a shower, esp. if likely to cause a

parade to be postponed: C20: F & Gibbons: B&P: (Wales has a notoriously wet climate; David, the Welsh patron saint.) New Zealander's & Australians say send her down, Hughie. Sup Semantics: Wales is the land of leeks (leaks)

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1977  
 Source:  Dictionary of Catch Phrases
 Author:  PARTRiDGE
 Vol / Page:  188
 Edition:  
 Quote:  send her down, Hughie! (and ..., Steve!) This Australian - hence also New Zealand - c.p. of late 

C19-20, the Steve variant being used during WW1, expresses a fervent desire for rain. (AS.) Variations of  the next, her for it being characteristically Australian.  send it down, David (with variant Davy lad)! The variant belongs  to the Regular Army: and the basic send it down, 

David is often intensified by the addition of  a repetitive send it down: late C19-20. in the army. esp. during WW1, it was used to implore David, the Welsh patron saint, to send a preferably very heavy shower, notably when it might cause a parade to be postponed or cancelled. Parts of Wales have a notoriously wet climate: and, what is more, Wales is the `Land of Leeks' (leaks). Both F & G and B & P are eloquent about this cp.

 Quote:  The larvae [of longhorn beetles] are timber-borers. The huhu,  <i>Prionoplus reticularis</i>, also known as `horny bug', `crusty back' and `hum-bug' in adult life, is said to be a toothsome morsel in the grub stage-but should not be washed down with alcohol as its tissues already carry a fair amount from the wood it consumes.

huhu
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Prionoplus reticularis, the grub (esp), and the beetle (pron. [hu:hu.], Maori [huhu]). A native beetle or its edible grub, found in decayed wood [Maori];, larva of the beatle found in decayed timber

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1985  
 Source:  Towards Taha Maori
 Author:  HOWE
 Vol / Page:  19
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hui - `meeting together'. Huis may be held for various reasons, but the main ones are that they give the opportunity for continued social interaction of both sexes, young and old; they allow

Maoris the opportunity to keep alive precious traditions (eg, song, dance, oratory, spirituality) and remember the past. Huis allow large numbers to meet and come to a consensus.

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  66
 Edition:  
 Quote:  He shifts into galvanising-leader mode, exhorting membership drives, slamming recent government publicity "about-turns" on Maori policy, dismissing the planned 2005 hui tamata (Maori economic summit) as little more than a government publicity stunt, stressing the need to validate Maori knowledge and "take New Zealand with us. We have to do as we preach; we have to help them get over the whakama [embarrassment] of saying 'Papatoetoe' [correctly] in front of their friends ... We will Maori-ise New Zealand. ..." 


 Notes:  

huia
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Heteralocha acutirostris, an extinct member of the NZ wattlebird family (Callaeatidae) prized by the Maori for its tail feathers [Ma. hu[u]ia, a bird (now extinct) whose tail feathers were valued as ornaments by Maoris.]
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  306/35
 Edition:  
 Quote:  As a young man, Pycroft had the distinction of eating a huia. Skilled in taxidermy, he had been sent a huia for mounting. After skinning it he handed its body to his landlady and had her skin it.

 Date:  0/0/1843  
 Source:  Travels in NZ
 Author:  DiEFFENBACH
 Vol / Page:  1/89
 Edition:  
 Quote:  But the bird ... is only found in the deepest recesses of the primeval forest covering the hills around Port Nicholson, and between the latter place and Hawke's Bay. it is called by the natives Uia, and was received into the ornithological system under the name of Neomorpha Gouldii. [90] ... the continued loud and shrill whistling of my guide, <i>uia, uia, uia</i>, in imitation of the notes of the bird, had attracted four, ... 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1845  
 Source:  Adventure in NZ
 Author:  WAKEFiELD
 Vol / Page:  1/91
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The huia is a black bird about as large as a thrush, with long thin legs and a slender semi-circular beak, which he uses in seeking in holes in trees for the insects on which he feeds. in the tail are four long black feathers tipt with white. These feathers are much valued by the natives as ornaments for the hair on great occasions .... The natives attracted the birds by imitating the peculiar whistle, from which it takes the name of huia.

 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Heteralocha acutirostris</i>. - Huia. South part of North island, in Ruahine, Tararua, and Rimutaka Ranges.
 Notes:  (Martin)

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRiS
 Vol / Page:  205
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Huia</i>... Maori name for a New Zealand bird, like a starling, <i> Heteralocha acutirostris</i>, Gould, of limited occurrence, chiefly found in North island; having beak straight and short in the male, long and curved in female. The tail feathers are highly prized for ornament by the Maoris. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1923  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  6/96
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Heteralocha acutirostis Gould. Huia. </i>
 Notes:  Myers Endemic Birds

 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  55/143
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>hu[u]ia</i>, a bird (Heteralocha acutirostris): white-tipped tail-feathers valued as ornaments: bird now extinct. A small, long, narrow, carved box (equivalent of our jewel-box) called waka-huia (waka here means container), a receptacle for feathers; but only huia-feathers. 


 Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  174
 Edition:  
 Quote:  huia : forest bird, now probably extinct, noted for difference in bills in male and female, and white band of tailfeathers. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1948  
 Source:  NZ Forest inhabiting Birds
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:   ...the only [bird] in which the bills of the sexes are different in shape ... now so rare that it is probably extinct ... Even in the days of the Maori its habitat was very restricted, confined as it was to parts of the Rimutaka, Tararua, Ruahine & Kaimanawa ranges.

hump
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: [AND a. obs. an arduous walk carrying a load on one's back 1890 Bold as only cit., but quoting a prior NZ ref: 1863 J.G.Walker Jrnl 7 Jan [MS.] 4 [this is OED ref, and needs checking and reconciling with my ref] b. a swagman 1955 only quot.] a

difficult (?tiring) walk or tramp carrying a load (on the back)

hump
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a term of abuse (phs a rhyming variant of lump). 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
hump
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: verb
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a. to carry (on the back or shoulders, and esp. a tiring load). Prob. introduced to NZ by Aust. gold-diggers; and phs orig. from English dial (cf EDD), phs reinforced by rhyme with lump v. of similar meaning, and similar metaphorical associations (lump/hump on back). 


 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes:

 Vol / Page:  7
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Found a log of dead wood, humped [fn] Anglice[e acute] - carried on shoulder] for a mile-and-a-half, - made a small fire, ...

 Vol / Page:

 Quote:  - lost the mare at Watts but found her coming home - could not catch her so humped the blankets &c.

hump and hollow
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: verb
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: to contour a flat swamp paddock into one with humps and hollows to promote drainage.

 Domain: Rural

 Date:  25/10/2001

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  19
 Edition:  
 Quote:  One way in which it [the development programme] will do this is to 'hump and hollow' some of the pakihi soils and to 'flip' pasture. Humping and hollowing creates contoured surfaces to promote drainage. The plan at this stage is to turn all those properties that are able to be flipped or humped and hollowed into dairying.

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:

 Quote:  We hesitate not to confess ourselves admirers of the Hundred system and of agriculture rather

then runholding, ... 1947 Note: The whole leader is an argument against declaring Hundreds before it becomes absolutely necessary, ...

 Date:  0/0/1949  
 Source:  Selected Documents
 Author:  RUTHERFORD
 Vol / Page:  112e
 Edition:  
 Quote:   [The runanga] will bear the same relation to other political machinery ... as the township in the United States of America bears to the county and state organization, and ministers suggest the name of township as the most suitable English term for the community that will be represented by a single runanga. it will correspond with the division of hundreds proposed by his Excellency. 

[Grey's annotation] i should have preferred the term `hundred'. it is already in use here. The natives will make a strange word out of `township'. 


 Notes:  1861 Nov 1 Memorandum by Ministers on Governor Grey's Proposed institutions for the Native Race in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 112e

 Date:  0/0/1949  
 Source:  Selected Documents
 Author:  RUTHERFORD
 Vol / Page:  112A
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Each district [of the proposed Maori portion of the North island] to be divided into about six hundreds from the runangas of each of which will be selected two persons to represent such hundred in the runanga of the district, and to act as assessor or native magistrate. 


 Notes:  1861 Nov 2 Sir George Grey Memorandum in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 112a

 Date:  0/0/1874  
 Source:  Colonial Experiences
 Author:  BATHGATE
 Vol / Page:  197
 Edition:  
 Quote:   [in Otago] a `hundred' and the land is then opened up for sale at 1 [pound] per acre.... The purchases of land within a `hundred' have the exclusive privilege of depasturing stock upon the unsold lands within the `hundred' in proportion to their purchased property. A small fee or

assessment of so much per head, is paid to the Government for this privilege. [Until the land is sold. All land unsold after a few years may be brought at ten shillings per acre] 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
 Author:  HOCKEN
 Vol / Page:  167
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The old Otago Block had already been divided into Hundreds, at first three in number, but was now subdivided for greater convenience into eight. The first extended from the Heads to the Taieri river, ... Within these Hundreds the rural lands were open for sale at 10s. and acre, with the  40s. improvement conditions. Outside them were 600,000 acres, open for sale at  10s. an acre, in blocks of not less than 2000 acres, without the improvement clause.

 Date:  0/0/1849  
 Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  1/175
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The flax (<i>korari</i>,) forming the dresses is of two or [176] three kinds; the most coarse, called muka, is employed for working the common garment (<i>kakaou</i>[a1-acute] <i>maori></i>[a-acute].) This flax is also made use of for laying up ropes, lines, &c. The superior dress called Kaitaka[a2-a3-acute], is made from silken flax, (<i>hunga hunga</i>[as-acute].) 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1868  
 Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
 Author:  LiNDSAY
 Vol / Page:  82
 Edition:  
 Quote:  in Otago the general name of the [flax] plant, as a whole, is `Korari,' - or as metamorphosed by the settler, pronounced and spelt `Koura<i>d</i>i,' [a-macron] or `Cora<i>d</i>i' [a-macron]. The same term is applied in the North island equally to the whole plant, and to the dried flower-stem when cut for rafts or other purposes; or exclusively to the flower-stalk. in the North [83] island, the Flax-plant is also known as `Harakeke,' or `Herekiakia,' - its usual name there. ... The lower part of the flower-stem is `Kaikaha;' the outer part of the leaf `Parakoka;' [a1, o-macron] the refuse of the leaf `Hunga-hunga;' the flax, dressed or not, or scraped fibre, manufactured from the leaf, `Whitau,' or `Muka.'

 Quote:  Sheep - it is in their nature to be inconvenient - are invariably over or down or up there, and shepherds want them somewhere else. They must be hunted to that place, in dog trials off the flat and up the hill in the Straight Hunt. The ZigZag uses three sets of two poles to represent such obstacles and the dog must hunt the sheep left, then right, then left through them.

 Quote:  To hunt sheep off the higher parts of their winter country onto lower, safer [land] when snow is expected; e.g., `We hunted down every day for a week, but no snow came.'  Quote:  Hunt down. To hunt the sheep off the higher parts of their winter country on to lower, safer spurs when snow is expected, e.g., `We hunted down every day for a week, but no snow came.' This is a very common expression in the Lakes district of Otago. i cannot remember hearing it in

Canterbury, though the job is done often enough. (C,1918)

huntaway
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
 Author:  McLiNTOCK
 Vol / Page:  1/493
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Huntaway. in both huntaway classes three sheep are set loose at the foot of the hill. While the shepherd remains at the bottom, his dog, working and barking to command, hunts the sheep

upwards on a defined line away from his master. in the zig-zag hunt, the sheep are directed through three sets of flags 1 chain apart and spaced equally up the hill on a zig-zag course of approximately 440 yards. The course for the straight hunt is about the same length, from the

foot of the hill up to and through a set of flags 1 chain apart.
 Notes:

 Notes:  

huntaway
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a dog that barks on command, trained to control sheep; a noisy sheepdog trained to drive sheep forward, away from the musterer; a special type of NZ sheep dog used for mustering; driving and backing dog that barks on command; see also Nelson huntaway.


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 Vol / Page:  E8

 Quote:  The affable, witty, almost Bertie Wooster-like character, Terrence, works a restaurant with all the skill of a huntaway at a dog trial.
 Notes:  

 Date:  11/9/1912  
 Source:  Otago Witness
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  35
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A huntaway should be a free-running dog,

noisy, and under good command, and should

lose points for not taking directions

readily, insufficient noise, being too

rash or too slow, and not keeping the

sheep on a good course.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1913  
 Source:  Country Work
 Author:  CARR
 Vol / Page:  33
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A new hand ... is wise investing in a good huntaway or a heading dog. He can practice [sic] on the `killers' i.e. the sheep kept handy for station use, or better still, a good noisy yard dog, as all

station hands are liable to be called upon to assist in drafting, etc. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  28/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  17
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Huntaway.A dog whose work is to drive sheep forward when mustering. As a verb the word is used in two sense, illustrated in the sentences: `That dog hunts away well' and `i hunt away with that dog.'  (C.) 


 Notes:  

 Date:  25/11/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that  bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be  taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special  slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.) 


 Notes:  Acland Glossary

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
 Author:  McLiNTOCK
 Vol / Page:  1/493
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The huntaway sheep dog is a New Zealand development. Original imported strains were all heading dogs whose instinctive method was to head the sheep and, working silently, to pull them

back to their masters. Early New Zealand shepherds, however, needed the occasional noisy dog which could flush sheep from cover on rough country. ...  Huntaway: A noisy dog, whose natural instinct is to hunt or chase sheep away. On account of their noise, they are used for forcing mobs, work in the sheep yards, and for clearing or hunting sheep off tracts of country.

 Notes:   [1986 NZPOD 366; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 239]

 Date:  0/0/1985  
 Source:  Working Dogs
 Author:  RENNiE
 Vol / Page:  12
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Beardie was developed as a barking dog because in some parts of Scotland, particularly in the Western Highlands, much of the ground is covered with bracken, which combined with the deep gullies known as corries, makes it impossible for a heading dog to see his sheep. Here the

shepherd has to get out above the sheep and more or less chase them out of the thick cover. These dogs were known as hunters, and it is presumably an adaptation of this name which led to the designation, huntaway. At the turn of the century there were four well known strains of huntaways about North Canterbury and Marlborough - the Clown, Rag, Borderglen's Rose and Pollock's Old Clyde breeds. Of these the Clown strain certainly had Beardie blood, believed to have been started with a half Beardie brought out from Scotland. 


 Notes:

 Quote:  i attended the making of a hunters' pie. When the fire was well burnt down i scraped the sticks and embers away, plaining the pie with the folded side on top.

hurdy-gurdy
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1948  
 Source:  Gumdigger, The
 Author:  REED
 Vol / Page:  56
 Edition:  
 Quote:   `hurdy-gurdy' [is a hand gum-washing machine, turned by a handle] -->[See also Reed Story of Kauri Gum] 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Gumdiggers, The
 Author:  REED
 Vol / Page:  82
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The machine age on the gumfield appears to have been heralded as early as 1915 when an 

ingenious digger, whose name has unfortunately been forgotten, introduced what came to be known as the `hurdy-gurdy' or `gurdy.' ... [83] in its simplest form it was a tub, or a section of a

small galvanised iron tank, the bottom perforated with small holes. in the centre stood a strong, revolving, upright shaft, to the lower part of which was attached a wooden paddle, extending on both sides of the shaft, almost to the sides of the tank. The top of the revolving shaft was fitted with a horizontal handle, enabling the paddle to be swung to and fro in a half-circle. This simple machine was usually operated by two men; a supply of gum-bearing dirt having been put into the tank, buckets of water were thrown in by one man while the other vigorously turned the shaft handle this way and that, stirring up the soil while the muddy water flowed out through the perforations.
 Notes:

 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1847  
 Source:  Savage Life
 Author:  ANGAS
 Vol / Page:  1/323
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The other garments of skins are the <i>huru huru</i>, and the <i>parawai</i>; the former is frequently worn, especially during the cold season, by the people of Cook's Straits and the districts south of Taupo [and is made of dog's skins] ... The other dress, called <i>parawai</i>, is exceedingly scarce; it comes from the Southern island, and is made of strips of dog's fur, arranged indiscriminately all over a very large mat of the finest flax.

 Quote:  in August 1918 High McCully of Waitohi showed a gathering of local farmers what his new drag harrow was capable of doing. This cultivator, which he called a 'hustler' had a width of 6 ft 9 and a half ins and was fitted with fifteeen tines. Hustlers are commonplace nowadays.

 Notes:  

hut
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: (in early colonial use) a simple house, usually  having only one room.; (then) spec. (esp. in the mountain country) of trampers' and musterers' etc. huts, but cf and cp crib, shack, whare, cf daub and wattle hut.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes:

 Vol / Page:  3
 Edition:  
 Quote:  At the end of the bush an alarming fire occurred, the high wind blowing the sparks of an open air fire against a neighbouring hut, built of dried fern and wattles.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1857  
 Source:  Letters from Canterbury, NZ
 Author:  PAUL
 Vol / Page:  90
 Edition:  
 Quote:  You are fairly entitled to something better than a warre[e-acute], say a two-roomed hut for yourself ... and a large, strong wata, or store raised on posts to keep your provisions safe

from rats. ... slabs plastered with clay are also used for walls ... One of these huts must serve you for your first year's wool-shed, with the help of a few hurdles in front, 

.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Merriam-Webster Third international
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  2024
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hut (h&ubreve.t), n. [Add.] 2. A house for shearers or other labourers on a station; as, the men's 

hut, there shearers' hut. This is sometimes a large, permanent structure of wood, brick, or stone. 

-->1898 Morris AE 207 Hut, n the cottage of a shepherd or a miner. The word is English but is 

especially common in Australia, and does not there connote squalor or meanness. The `Men's Hut' on a station is the building occupied by the male employees. [1844]

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
 Author:  BEATTiE
 Vol / Page:  33
 Edition:  
 Quote:  He [the pioneer pastoralist] has built a domicile of some sort, be it of canvas, calico, bagging, sticks, ferntrees, grass, slabs, mud, clay, stone, or wattle and daub. He may call it various names

according to its materials, but three names would not enter his head - i.e., crib, back, or shack. He may call it a cabin, a shanty, a cottage, a warrie [whare], but probably he would use the commonest term of all - hut. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
 Author:  BEATTiE
 Vol / Page:  11
 Edition:  
 Quote:  There is a danger of all writers about the old days using modern terms which were not used in the period they were writing about, and i have always tried to steer clear of this pit. Young writers are particularly prone to go astray in this matter, and we see talk of pioneer shacks in Otago, using a modern Canadian word, where an Otago pioneer would have said hut or warrie. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1982

 Author:  367

 Quote:  hut 1 n. ... NZ & Austral. accommodation for stockmen, shearers, etc. on a station. 3 hut-keeper NZ & Austral. person who looks after huts on a station during working hours. 


 Notes:  [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]

 Date:  0/0/1987  
 Source:  Boards, Blades & Barebellies
 Author:  OGONOWSKA-COATES
 Vol / Page:  96
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hut. House where the station hands or shearers live. Some call it a whare. Until the 1930s and

40s the men usually ate, cooked and slept in a one-roomed hut with a fireplace at one end and bunks in tiers around the walls. Often there were no facilities for washing other than the creek. Today most huts are quite comfortable, with separate rooms for eating and sleeping, showers and toilets.

 Date:  0/9/2003  
 Source:  NZ Heritage
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  No. 90/10
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Jack's Hut, near the summit of Arthur's Pass, is a rare surviving example of the roadmen's huts that dotted New Zealand's highest altitude main highway. Each roadman was responsible for maintaining a section of the road - clearing slips, filling in potholes - and lived with his family in a hut along his stretch.

 Citations 
 Date:  0/8/2008  
 Source:  FMC - (Federated Mountain Clubs of NZ) Bulletin
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  41
 Edition:  
 Quote:  He also contracted the hut-bagging disease rife amongst VUWTC members, and he says his tally is now somewhere in the 700s, with 300-odd to go. While he acknowledges that hut-bagging can become a silly obsession - "where one can't see the hills for the huts" - it does have the advantage of "leading me to places i would not normally think of tramping".

 Date:  0/0/1868

 Author:  LiNDSAY
 Vol / Page:  59
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hence the plant [<i>Acaena sanguisorbae</i>] is only too familiar, as the `Native Burr' to the sheep farmers alike of New Zealand, Australia, and Tasmania. ... To the Otago settler the plant is also known as the `Bidi-bidi,' or `Beta-beta;' to the North island Maori as `Hutiwai,' `Piri-piri,' (Colenso), or `Piri-kahu,' (Colenso).

 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
 Author:  HiLGENDORF
 Vol / Page:  99
 Edition:  
 Quote:  PiRi PiRi (<i>Aceara ... sanguisorbae</i>). This name is commonly corrupted into [called] bidi bid. in the North island the plant is called hutiwai or utiwai and by mistake poroporo. it is a native species well known to all New Zealanders, and is a weed chiefly on land in process of being brought into occupation. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1936  
 Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  363
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hutiwai (<i>Acaena [364] sanguisorbae</i> and <i>A. novae zelandiae</i>) are indigenous weeds of hilly country devoted almost entirely to sheep grazing.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1861  
 Source:  Samuel Butler
 Author:  JONES
 Vol / Page:  1/87
 Edition:  
 Quote:  April, 1861 - it is Sunday. We rose later than usual. There are five men sleeping in the

hut. i sleep in a bunk on one side of the fire, Mr. Haast ... sleeps upon the opposite one; my bullock-driver and hut-keeper have two bunks at the far end of the hut, along the wall; ... The usual mutton and bread for breakfast with a pudding made of flour and water baked in the camp-oven after a joint of meat - Yorkshire pudding, but without eggs. While we were at breakfast, a robin perched on the table and sat there a good while pecking at the sugar. 


 Notes:  1861 April Butler's Note in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler - A Memoir 1/87

hydraulic deal
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: (hire purchase)
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  12/4/1985  
 Source:  Evening Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A HiGH COURT jury was told by Crown counsel Justin Smith in Wellington yesterday of a 

hire purchase `hydraulic deal' - a transaction, in which a hire purchase agreement stated a deposit had been paid whereas, in fact, it had not. ... Mr Smith said that during the trial the jury would hear about what was known colloquially as a `hydraulic deal'. This was a situation where there was a deal in which a dealer intended to sell a truck for, say, $50,000 and required a deposit of

$10,000 by any hire purchaser.  in the case of a $50,000 truck (a hypothetical example) the dealer knew the hire purchase company was going to have reservations about financing the full $50,000.  `So the dealer draws up a hire purchase agreement anyway. The real price is still $50,000. But on the agreement the dealer said he had received the sum of $10,000 by way of deposit.'  Mr Smith said that if a hire purchase company accepted the assignment of the agreement the dealer got his money in full and the customer got his truck (then claimed to be worth $60,000) without having to pay a deposit.
 Notes:  1985? Apr? c12-24 Dom ?Evening Post - check date
